SP.P: But what speake I of the diseases of the body, children of the Fayre?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: That's to vs, Sister. Braue i'faith!

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Harke, O, you sonnes and daughters of Smithfield! and heare what mallady it doth the minde: It causeth swearing, it causeth swaggering, it causeth snuffling, and snarling, and now and then a hurt.

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: He hath something of Master Ouerdo, mee thinkes, bro∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: So mee thought, Sister, very much of my brother Ouer∣doo: And 'tis, when he speakes.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Looke into any Angle o'the towne, (the Streights, or the Bermuda's) where the quarrelling lesson is read, and how doe they entertaine the time, but with bottle-ale, and tabacco? The Lecturer is o'one side, and his Pupils o'the other; But the seconds are still bottle ale, and tabacco, for which the Lecturer reads, and rhe Nouices pay. Thirty pound a weeke in bole-ale! forty in ta∣bacco! and ten more in Ale againe. Then for a sute to drinke in, so much, and (that being slauer'd) so much for another sute, and then a third sute, and a fourth sute! and still the bottle-ale slaue∣reth, and the tabacco stinketh!

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P:
Heart of a mad-man! are you rooted heere? well you
neuer away? what can any man finde out in this bawling fellow, to grow heere for? hee is a full handfull higher, sin'he heard him, will you fix heere? and set vp a Booth? Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: I will conclude briefely—

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Hold your peace, you roaring Rascall, I'le runne my head i'your chaps else. You were best build a Booth, and en∣tertaine him, make your Will, and you say the word, and him your heyre! heart, I neuer knew one taken with a mouth of a peeke, a∣fore. By this light, I'le carry you away o' my backe, and you will not come.He gets him vp on pick∣packe.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Stay Numpes, stay, set mee downe: I ha' lost my purse, Numps, O my purse! one o'my fine purses is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: OVER.
SP.P: Is't indeed, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I, as I am an honest man, would I were an errant Rogue, else! a plague of all roguy, damn'd cut-purses for me.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Blesse 'hem with all my heart, with all my heart, do you see! Now, as I am no Infidell, that I know of, I am glad on't. I I am, (here's my witnesse!) doe you see, Sir? I did not tell you of his fables, I? no, no, I am a dull malt-horse, I, I know nothing. Are you not iustly seru'd i'your conscience now? speake i'your consci∣ence. Much good doe you with all my heart, and his good heart that has it, with all my heart againe.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: This fellow is very charitable, would he had a purse too! but, I must not be too bold, all at a time.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Nay, Numps, it is not my best purse.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Not your best! death! why should it be your worst? why should it be any, indeed, at all? answer me to that, gi'mee a reason from you, why it should be any?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Nor my gold, Numps; I ha' that yet, looke heere else, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why so, there's all the feeling he has!

SP.SPEAKER: OVER.
SP.P: I pray you, haue a better care of that, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Nay, so I will, I warrant you; let him catch this, that catch can. I would aine see him get this, looke you heere.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: So, so, so, so, so, so, so, so! Very good.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I would ha' him come againe, now, and but offer at it. Sister, will you take notice of a good iest? I will put it iust where th'other was, and if we ha' good lucke, you shall see a delicate fine trap to catch the cutpurse, nibling.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Faith, and he'll trye ere you be out o'the Fayre.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Come, Mistresse Grace, pre'thee be not melancholy for my mis-chance; sorrow wi'not keepe it, Sweet heart.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: I doe not thinke on't, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: COOK.
SP.P: 'Twas but a little scuruy white money, hang it: it may hang the cutpurse, one day. I ha' gold left to gi'thee a fayring, yet, as hard as the world goes: nothing angers me, but that no body heere, look'd like a cutpurse, vnlesse 'twere Numps.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS
SP.P: How? I? I looke like a cutpurse? death! your Sister's a cutpurse! and your mother and father, and all your kinne were cutpurses! And here is a Rogue is the baud o'the cutpurses, whom I will beat to begin with.

SP.SPEAKER: OVER.
SP.P: Good Mr Humphrey.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: You are the Patrico! are you? the Patriarch of the cutpurses? you share, Sir, they say, let them share this with you. Are you i'your hot fit of preaching againe? I'le coole you.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Murther, murther, murther.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Hold thy hand, childe of wrath, and heyre of anger,They speake all together: and Waspe beats the Iustice. make it not Childermasse day in thy fury, or the feast of the French Bartholmew, Parent of the of the Massacre.

NAy, tish all gone, now! dish tish, phen tou vilt not be phitin call, Master Offi∣sher, phat ish a man te better to lishen out noyshes for tee, & tou art in an oder 'orld, being very shuffishient noyshes and gallantsh too, one o'their brabblesh woud haue fed vsh all dish fortnight, but tou art so bushy about beggersh stil, tou hast no leshure to intend shentlemen, and't be.

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: Why, I told you, Dauy Bristle.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P:
Come, come, you told mee a pudding, Toby Haggise; A matter of nothing; I am sure it came to nothing! you said, let's goe o Vrsla's, indeede; but then you met the man with the mon∣sters,
and I could not get you from him. An old foole, not leaue seeing yet?

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: Why, who would ha' thought any body would ha' quar∣rell'd so earely? or that the ale o'the Fayre would ha' beene vp so soone.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Phy? phat a clocke toest tou tinke it ish, man?

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: I cannot tell.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI▪
SP.P: Tou art a vishe vatchman, i'te meane teeme.

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: Why? should the watch goe by the clocke, or the clock by the watch, I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: One should goe by another, if they did well.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Tou art right now! phen didst tou euer know, or heare of a shuffishient vatchman, but he did tell the clocke, phat bushi∣nesse soeuer he had?

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Nay, that's most true, a sufficient watchman knowes what a clocke it is.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Shleeping, or vaking! ash well as te clocke himshelfe, or te lack dat shtrikes him!

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Let's enquire of Master Leatherhead, or Ione Trash heere. Master Leatherhead, doe you heare, Master Leatherhead?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: If it be a Ledderhead, tish a very tick Ledderhead, tat sho mush noish vill not peirsh him.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: I haue a little businesse now, good friends doe not trou∣ble me.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Phat? because o'ty wrought neet cap, and ty pheluet sherkin, Man? phy? I haue sheene tee in ty Ledder sherkin, ere now, Mashter o'de hobby-Horses, as bushy and as stately as tou sheem'st to be▪

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Why, what an' you haue, Captaine Whit? hee has his choyce of Ierkins, you may see by that, and his caps too, I assure you, when hee pleases to be either sicke, or imploy'd.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: God a mercy Ione, answer for me.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Away, be not sheen i'my company, here be shentlemen, and men of vorship.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. III. SCENE. II.
DIV2.STAGE: QVARLOVS. WHIT. WIN-VVIFE. BVSY. IOHN. PVRE-CRAFT. WIN. KNOK. HVM. MOON-CALFE. VRSLA.

SP.P: WEe had wonderfull ill lucke, to misse this prologue o'the purse, but the best is, we shall haue fiue Acts of him ere night: hee'le be spectacle enough! I'le answer for't.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: O Creesh! Duke Quarlous, how dosht tou? tou dosht not know me, I feare? I am te vishesht man, but Iustish Ouerdoo, in all Bartholmew Fayre, now. Gi' me tweluepence from tee, I vill help tee to a vife vorth forty marks for't, and't be.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Away, Rogue, Pimpe away.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: And shee shall shew tee as fine cut o'rke fort't in her shmock too, as tou cansht vishe i'faith; vilt tou haue her, vorship∣full Vin vife? I vill helpe tee to her, heere, be an't be, in te pig-quarter▪ gi'me ty twelpence from tee,

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Why, there's twelpence, pray thee wilt thou be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI,
SP.P: Tou art a vorthy man, and a vorshipfull man still.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Get you gone, Rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: I doe meane it, man. Prinsh Quarlous if tou hast need on me, tou shalt finde me heere, at Vrsla's, I vill see phat ale, and punque ish i'te pigshty, for tee, blesse ty good vorship.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Looke! who comes heere! Iohn Little-wit!

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: And his wife, and my widdow, her mother: the whole family.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: 'Slight, you must gi'hem all fairings, now!

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Not I, I'le not see 'hem,

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: They are going a feasting. What Schole-master's that s with 'hem?

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: That's my Riuall, I beleeue, the Baker!

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: So, walke on in the middle way, fore-right, turne ney∣ther to the right hand, nor to the left: let not your eyes be drawne aside with vanity, nor your eare with noyses.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: O, I know him by that start!

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: What do you lack? what do you buy, pretty Mistris! a fine Hobby-Horse, to make your sonne a Tilter? a Drum to make him a Souldier? a Fiddle, to make him a Reueller? What is't you lack? Little Dogs for your Daughters! or Babies, male, or female?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Look not toward them, harken not: the place is Smithfield, or the field of Smiths, the Groue of Hobbi-horses and trinkets, the wares are the wares of diuels. And the whole Fayre is the shop of Satan! They are hooks, and baites, very baites, that are hung out on euery side, to catch you, and to hold you as it were, by the gills; and by the nostrills, as the Fisher doth: therefore, you must not looke, nor turne toward them— The Heathen man could stop his eares with wax, against the harlot o'the sea: Doe you the like, with your fingers against the bells of the Beast.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: What flashes comes from him!

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: O, he has those of his ouen! a notable hot Baker 'twas, when hee ply'd the peele: hee is leading his flocke into the Fayre, now.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Rather driuing 'hem to the Pens: for he will let 'hem looke vpon nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P:
Gentlewomen, the weather's hot! whither walke you?
Haue a care o'your fine veluet caps, the Fayre is dusty. Take a sweet delicate Booth,Little-wit is gazing at the signe; which is the Pigs-head with a large writing vn∣der it. with boughs, here, ithe way, and coole your selues i'the shade: you and your friends. The best pig and bottle-ale i' the Fayre, Sir. Old Vrsla is Cooke, there you may read: the pigges head speakes it. Poore soule, shee has had a Sringhalt, the Maryhin∣chco: but shee's prettily amended.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: A delicate show-pig, little Mistris, with shweet sauce, and crackling, like de bay-leafe i'de fire, la! Tou shalt ha'de cleane side o'de table-clot and di glass vash'd with phatersh of Dame Annessh Cleare.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: This's sine, verily, here be the best pigs: and shee doe's roast 'hem as well as euer she did; the Pigs head sayes.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Excellent, excellent, Mistris, with fire o' Iuniper and Rose∣mary branches! The Oracle of the Pigs head, that, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: Sonne, were you not warn'd of the vanity of the eye? haue you forgot the wholesome admonition, so soone?

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Good mother, how shall we finde a pigge, if we doe not looke about for't? will it run off o'the spit, into our mouths thinke you? as in Lubberland? and cry, we, we?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: No, but your mother, religiously wise, conceiueth it may offer it selfe, by other meanes, to the sense, as by way of steeme which I thinke it doth, here in this place (Huh, huh) yes, it doth. and it were a sinne of obstinacy,Busy sents after it like a Hound. great obstinacy, high and hor∣rible obstinacy, to decline, or resist the good titillation of the famelick sense, which is the smell. Therefore be bold (huh, huh, huh) follow the sent. Enter the Tents of the vncleane, for once, and satisfie your wiues frailty. Let your fraile wife be satisfied: your zealous mother, and my suffering selfe, will also be satisfi∣ed.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Come, Win, as good winny here, as goe farther, and see nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Wee scape so much of the other vanities, by our earely entring.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: It is an aedifying consideration.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: This is scuruy, that wee must come into the Fayre, and not looke on't.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Win, haue patience, Win, I'le tell you more anon.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Moone-calfe, entertaine within there, the best pig i'the Booth; a Porklike pig. These are Banbury-bloods, o'the sincere stud, come a pigge-hunting. Whit, wait Whit, looke to your charge.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: A pigge prepare, presently, let a pigge be prepared to vs.

SP.SPEAKER: MOo.
SP.P: S'light, who be these?

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: Is this the good seruice, Iordan, you'ld doe me?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Why, Vrs? why, Vrs? thou'lt ha' vapours i'thy legge againe presently, pray thee go in, 't may turne to the scratches else.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: Hang your vapours, they are stale, and stinke like you, are these the guests o'the game, you promis'd to fill my pit with∣all, to day?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: I what aile they Vrs?

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: Aile they? they are all sippers, sippers o'the City, they looke as they would not drinke off two penn'orth of bottle-ale a∣mongst 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: MOO.
SP.P: A body may read that i'their small printed ruffes.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Away, thou art a foole, Vrs, and thy Moone-calfe too, i'your ignorant vapours, now? hence, good guests, I say right hypocrites, good gluttons. In, and set a couple o'pigs o'the board, and halfe a dozen of the biggest bottles afore 'hem, and call Whit, I doe not loue to heare Innocents abus'd: Fine ambling hypo∣crites! and a stone-puritane, with a sorrell head, and beard, good mouth'd gluttons: two to a pigge, away.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: Are you sure they are such?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: O'the right breed, thou shalt try 'hem by the teeth, Vrs, where's this Whit?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.L: Behold, man and see, what a worthy man am ee!
With the fury of my sword, and the shaking of my beard,
I will make ten thousand men afeard.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Well said, braue Whit, in, and feare the ale out o'the bottles, into the bellies of the brethren, and the sisters drinke to the cause, and pure vapours.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: My Roarer is turn'd Tapster, mee thinks. Now were a fine time for thee, Win-wife, to lay aboard thy widdow, thou'lt ne∣uer be Master of a better season, or place; shee that will venture her selfe into the Fayre, and a pig-boxe, will admit any assault, be assur'd of that.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: I loue not enterprises of that suddennesse, though.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: I'le warrant thee, then, no wife out o'the widdowes Hundred: if I had but as much Title to her, as to haue breath'd once on that streight stomacher of hers, I would now assure my selfe to carrry her, yet, ere shewent out of Smithfield. Or she should carry me, which were the fitter sight, I confesse. But you are a mo∣dest vndertaker, by circumstances, and degrees; come, 'tis Disease in thee, not Iudgement, I should offer at all together. Looke, here's the poore foole, againe, that was stung by the waspe, ere while.

I will make no more orations, shall draw on these tragicall con∣clusions. And I begin now to thinke, that by a spice of collate∣rall Iustice, Adam Ouerdoo, deseru'd this beating; for I the said Adam, was one cause (a by-cause) why the purse was lost: and my wiues brothers purse too, which they know not of yet. But I shall make very good mirth with it, at supper, (that will be the sport) and put my little friend, Mr Humphrey Wasp's choler quite out of counte∣nance. When, sitting at the vpper end o'my Table, as I vse, & drink∣ing to my brother Cokes, and Mrs. Alice Ouerdoo, as I wil, my wife, for their good affectiō to old Bradley, I deliuer to'hem, it was I, that was cudgell'd, and shew 'hem the marks. To see what bad euents may peepe out o'the taile of good purposes! the care I had of that ciuil yong man, I tooke fancy to this morning, (and haue not left it yet) drew me to that exhortation, which drew the company, indeeede, which drew the ut-purse; which drew the money; which drew my brother Cokes his losse; which drew on Wasp's anger; which drew on my beating: a pretty gradation! And they shall ha' it i'their dish, i'faith, at night for fruit: I loue to be merry at my Ta∣ble. I had thought once, at one speciall blow he ga'me, to haue re∣uealed my selfe? but then (I thank thee fortitude) I remembred that a wise man (and who is euer so great a part, o'the Common-wealth in himselfe) for no particular disaster ought to abandon a publike good designe. The husbandman ought not for one vn∣thankful yeer, to forsake the plough; The Shepheard ought not, for one scabb'd sheep, to throw by his tar-boxe; The Pilot ought not for one leake i'the poope, to quit the Helme; Nor the Alderman ought not for one custerd more, at a meale, to giue vp his cloake; The Constable ought not to breake his staffe, and forsweare the watch, for one roaring night; Nor the Piper o'the Parish (Vt par∣uis componere magna solebam) to put vp his pipes, for one rainy Sunday. These are certaine knocking conclusions; out of which, I am resolu'd, come what come can, come beating, come imprison∣ment, come infamy, come banishment, nay, come the rack, come the hurdle, (welcome all) I will not discouer who I am, till my due time; and yet still, all shall be, as I said euer, in Iustice name, and the King's, and for the Common-wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: What doe's he talke to himselfe, and act so seriously? poore foole!

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: No matter what. Here's fresher argument, intend that.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. III. SCENE. IIIJ.
DIV2.STAGE: COKES. LEATHERHEAD. WASPE. Mistresse OVERDOO. WIN-VVIFE. QVARLOVS. TRASH. GRACE.

SP.P: COme, Mistresse Grace, come Sister, heere's more fine sights, yet i'faith. Gods 'lid where's Numps?

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: What doe you lacke, Gentlemen? what is't you buy? fine Rattles! Drummes? Babies? little Dogges? and Birds for Ladies? What doe you lacke?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Good honest Numpes, keepe afore, I am so afraid thou'lt lose somewhat: my heart was at my mouth, when I mist thee.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: You were best buy a whip i'your hand to driue me.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Nay, doe not mistake, Numps, thou art so apt to mis∣take: I would but watch the goods. Looke you now, the treble fiddle, was e'en almost like to be lost.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Pray you take heede you lose not your selfe: your best way, were e'en get vp, and ride for more surety. Buy a tokens worth of great pinnes, to fasten your selfe to my shoulder.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: What doe you lacke, Gentlemen? fine purses, pouches, pincases, pipes? What is't you lacke? a paire o'smithes to wake you i'the morning? or a fine whistling bird?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Numps, here be finer things then any we ha' bought by oddes! and more delicate horses, a great deale! good Numpes, stay▪ and come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Will you scourse with him? you are in Smithfield, you may fit your selfe with a fine easy-going street-nag, for your sad∣dle again' Michaelmasse-terme, doe, has he ne'er a little odde cart for you, to make a Carroch on, i'the countrey, with foure pyed hob∣byhorses? why the meazills, should you stand heere, with your traine, cheaping of Dogges, Birds, and Babies? you ha' no chil∣dren to bestow 'hem on? ha' you?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: No, but again' I ha' children, Numps, that's all one.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Do, do, do, do; how many shall you haue, think you? an' I were as you, I'ld buy for all my Tenants, too, they are a kind o'ciuill Sauages, that wil part with their children for rattles, pipes, and kniues. You were best buy a hatchet, or two, & truck with 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Good Numps, hold that little tongue o'thine, and saue it a labour. I am resolute Bat, thou know'st.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: A resolute foole, you are, I know, and a very sufficient Coxcombe; with all my heart; nay you haue it, Sir, and you be angry, turd i'your teeth, twice: (if I said it not once afore) and much good doe you.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: Was there euer such a selfe-affliction? and so imper∣tinent?

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Alas! his care will goe neere to cracke him, let's in, and comfort him.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Would I had beene set i'the ground, all but the head on me, and had my braines bowl'd at, or thresh'd out, when first I vnderwent this plague of a charge!

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: How now, Numps! almost tir'd i'your Protectorship? ouerparted? ouerparted?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why, I cannot tell, Sir, it may be I am, dos't grieue you?

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: No, I sweare dos't not, Numps: to satisfie you.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Numps? S'blood, you are fine and familiar! how long ha' wee bin acquainted, I pray you?

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: I thinke it may be remembred, Numps, that? 'twas since morning sure.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why, I hope I know't well enough, Sir, I did not aske to be told.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: No? why then?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: It's no matter why, you see with your eyes, now, what I said to you to day? you'll beleeue me another time?

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Are you remouing the Fayre, Numps?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: A pretty question! and a very ciuill one! yes faith, I ha' my lading you see; or shall haue anon, you may know whose beast I am, by my burthen. If the pannier-mans Iacke were euer better knowne by his loynes of mutton, I'le be flead, and feede dogs for him, when his time comes.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: How melancholi' Mistresse Grace is yonder! pray thee let's goe enter our selues in Grace, with her.

SP.SPEAKER: COK,
SP.P: Those sixe horses, friend I'le haue—

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: And the three Iewes trumps; and halfe a dozen o'Birds, and that Drum, (I haue one Drumme already) and your Smiths; I like that deuice▪ o'your smiths, very pretty well, and foure Hal∣berts —and (le'me see) that fine painted great Lady, and her three women for state, I'le haue.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: No, the shop; buy the whole shop, it will be best, the shop, the shop!

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: If his worship please.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Yes, and keepe it during the Fayre, Bobchin.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P:
Peace, Numps, friend, doe not meddle with him, an'
you be wise, and would shew your head aboue board: hee will sting thorow your wrought night-cap, beleeue me. A set of these Violines, I would buy too, for a delicate young noise I haue i'the countrey, that are euery one a size lesse then another, iust like your fiddles. I would faine haue a fine young Masque at my marriage, now I thinke on't: but I doe want such a number o'things. And Numps will not helpe me now, and I dare not speake to him.

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Will your worship buy any ginger-bread, very good bread, comfortable bread?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Ginger-bread! yes, let's see.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: There's the tother sprindge?He runnes to her shop.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Is this well, goody Ione? to interrupt my market? in the midst? and call away my customers? can you answer this, at the Piepouldres?

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Why? if his Master-ship haue a minde to buy, I hope my ware lies as open as another's; I may shew my ware, as well as you yours.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Hold your peace; I'le content you both: I'le buy vp his shop, and thy basket.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Will you i'faith?

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Why should you put him from it, friend?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Cry you mercy! you'ld be sold too, would you? what's the price on you? Ierkin, and all as you stand? ha' you any qua∣lities?

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Yes, good-man angry-man, you shall finde he has quali∣ties, if you cheapen him.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Gods so, you ha' the selling of him! what are they? will they be bought for loue, or money?

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: No indeed, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: For what then? victualls?

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: He scornes victuals, Sir, he has bread and butter at home, thanks be to God! and yet he will do more for a good meale, if the toy take him i'the belly, mary then they must not set him at lower end; if they do, he'll goe away, though he fast. But put him a top o'the Table, where his place is, and hee'll doe you forty fiue things. Hee has not been sent for, and sought out for nothing, at your great citty-suppers, to put downe Coriat, and Cokeley, and bin laught at for his labour; he'll play you all the Puppets i'the towne ouer, and the Players, euery company, and his owne company too; he spares no body!

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I'faith?

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Hee was the first, Sir, that euer baited the fellow i'the beare's skin, an't like your worship: no dog euer came neer him, since. And for fine motions!

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Is hee good at those too? can hee set out a Masque trow?

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P:
O Lord, Master! sought to farre, and neere, for his in∣uentions:
and hee engrosses all, hee makes all the Puppets i'the Fayre.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Do'st thou (in troth) old veluet Ierkin▪ giue mee thy hand.

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, you shall see him in his veluet Ierkin, and a scarfe, too, at night, when you heare him interpret Master Little∣wit's Motion.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Speake no more, but shut vp shop presently, friend. I'le buy both it, and thee too, to carry downe with me, and he hamper, beside. Thy shop shall furnish out the Masque, and hers the Banquet: I cannot goe lesse, to set out any thing with credit▪ what's the price, at a word, o'thy whole shop, case, and all as it stands?

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Sir, it stands me in sixe and twenty shillings seuen pence, halfe-peny, besides three shillings for my ground.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Well, thirty shillings will doe all, then! And what comes yours too?

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Foure shillings, and eleauen pence, Sir, ground, and all, an't like your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Yes, it do's like my worship very well, poore woman, that's fiue shillings more, what a Masque shall I furnish out, for forty shillings? (twenty pound scotsh) and a Banquet of Ginger-bread? there's a stately thing! Numps? Sister? and my wedding gloues too? (that I neuer thought on afore.) All my wedding gloues, Ginger-bread? O me! what a deuice will there be? to make 'hem eate their fingers ends! and delicate Brooches for the Bride-men! and all! and then I'le h' this poesie put to 'hem: For the best grace, meaning Mistresse Grace, my wedding poesie.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: I am beholden to you, Sir, and to your Bartholmew-wit.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: You doe not meane this, doe you? is this your first pur∣chase?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Yes faith, and I doe not thinke, Numpes, but thou'lt say, it was the wisest Act, that euer I did in my wardship.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Like inough! I shall say any thing. I!

I Cannot beget a Proiect, with all my politicall braine, yet; my Proiect is how to fetch off this proper young man, from his de∣baucht company: I haue followed him all the Fayre ouer, and still I finde him with this songster: And I begin shrewdly to suspect their familiarity; and the young man of a terrible taint, Poetry! with which idle disease, if he be infected, there's no hope of him, in a state-course. Actum est, of him for a common-wealths-man: i hee goe to't in Rime, once.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Yonder he is buying o'Ginger-bread: set in quickly, before he part wirh too much on his money.

P.HI: My masters and friends, and good people, draw neere, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Ballads! harke, harke! pray thee, fellow, stay a little,He runn's the Ballad man. good Numpes, looke to the goods. What Ballads hast thou? let me see, let me see my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why so! hee's flowne `to another lime-bush, there he will flutter as long more; till hee ha' ne'r a feather left. Is there a vexation like this, Gentlemen? will you beleeue mee now, here∣after? shall I haue credit with you?

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Yes faith, shalt thou, Numps, and thou art worthy on't, for thou sweatest for't. I neuer saw a young Pimpe errant, and his Squire better match'd.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Faith, the sister comes after'hem, well, too.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Nay, if you saw the Iustice her husband, my Guardian, you were fitted for the Messe, hee is such a wise one his way—

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: I wonder, wee see him not heere.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: O! hee is too serious for this place, and yet better sport then then the other three, I assure you, Gentlemen: where ere he is, though't be o'the Bench.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: How dost thou call it! A caueat against cutpurses! a good iest, i'faith, I would faine see that Daemon, your Cutpurse, you talke of, that delicate handed Diuell;He show's his purse boastingly. they say he walkes here∣about; I would see him walke, now. Looke you sister, here, here, let him come, sister, and welcome. Ballad-man, do's any cutpur∣ses haunt hereabout? pray thee raise me one or two▪ beginne and shew me one.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P:
Sir, this is a spell against 'hem, spicke and span new; and 'tis made as 'twere in mine owne person, and I sing it in mine owne
defence. But 'twill cost a penny alone, if you buy it.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: No matter for the price, thou dost not know me, I see, I am an odd Bartholmew.

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: Ha'st a fine picture, Brother?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: O Sister, doe you remember the ballads ouer the Nur∣sery-chimney at home o' my owne pasting vp, there be braue pi∣ctures. Other manner of pictures, than these, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Yet these will serue to picke the pictures out o' your pockets, you shall see.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: So, I heard 'hem say. Pray thee mind him not, fellow: hee'll haue an oare in euery thing.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: It was intended Sir, as if a purse should chance to be cut in my presence, now, I may be blamelesse, though: as by the se∣quell, will more plainely appeare.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: We shall find that i'the matter. Pray thee begin.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: To the tune of Paggingtons Pound, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Fa, la la la, la la la, fa la la la. Nay, I'll put thee in tune, and all! mine owne country dance! Pray thee begin.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: It is a gentle admonition, you must know, Sir, both to the purse-cutter, and the purse-bearer.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Not a word more, out o'the tune, an' thou lou'st mee: Fa, la la la, la la la, fa la la la. Come, when?

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.L: My masters and friends, and good people draw neere,
And looke to your purses, for that I doe say;

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Ha, ha, this chimes! good counsell at first dash.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.L: And though little money, in them you doe beare.
It cost more to get, then to lose in a day. COK. Good!
You oft haue beene told,
Both the young and the old; COK. Well said! hee were to blame that wold not i'faith.
And bidden beware of the cutpurse so bold:
Then if you take heed not, free me from the curse,
Who both giue you warning, for and, the cutpurse.
Youth, youth, thou hadst better bin staru'd by thy Nurse,
Then liue to be hanged for cutting a purse.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Good i'faith, how say you, Numps? Is there any harme i'this?

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.L: It hath bin vpbrayded to men of my trade, COK. The more coxcōbes they that did it, I wusse.
That oftē times we are the cause of this crime.
Alacke and for pitty, why should it be said?
As if they regarded or places, or time.
Examples haue been
Of some that were seen,
In Westminster Hall, yea the pleaders between, COK. God a mercy for that! why should they be more free in∣deede?
Then why should the Iudges be free from this curse,
More then my poore selfe, for cutting the purse?
Youth, youth, thou hadst better bin staru'd by the Nurse,
Then liue to be hanged for cutting a purse.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: That againe, good Ballad-man, that againe. O rare!He sings the burden with him. I would faine rubbe mine elbow now, but I dare not pull out my hand. On, I pray thee, hee that made this ballad, shall be Poet to my Masque.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.L: At Worc'ter 'tis knowne well, and euen i'the ayle,
A Knight of good worship did there shew his face,
Against the foule sinners, in zeale for to rayle,
And lost (ipso facto) his purse in the place. COK. Is it possible?
Nay, once from the Seat
Of Iudgement so great,
A Iudge there did lose a faire pouch of veluete. COK. I'faith?
O Lord for thy mercy, how wicked or worse,
Are those that so venture their necks for a purse! Youth, youth, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Youth, youth, &c? pray thee stay a little, friend, yet o'thy conscience, Numps, speake, is there any harme i'this?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: To tell you true, 'tis too good for you, lesse you had grace to follow it.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: It doth discouer enormitie, I'le marke it more: I ha'not lik'd a paltry piece of poetry, so well a good while.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Youth, youth, &c! where's this youth, now? A man must call vpon him, for his owne good, and yet hee will not ap∣peare: looke here, here's for him, handy-dandy,Hee shewes his purse. which hand will he haue? On, I pray there, with the rest, I doe heare of him, but I cannot see him, this Master Youth, the cutpurse.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.L: At Playes and at Sermons, and at the Sessions,
'Tis daily their practice such booty to make:
Yea, vnder the Gallowes, at Executions,
They sticke not the Stare-abouts purses to take.
Nay one without-grace, COK. That was a fine fellow! I would haue him, now.
at a better place,
At Court, & in Christmas, before the Kings face,
Alacke then for pitty must I beare the curse,
That onely belongs to the cunning cutpurse?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: But where's their cunning, now, when they should vse it? they are all chain'd now, I warrant you. Youth, youth, thou hadst better, &c. The Rat-catchers charme, are all fooles and Asses to this! A poxe on 'hem, that they will not come! that a man should haue such a desire to a thing, and want it.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: 'Fore God, I'ld giue halfe the Fayre, and 'twere mine, for a cutpurse for him, to saue his longing.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Looke you Sister, heere, heere, where is't now?Hee shewes his purse a∣gaine. which pocket is't in? for a wager?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I beseech you leaue your wagers, and let him end his matter, an't may be.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: O, are you aedified Numps?

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Indeed hee do's interrupt him, too much: There Numps spoke to purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: againe.Sister, I am an Asse, I cannot keepe my purse: on, on; I pray thee, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.L: But O, you vile nation of cutpurses all,
Relent and repent, and amend and be sound,
Edgworth gets vp to him, and tickles him in the care with a straw twice to draw his hand out of his pocket.And know that you ought not, by honest mens fall,
Aduance your owne fortunes, to die aboue ground,
And though you goe gay,
In silkes as you may,
It is not the high way to heauen, (as they say)
Repent then, repent you, for better, for worse:
And kisse not the Gallowes for cutting a purse.
Youth, youth, thou hadst better bin steru'd by thy Nurse,
Then liue to be hanged for cutting a purse.

SP.SPEAKER: WINW.
SP.P: Will you see sport? looke, there's a fellow ga∣thers vp to him, marke.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Good, 'i faith ô he has lighted on the wrōg pocket. WINW. He has it, 'fore God hee is a braue fellow; pitty hee should be detected.

SP.SPEAKER: ALL
SP.P: An excellent ballad! an excellent ballad!

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Friend, let mee ha' the first, let mee ha' the first, I pray you.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Pardon mee, Sir. First come, first seru'd; and I'le buy the whole bundle too.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: That conueyance was better then all, did you see't? he has giuen the purse to the ballad-singer.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Has hee?

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Sir, I cry you mercy; I'le not hinder the poore mans profit: pray you mistake me not.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Sir, I take you for an honest Gentleman; if that be mis∣taking, I met you to day afore: ha! humh! O God! my purse is gone, my purse, my purse, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Come, doe not make a stirre, and cry your selfe an Asse, thorow the Fayre afore your time.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Why, hast thou it, Numpes? good Numpes, how came you by it? I mar'le!

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I pray you seeke some other gamster, to play the foole with: you may lose it time enough, for all your Fayre-wit.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: By this good hand, gloue and all, I ha' lost it already, if thou hast it not: feele else, and Mistris Grace's handkercher, too, out o'the tother pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why, 'tis well; very well, exceeding pretty, and well.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Are you sure you ha' lost it, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: O God! yes; as I am an honest man, I had it but e'en now, at youth, youth.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: I hope you suspect not me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Thee? that were a iest indeede! Dost thou thinke the Gentleman is foolish? where hadst thou hands, I pray thee? Away Asse, away.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: I shall be beaten againe, if I be spi'd.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Sir, I suspect an odde fellow, yonder, is stealing away.

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: Brother, it is the preaching fellow! you shall suspect him. He was at your tother purse, you know! Nay, stay, Sir, and view the worke you ha'done, an'you be benefie'd at the Gallowes, and preach there, thanke your owne handy-worke.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Sir, you shall take no pride in your preferment: you shall be silenc'd quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: What doe you meane? sweet buds of gentility.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: To ha' my peneworths out on you: Bud. No lesse then two purses a day, serue you? I thought you a simple fellow, when my man Numpes beate you, i'the morning, and pittied you—

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: So did I, I'll besworne, brother; but now I see hee is a lewd, and pernicious Enormity: (as Master Ouerdoo calls him.)

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Mine owne words turn'd vpon mee, like swords.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Cannot a man's purse be at quiet for you, i'the Masters pocket, but you must intice it forth, and debauch it?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Sir, Sir, keepe your debauch, and your fine Bartholmew-termes to your selfe; and make as much on'hem as you please. But gi'me this from you, i'the meane time: I beseech you, see if I can looke to this.Wasp takes the Licence from him.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Why, Numps?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why? because you are an Asse, Sir, there's a reason the shortest way, and you will needs ha' it; now you ha'got the tricke of losing, you'ld lose your breech, an't 'twere loose. I know you, Sir, come, deliuer, you'll goe and cracke the vermine, you breed now, will you? 'tis very fine, will you ha' the truth on't? they are such retchlesse flies as you are, that blow cutpurses a∣broad in euery corner; your foolish hauing of money, makes 'hem. An' there were no wiser then I, Sir, the trade should lye open for you, Sir, it should i'faith, Sir. I would teach your wit to come to your head, Sir, as well as your land to come into your hand, I as∣sure you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: Alacke, good Numps.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Nay, Gentlemen, neuer pitty mee, I am not worth it: Lord send me at home once, to Harrow o'the Hill againe, if I tra∣uell any more, call me Coriat; withall my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Stay, Sir, I must haue a word with you in priuate. Doe you heare?

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: With me, Sir? what's your pleasure? good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Doe not deny it. You are a cutpurse, Sir, this Gentle∣man here, and I, saw you, nor doe we meane to detect you (though we can sufficiently informe our selues, toward the danger of con∣cealing you) but you must doe vs a piece of seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Good Gentlemen, doe not vndoe me; I am a ciuill young man, and but a beginner, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P:
Sir, your beginning shall bring on your ending, for vs.
We are no Catchpoles nor Constables. That you are to vndertake, is this; you saw the old fellow, with the blcke boxe, here?

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: The little old Gouernour, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: That same: I see, you haue flowne him to a marke al∣ready. I would ha'you get away that boxe from him, and bring it vs.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Would you ha' the boxe and all, Sir? or onely that, that is in't? I'le get you that, and leaue him the boxe, to play with still: (which will be the harder o'the two) because I would gaine your worships good opinion of me.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: He sayes well, 'tis the greater Mastry, and 'twill make the more sport when 'tis mist.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: I, and 'twill be the longer a missing, to draw on the sport.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: But looke you doe it now, sirrah, and keepe your word: or—

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Sir, if euer I breake my word, with a Gentleman, may I neuer read word at my need. Where shall I find you?

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Some-where i'the Fayre, heereabouts. Dispatch it quickly. I would faine see the carefull foole deluded! of all Beasts, I loue the serious Asse. He that takes paines to be one, and playes the foole, with the greatest diligence that can be.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Then you would not chose, Sir, but loue my Guardian, Iustice Ouerdo, who is answerable to that description, in euery haire of him.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: So I haue heard. But how came you, Mistis Welborne, to be his Ward? or haue relation to him, at first?

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Faith, through a common calamity, he bought me, Sir; and now he will marry me to his wiues brother, this wise Gentle∣man, that you see, or else I must pay value o'my land

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: S'lid, is there no deuice of disparagement? or so? talke with some crafty fellow, some picklocke o'the Law! Would I had studied a yeere longer i'the Innes of Court, and't had beene but i'your case.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: I Master Quarlous, are you proffering?

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: You'ld bring but little ayde, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: (I'le looke to you 'ifaith, Gamster.) An vnfortunate foolish Tribe you are falne into, Lady, I wonder you can en∣dure 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Sir, they that cannot worke their fetters off; must weare 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: WINW.
SP.P: You see what care they haue on you, to leaue you thus.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Faith the same they haue of themselues, Sir. I cannot greatly complaine, if this were all the plea I had against 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P:
'Tis true! but will you please to withdraw with vs, a little, and make them thinke, they haue lost you. I hope our man∣ners ha' beene such hitherto, and our language, as will giue
you no cause, to doubt your selfe, in our company.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Sir, I will giue my selfe, no cause; I am so secure of mine owne manners, as I suspect not yours.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Looke where Iohn Little-wit comes.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Away, I'le not be seene, by him.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: No, you were not best, hee'ld tell his mother, the widdow.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN W.
SP.P: Heatt, what doe you meane?

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Cry you mercy, is the winde there? must not the wid∣dow be nam'd?

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. III SCENE. VI.
DIV2.STAGE: IOHN. WIN. TRASH. LEATHERHEAD. KNOCKHVM. BVSY. PVRE CRAFT.

SP.P: DOe you heare Win, Win?

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: What say you, Iohn?

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: While they are paying the reckoning, Win, I'll tell you a thing Win, wee shall neuer see any sights i'the Fayre, Win, except you long still, Win, good Win, sweet Win, long to see some Hob∣by-horses, and some Drummes, and Rattles, and Dogs, and fine deuices, Win. The Bull with the fiue legs, Win; and the great Hog: now you ha' begun with Pigge, you may long for any thing, Win, and so for my Motion, Win.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: But we sha'not eat o'the Bull, and the Hogge, Iohn, how shall I long then?

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: O yes! Win: you may long to see, as well as to taste, Win: how did the Pothecarie's wife, Win, that long'd to see the Anatomy, Win? or the Lady, Win, that desir'd to spit i'the great Lawyers mouth, after an eloquent pleading? I assure you they long'd, VVin, good Win, goe in, and long.

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: I think we are rid of our new customer, brother Leather-head, wee shall heare no more of him.They plot to be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: All the better, let's packe vp all, and be gone, before he finde vs

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Stay a little, yonder comes a company: it may be wee may take some more money.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO,
SP.P: Sir, I will take your counsell, and cut my haire, and leaue vapours: I see, that Tabacco, and Bottle-Ale, and Pig, and Whit, and very Vrsla, her selfe, is all vanity.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P:
Onely Pigge was not comprehended in my admonition,
the rest were. For long haire, it is an Ensigne of pride, a banner, and the world is full of those banners, very full of Banners. And, bottle-ale is a drinke of Sathan's, a diet-drinke of Sathans, deui∣sed to puffe vs vp, and make vs swell in this latter age of vanity, as the smoake of tabacco, to keepe vs in mist and error: But the fleshly woman, (which you call Vrsla) is aboue all to be auoyded, hauing the marks vpon her, of the three enemies of Man, the World, as being in the Faire; the Deuill, as being in the fire; and and the Flesh, as being her selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: Brother Zeale-of-the land! what shall we doe? my daugh∣ter Win-the-fight, is falne into her fit of longing againe.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: For more pig? there is no more, is there?

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: To see some sights, i' the Faire.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Sister, let her fly the impurity of the place, swiftly, lest shee partake of the pitch thereof. Thou art the seate of the Beast, O Smithfield, and I will leaue thee. Idolatry peepeth out on euery side of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: An excellent right Hypocrite! now his belly is full, he falls a railing and kicking, the Iade. A very good vapour! I'll in, and ioy Vrsla, with telling, how her pigge works, two and a halfe he eate to his share. And he has drunke a pailefull. He eates with his eyes, as well as his teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: What doe you lack, Gentlemen? What is't you buy? Rattles, Drumms, Babies.—

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Peace, with thy Apocryphall wares, thou prophane Pub∣lican: thy Bells, thy Dragons, and thy Tobie's Dogges. Thy Hobby-horse is an Idoll, a very Idoll, a feirce and rancke Idoll: And thou, the Nabuchadnezzar, the proud Nabuchadnezzar of the Faire, that set'st it vp, for children to fall downe to, and worship.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Cry you mercy, Sir, will you buy a fiddle to fill vp your noise.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Looke Win. doe, looke a Gods name, and saue your longing. Here be fine sights.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: I child, so you hate 'hem, as our Brother Zeale do's, you may looke on 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Or what do you say, to a Drumme. Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: It is the broken belly of the Beast, and thy Bellowes there are his lungs, and these Pipes are his throate, those Feathers are of his taile, and thy Rattles, the gnashing of his teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: And what's my ginger-bread? I pray you.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: The prouander that pricks him vp. Hence with thy bas∣ket of Popery, thy nest of Images: and whole legend of ginger-worke.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Sir if you be not quiet, the quicklier, I'll ha'you clapp'd fairely by the heeles, for disturbing the Faire.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: The sinne of the Faire prouokes me, I cannot bee silent.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: Good brother Zeale!

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Sir, I'll make you silent, beleeue it.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Il'd giue a shilling, you could i'faith, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Sir, giue me your shilling, I'll giue you my shop, if I do not, and I'll leaue it in pawne with you, i'the meane time.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: A match i'faith, but do it quickly, then.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Hinder me not, woman. I was mou'd in spirit,He speakes to the wid∣dow. to bee here, this day, in this Faire, this wicked, and foule Faire; and fit∣ter may it be a called a foule, then a Faire: To protest against the abuses of it, the foule abuses of it, in regard of the afflicted Saints, that are troubled, very much troubled, exceedingly troubled, with the opening of the merchandize of Babylon againe, & the peeping of Popery vpon the stals, here, here, in the high places. See you not Goldylocks, the purple strumpet, there? in her yellow gowne, and greene sleeues? the prophane pipes, the tinckling timbrells? A shop of reliques!

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Pray you forbeare, I am put in trust with 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: And this Idolatrous Groue of Images, this flasket of Idols!Ouerthrows the ginger-bread. which I will pull downe—
(TRA. O my ware, my ware, God blesse it.)

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: In my zeale, and glory to be thus exercis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Here he is, pray you lay hold on his zeale, wee cannot sell a whistle, for him, in tune. Stop his noyse, first!

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Thou canst not: 'tis a sanctified noise.Leather-head enters with officers I will make a loud and most strong noise, till I haue daunted the prophane ene∣my. And for this cause.—

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Sir, heer's no man afraid of you, or your cause. You shall sweare it, i'the stocks, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: I will thrust my selfe into the stocks, vpon the pikes of the Land.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Carry him away.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: What doe you meane, wicked men?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Let them alone; I feare them not.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Was not this shilling well ventur'd, Win? for our liber∣ty? Now we may goe play, and see ouer the Fayre, where we list our selues; my mother is gone after him, and let her ee'n go, and loose vs.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: Yes Iohn, but I know not what to doe.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: For what, Win?

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: For a thing, I am asham'd to tell you, i'faith, and 'tis too farre to go home.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: I pray thee bee not asham'd, VVin. Come, i'faith thou shall not be asham'd, is it any thing about the Hobby-horse-man? an't be, speake freely.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: Hang him, base Bobchin, I scorne him; no, I haue very great, what sha' call'um, Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P:
ô! Is that all, Win? wee'll goe backe to Captaine Ior∣dan; to the pig-womans, Win. hee'll helpe vs, or she with a
dripping pan, or an old kettle, or something. The poore greasie soule loues you, Win, and after we'll visit the Fayre all ouer, Win, and, see my Puppet play, Win, you know it's a fine matter, Win.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Let's away, I counsell'd you to packe vp afore, Ione.

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: A poxe of his Bedlem purity. Hee has spoyl'd halfe my ware: but the best is, wee lose nothing, if wee misse our first Merchant.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: It shall be hard for him to finde, or know vs, when we are translated, Ione.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. IIII. SCENE. I.
DIV2.STAGE: TROVBLE-ALL. BRISTLE. HAGGISE, COKES. IVSTICE. POCHER, BVSY. PVRECRAFT.

SP.P: MY Masters, I doe make no doubt, but you are officers.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: What then, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: And the Kings louing, and o∣bedient subiects.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Obedient, friend? take heede what you speake, I aduise you: Oliuer Bristle aduises you. His louing subiects, we grant you: but not his obedient, at this time, by your leaue, wee know our selues, a little better then so, wee are to command, Sr. and such as you are to be obedient. Here's one of his obedient subiects, going to the stocks, and wee'll make you such another, if you talke.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: You are all wise enough i'your places, I know.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: If you know it, Sir, why doe you bring it in question?

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: I question nothing, pardon me. I do only hope you haue warrant, for what you doe, and so, quit you, and so, multiply you.

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: He goes a∣way againe.What's hee? bring him vp to the stocks there. Why bring you him not vp?

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: If you haue Iustice Ouerdoo's warrant, 'tis well:comes again. you are safe; that is the warrant of warrants. I'le not giue this button, for any mans warrant else.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Like enough, Sir, but let me tell you, an' you play away your buttons, thus, you will want 'hem ere night,goes away. for any store I see about you: you might keepe 'hem, and saue pinnes, I wusse.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: What should hee be, that doth so esteeme, and aduance my warrant? he seemes a sober and discreet person! it is a com∣fort to a good conscience, to be follow'd with a good fame, in his sufferings. The world will haue a pretty tast by this, how I can beare aduersity: and it will beget a kind of reuerence, toward me, hereafter, euen from mine enemies, when they shall see I carry my calamity nobly, and that it doth neither breake mee, nor bend mee.

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: Come, Sir, heere's a place for you to preach in.They put him in the stocks. Will you put in your legge?

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: That I will, cheerefully.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: O'my conscience a Seminary! hee kisses the stockes.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Well my Masters, I'le leaue him with you; now I see him bestow'd, I'le goe looke for my goods, and Numps.

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: You may, Sir, I warrant you; where's the tother Baw∣ler? fetch him too, you shall find 'hem both fast enough.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: In the mid'st of this tumult, I will yet be the Author of mine owne rest, and not minding their fury, sit in the stockes, in that calme, as shall be able to trouble a Triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Doe you assure me vpon your words?comes again, may I vndertake for you, if I be ask'd the question; that you haue this warrant?

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: What's this fellow, for Gods sake?

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Doe but shew me Adam Ouerdoo, and I am satisfied▪goes out.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Hee is a fellow that is distracted, they say; one Trouble-all▪ hee was an officer in the Court of Pie-poulders, here last yeere, and put out on his place by Iustice Ouerdoo.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Vpon which, he tooke an idle conceipt, and's runne mad vpon't. So that euer since, hee will doe nothing, but by Iustice Ouerdoo's warrant, he will not eate a crust, nor drinke a little, nor make him in his apparell, ready. His wife, Sirreuerence, cannot get him make his water, or shift his shirt, without his warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: If this be true, this is my greatest disaster! how am I bound to satisfie this poore man, that is of so good a nature to mee, out of his wits! where there is no roome left for dissembling.comes in.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: If you cannot shew me Adam Ouerdoo, I am in doubt of you: I am afraid you cannot answere it.

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: Before me,goes againe. Neighbour Bristle (and now I thinke on't bet∣ter) Iustice Ouerdoo, is a very parantory person.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: O! are you aduis'd of that? and a seuere Iusticer, by your leaue.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Doe I heare ill o'that side, too?

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: He will sit as vpright o'the bench, an' you marke him, as a candle i'the socket, and giue light to the whole Court in euery businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: But he will burne blew, and swell like a bile (God blesse vs) an' he be angry.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI..
SP.P: I, and hee will be angry too, when his list, that's more: and when hee is angry, be it right or wrong; hee has the Law on's side, euer. I marke that too.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: I will be more tender hereafter. I see compassion may become a Iustice, though it be a weaknesse, I confesse; and neerer a vice, then a vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: They take the Iustice out.Well, take him out o' the stocks againe, wee'll goe a sure way to worke, wee'll ha' the Ace of hearts of our side, if we can.

SP.SPEAKER: POC.
SP.P: Come, bring him away to his fellow, there. Master Busy, we shall rule your legges, I hope, though wee cannot rule your tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: No, Minister of darkenesse, no, thou canst not rule my tongue, my tongue it is mine own; and with it I will both knke and mocke downe your Bartholmew abhominatns, till you made a hissing to the neighbour Parishes, round about.

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: Let him alone, we haue deuis'd better vpon't.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: And shall he not into the stocks then?

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: No, Mistresse, wee'll haue 'hem both to Iustice Ouerdoo, and let him doe ouer 'hem as is fitting. Then I, and my gossip Haggis, and my beadle Pocher are discharg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: O, I thanke you, blessed, honest men!

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Nay, neuer thank vs, but thank this mad-man that comes heere, hee put it in our heads.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: Is hee mad? Now heauen increase his madnesse, and blesse it,Comes a∣gaine. and thanke it, Sir, your poore hand-maide thanks you.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Haue you a warrant? an' you haue a warrant, shew it.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: Yes, I haue a warrant out of the word, to giue thankes for remouing any scorne intended to the brethren.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: It is Iustice Ouerdoo's warrant, that I looke for, if you haue not that, keepe your word, I'le keepe mine. Quit yee, and multiply yee.
COme away Nightingale, I pray thee.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Whither goe you? where's your warrant?

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Warrant, for what, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: For what you goe about, you know how fit it is, an' you haue no warrant, blesse you, I'le pray for you,Goes out. that's all I can doe.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: What meanes hee?

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: A mad-man that haunts the Fayre, doe you not know him? it's maruell hee has not more followers, after his ragged heeles.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Beshrew him, he startled me: I thought he had knowne of our plot. Guilt's a terrible thing! ha' you prepar'd the Costard∣monger?

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: Yes, and agreed for his basket of peares; hee is at the corner here, ready. And your Prise, he comes downe, sailing, that way, all alone; without his Protector: hee is rid of him, it seemes.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: I, I know; I should ha' follow'd his Protector-ship for a feat I am to doe vpon him: But this offer'd it selfe, so i'the way, I could not let it scape: heere he comes, whistle,Nightin∣gale whistles be this sport call'd Dorring the Dottrell.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: Wh, wh, wh, wh, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: By this light, I cannot finde my ginger-bread-Wife, nor my Hobby-horse-man in all the Fayre, now; to ha' my money a∣gaine. And I do not know the way out on't, to go home for more, doe you heare, friend, you that whistle; what tune is that, you whistle?

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: A new tune, I am practising, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Dost thou know where I dwell, I pray thee? nay, on with thy tune, I ha' no such hast, for an answer: I'le practise with thee.Nightin∣gale sets his foote afore him, and he falls with his basket.

SP.SPEAKER: COS.
SP.P: Buy any peares, very fine peares, peares fine.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Gods so! a musse, a musse, a musse, a musse.

SP.SPEAKER: COS.
SP.P: Good Gentleman, my ware, my ware, I am a poore man. Good Sir, my ware.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: Cokes falls a scrambling whilest they runne away with his things.Let me hold your sword, Sir, it troubles you.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Doe, and my cloake, an'thou wilt; and my hat, too.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: A delicate great boy! me thinks, he out-scrambles 'hem all. I cannot perswade my selfe, but he goes to grammer-schole yet; and playes the trewant, to day.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: Would he had another purse to cut, Zekiel.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Purse? a man might cut out his kidneys, I thinke; and he neuer feele 'hem, he is so earnest at the sport.

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: His soule is halfe way out on's body, at the game.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Away, Nightingale: that way.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I thinke I am furnish'd for Catherne peares, for one vn∣der-meale: gi'me my cloake.

SP.SPEAKER: COS.
SP.P: Good Gentleman, giue me my ware.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Where's the fellow, I ga' my cloake to? my cloake? and my hat?He runs out. ha! Gods'lid, is he gone? thieues, thieues, helpe me to cry, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Away, Costermonger, come to vs to Vrsla's. Talke of him to haue a soule? 'heart, if hee haue any more then a thing giuen him in stead of salt, onely to keepe him from stinking, I'le be hang'd afore my time, presently, where should it be trow? in his blood; hee has not so much to'ard it in his whole body, as will maintaine a good Flea; And if hee take this course, he will not ha' so much land left, as to reare a Calfe within this twelue month. Was there euer greene Plouer so pull'd! That his little Ouerseer had beene heere now, and beene but tall enough, to see him steale peares, in exchange, for his beauer-hat, and his cloake thus? I must goe finde him out, next, for his blacke boxe, and his Patent (it seemes) hee has of his place; which I thinke the Gentleman would haue a reuersion of; that spoke to me for it so earnestly.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: He comes a∣gaine.Would I might lose my doublet, and hose, too; as I am an honest man, and neuer stirre, if I thinke there be any thing, but thieuing, and cooz'ning, i'this whole Fayre▪ Bartholmew-fayre, quoth he; an' euer any Bartholmew had that lucke in't, that I haue had, I'le be martyr'd for him,throws away his peares. and in Smithfield, too. I ha' paid for my peares, a rot on 'hem, I'le keepe 'hem no longer; you were choake-peares to mee; I had bin better ha'gone to mum chance for you, I wusse. Me thinks the Fayre should not haue vs'd me thus, and 'twere but for my names sake, I would not ha' vs'd a dog o'the name, so. O, Numps will triumph, now! Friend, doe you know who I am? or where I lye? I doe not my selfe, I'll besworne. Doe but carry me home, and I'le please thee, I ha' money enough there, I ha' lost my selfe, and my cloake and my hat; and my fine sword, and my sister, and Numps, and Mistris Grace, (a Gentlewoman that I should ha' marryed) and a cut-worke handkercher, shee ga' mee, and two purses to day. And my bargaine o'Hobby-horses and Ginger-bread, which grieues me worst of all.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Trouble-all comes again.By whose warrant, Sir, haue you done all this?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Warrant? thou art a wise fellow, indeed, as if a man need a warrant to lose any thing, with.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Yes, Iustice Ouerdo's warrant, a man may get, and lose with, I'le stand to't.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Iustice Ouerdoo? Dost thou know him? I lye there, hee is my brother in Law, hee marryed my sister: pray thee shew me the way, dost thou know the house?

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Sir, shew mee your warrant, I know nothing without a warrant, pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Why, I warrant thee, come along: thou shalt see, I haue wrought pillowes there, and cambricke sheetes, and sweete bags, too. Pray thee guide me to the house.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Sir, I'le tell you; goe you thither your selfe, first, alone; tell your worshipfull brother your minde: and but bring me three lines of his hand, or his Clerkes, with Adam Ouerdoo, vnderneath; here I'le stay you, Ile obey you, and I'le guide you presently.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: S'lid, this is an Asse, I ha' found him, poxe vpon mee, what doe I talking to such a dull foole; farewell, you are a very Coxcomb, doe you heare?

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: I thinke, I am, if Iustice Ouerdoo signe to it, I am, and so wee are all, hee'll quit vs all, multiply vs all.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. IIII.
SCENE. IIJ.
DIV2.STAGE: GRACE. QVARLOVS. WIN-WIFE.They enter with their swords drawne. TROVBLE-ALL. EDGVVORTH.
DIV2.P: GEntlemen, this is no way that you take: you do but breed one another trouble, and offence, and giue me no contentment at all. I am no she, that affects to be quarell'd for, or haue my name or fortune made the question of mens swords.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: S'lood, wee loue you.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: If you both loue mee, as you pretend, your owne reason will tell you, but one can enioy me; and to that point, there leads a directer line, then by my infamy, which must follow, if you fight. 'Tis true, I haue profest it to you ingenuously, that rather then to be yoak'd with this Bridegroome is appointed me, I would take vp any husband, almost vpon any trust. Though Subtilty would say to me, (I know) hee is a foole, and has an estate, and I might go∣uerne him, and enioy a friend, beside. But these are not my aymes, I must haue a husband I must loue, or I cannot liue with him. I shall ill make one of these politique wiues!

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Why, if you can like either of vs, Lady, say, which is he, and the other shall sweare instantly to desist.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Content, I accord to that willingly.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Sure you thinke me a woman of an extreme leuity, Gen∣tlemen, or a strange fancy, that (meeting you by chance in such a place, as this, both at one instant, and not yet of two hours acquain∣tance, neither of you deseruing afore the other, of me) I should so forsake my modesty (though I might affect one more particularly) as to say, This is he, and name him.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Why, wherefore should you not? What should hinder you?

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: If you would not giue it to my modesty, allow it yet to my wit; giue me so much of woman, and cunning, as not to betray my selfe impertinently. How can I iudge of you, so farre as to a choyse, without knowing you more? you are both equall, and alike to mee, yet: and so indifferently affected by mee, as each of you might be the man, if the other were away. For you are rea∣sonable creatures, you haue vnderstanding, and discourse. And if fate send me an vnderstanding husband, I haue no feare at all, but mine owne manners shall make him a good one.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Would I were put forth to making for you, then.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: It may be you are, you know not what's toward you: will you consent to a motion of mine, Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: WINW.
SP.P: What euer it be, we'll presume reasonablenesse, com∣ming from you.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: And fitnesse, too.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: I saw one of you buy a paire of tables, e'en now.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Yes, heere they be, and maiden ones too, vnwritten in.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: The fitter for what they may be imployed in. You shall write either of you, heere, a word, or a name, what you like best; but of two, or three syllables at most: and the next person that comes this way (because Destiny has a high hand in businesse of this nature) I'le demand, which of the two words, he, or she doth approue; and according to that sentence, fixe my resolution, and affection, without change.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Agreed, my word is conceiued already.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: And mine shall not be long creating after.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: But you shall promise, Gentlemen, not to be curious to know, which of you it is, taken; but giue me leaue to conceale that till you haue brought me, either home, or where I may safely tender my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W
SP.P: Why that's but equall.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Wee are pleas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Because I will bind both your indeauours to work toge∣ther, friendly, and ioyntly, each to the others fortune, and haue my selfe fitted with some meanes, to make him that is forsaken, a part of amends.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: These conditions are very curteous. Well my word is out of the Arcadia, then: Argalus.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: And mine out of the play, Palemon.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Haue you any warrant for this, Gentlemen?Trouble-all comes again.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR. WIN-W.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: There must be a warrant had, beleeue it.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: For what?

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Fot whatsoeuer it is, any thing indeede, no matter what.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: S'light, here's a fine ragged Prophet, dropt downe 'ithe nicke!

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Heauen quit you, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Nay, stay a little, good Lady, put him to the question.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: You are content, then?

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W. QVAR.
SP.P: Yes yes.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Sir, heere are two names written—

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Is Iudice Ouerdoo, one?

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: How, Sir? I pray you read 'hem to your selfe, it is for a wager betweene these Gentlemen, and with a stroake or any dif∣ference, marke which you approue best.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: They may be both worshipfull names for ought I know, Mistresse, but Adam Ouerdoo had beene worth three of 'hem, I as∣sure you, in this place, that's in plaine english.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: This man amazes mee! I pray you, like one of 'hem, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: I doe like him there, that has the best warrant, Mistresse, to saue your longing, and (multiply him) It may be this. But I am I still for Iustice Ouerdoo, that's my conscience. And quit you.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Is't done, Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: I, and strangely, as euer I saw! What fellow is this trow?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: No matter what, a Fortune-teller wee ha' made him. Which is't, which is't.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Nay, did you not promise, not to enquire?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: S'lid, I forgot that, pray you pardon mee. Looke, here's our Mercury come: The Licence arriues i'the finest time, too! 'tis but scraping out Cokes his name, and 'tis done.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: How now lime-twig? hast thou touch'd.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P:
Not yet, Sir, except you would goe with mee, and see't, it's not worth speaking on. The act is nothing, without a witnesse. Yonder he is, your man with the boxe falne into the fi∣nest company, and so transported with vapours, they ha' got in a Northren Clothier, and one Puppy, a Westerne man, that's come to wrastle before my Lord Maior, anone, and Captaine Whit, and one Val Cutting, that helpes Captaine Iordan to roare, a circling boy: with whom your Numps, is so taken, that you may strip him of his cloathes, if you will. I'le vndertake to geld him for you; if you had but a Surgeon, ready, to feare him. And Mistresse Iustice,
there, is the goodest woman! shee do's so loue 'hem all ouer, in termes of Iustice, and the Stile of authority, with her hood vp∣right—that I beseech you come away Gentlemen, and see't.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: S'light, I would not lose it for the Fayre, what'll you doe, Ned?

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Why, stay heere about for you, Mistresse Welborne must not be seene.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Doe so, and find out a Priest i'the meane time, I'le bring the License. Lead, which way is't?

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Here, Sir, you are o'the backeside o'the Booth already, you may heare the noise.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. IIIJ. SCENE. IV.
DIV2.STAGE: KNOCKHVM. NORDERN. PVPPY. CVT∣TING. WHIT. EDGVVORTH. QVARLOVS. OVERDOO. WASPE. BRISTLE.

SP.P: WHit, bid Vall Cutting continue the vapours for a lift, Whit, for a lift.

SP.SPEAKER: NOR.
SP.P: Il'e ne mare, Il'e ne mare, the eale's too meeghty.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: How now! my Galloway Nag, the staggers? ha! Whit, gi'him a slit i'the fore-head. Cheare vp, man, a needle, and threed to stitch his eares. I'ld cure him now an'I had it, with a little butter, and garlike, long-pepper, and graines. Where's my horne? I'le gi'him a mash, presently, shall take away this dizzinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP.
SP.P: Why, where are you zurs? doe you vlinch, and leaue vs i'the zuds, now?

SP.SPEAKER: NOR.
SP.P: I'le ne mare, I'is e'en as vull as a Paipers bag, by my troth, I.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP.
SP.P: Doe my Northerne cloth zhrinke i'the wetting? ha?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Why, well said, old Flea-bitten, thou'lt neuer tyre, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: They fall to their va∣pours, a∣gaine.No, Sir, but he may tire, if it please him.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Who told dee sho? that he vuld neuer teer, man?

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: No matter who told him so, so long as he knowes.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Nay, I know nothing, Sir, pardon me there.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: They are at it stil, Sir, this they call vapours.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: He shall not pardon dee, Captaine, dou shalt not be par∣don'd. Pre'de shweete heart doe not pardon him.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: S'light, I'le pardon him, an'I list, whosoeuer saies nay to't.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Where's Numps? I misse him.Here they continue their game of vapours, which is non sense. Eue∣ry man to op∣pose the last man that spake: whe∣the it con∣cern'd him, or no.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why, I say nay to't.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: O there he is!

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: To what doe you say nay, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: To any thing, whatsoeuer it is, so long as I do not like it.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Pardon me, little man, dou musht like it a little.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: No, hee must not like it at all, Sir, there you are i'the wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: I tinke I be, he musht not like it, indeede.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: Nay, then he both must, and will like it, Sir, for all you.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: If he haue reason, he may like it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: By no meansh Captaine, vpon reason, he may like no∣thing vpon reason.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I haue no reason, nor I will heare of no reason, nor I will looke for no reason, and he is an Asse, that either knowes any, or lookes for't from me.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: Yes, in some sense you may haue reason, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I, in some sense, I care not if I grant you.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Pardon mee, thou ougsht to grant him nothing, in no shesh, if dou doe loue dy shelfe, angry man.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why then, I doe grant him nothing; and I haue no sense.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: 'Tis true, thou hast no sense indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: S'lid, but I haue sense, now I thinke on't better, and I will grant him any thing, doe you see?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: He is i'the right, and do's vtter a sufficient vapour.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: Nay, it is no sufficient vapour, neither, I deny that.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Then it is a sweet vapour.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: It may be a sweet vapour.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Nay, it is no sweet vapour, neither, Sir, it stinkes, and I'le stand to't.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Yes, I tinke it dosh shtinke, Captaine. All vapour dosh shtinke.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Nay, then it do's not stinke, Sir, and it shall not stinke.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: By your leaue, it may, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I, by my leaue, it may stinke, I know that.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Pardon me, thou knowesht nothing, it cannot by thy leaue, angry man.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: How can it not?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Nay, neuer question him, for he is i'the right.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Yesh, I am i'de right, I confesh it, so ish de little man too.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I'le haue nothing confest, that concernes mee. I am not i'the right, nor neuer was i'the right, nor neuer will be i'the right, while I am in my right minde,

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: Minde? why, heere's no man mindes you, Sir,They drinke againe. nor any thing else.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP.
SP.P: Vreind, will you mind this that wee doe?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Call you this vapours? this is such beltching of quar∣rell, as I neuer heard. Will you minde your businesse, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: You shall see, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: NOR.
SP.P: I'le ne maire, my waimb warkes too mickle with this anready.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Will you take that, Master Waspe, that no body should minde you?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why? what ha' you to doe? is't any matter to you?

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: No, but me thinks you should not be vnminded, though,

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Nor, I wu'not be, now I thinke on't, doe you heare, new acquaintance, do's no man mind me, say you?

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, euery man heere mindes you, but how?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Nay, I care as little how, as you doe, that was not my question.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: No, noting was ty question, tou art a learned man, and I am a valiant man, i'faith la, tou shalt speake for mee, and I vill fight for tee.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Fight for him, Whit? A grosse vapour, hee can fight for himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: It may be I can, but it may be, I wu' not, how then?

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: Why, then you may chuse.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why, and I'le chuse whether I'le chuse or no.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: I thinke you may, and 'tis true; and I allow it for a re∣solute vapour.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Nay, then, I doe thinke you doe not thinke, and it is no resolute vapour.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: Yes, in some sort he may allow you.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: In no sort, Sir, pardon me, I can allow him nothing. You mistake the vapour.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: He mistakes nothing, Sir, in no sort.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Yes, I pre dee now, let him mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: A turd i'your teeth, neuer pre dee mee, for I will haue nothing mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: They fall by the cares.Turd, ha turd? a noysome vapour, strike Whit.

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: Why, Gentlemen, why Gentlemen, I charge you vpon my authority, conserue the peace. In the Kings name, and my Husbands, put vp your weapons, I shall be driuen to commit you my selfe, else.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Why doe you laugh, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Sir, you'll allow mee my christian liberty. I may laugh, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: In some sort you may, and in some sort you may not, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Nay in some sort, Sir, hee may neither laugh, nor hope, in this company.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Yes, then he may both laugh, and hope in any sort, an't please him.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Faith, and I will then, for it doth please mee excee∣dingly.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: No exceeding neither, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: No, that vapour is too lofty.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Gentlemen, I doe not play well at your game of vapours, I am not very good at it, but—

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: Doe you heare, Sir? I would speake with you in circle?Hee drawes a circle on the ground.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: In circle, Sir? what would you with me in circle?

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: Can you lend me a Piece, a Iacobus? in circle?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: S'lid, your circle will proue more costly then your va∣pours, then. Sir, no, I lend you none.

SP.SPEAKER: CVT.
SP.P: Your beard's not well turn'd vp, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
