SP.P: How Rascall? are you playing with my beard?They draw all, and fight. I'le breake circle with you.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. NOR.
SP.P: Gentlemen, Gentlemen!

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Gather vp, Whit, gather vp, Whit, good vapours.

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: What meane you? are you Rebells? Gentlemen? shall I send out a Sericant at Armes, or a Writ o'Rebellion, against you? I'le commit you vpon my woman-hood, for a Riot, vpon my Iu∣stice-hood, if you persist.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Vpon your Iustice-hood? Mary shite o'your hood, you'll commit? Spoke like a true Iustice of peace's wife, indeed, and a fine female Lawyer! turd i'your teeth for a fee, now.

SP.SPEAKER: OVER.
SP.P: Why, Numps, in Master Ouerdoo's name, I charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Good Mistresse Vnderdoo hold your tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: OVER.
SP.P: Alas! poore Numps.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Alas! and why alas from you, I beseech you? or why poore Numps, goody Rich? am I come to be pittied by your tuft taffata now? why Mistresse, I knew Adam, the Clerke, your hus∣band, when he was Adam Scriuener, and writ for two pence a sheet, as high as he beares his head now, or you your hood, Dame. What are you, Sir?The watch comes in.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Wee be men, and no Infidells; what is the matter, here, and the noyses? can you tell?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Heart, what ha' you to doe? cannot a man quarrell in quietnesse? but hee must be put out on't by you? what are you?

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Why, wee be his Maiesties Watch, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Watch? S'blood, you are a sweet watch, indeede. A body would thinke, and you watch'd well a nights, you should be contented to sleepe at this time a day. Get you to your fleas, and your flocke-beds, you Rogues, your kennells, and lye downe close.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Downe? yes, we will downe, I warrant you, downe with him in his Maiesties name, downe, downe with him, and carry him away, to the pigeon-holes.

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: I thanke you honest friends, in the behalfe o'the Crowne, and the peace, and in Master Ouerdoo's name, for suppressing enor∣mities.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Stay, Bristle, heere ish a noder brash o'drunkards, but very quiet, speciall drunkards, will pay dee, fiue shillings very well. Take 'hem to dee, in de graish o' God: one of hem do's change cloth, for Ale in the Fayre, here, te toder ish a strong man, a mighty man, my Lord Mayors man, and a wrastler. Hee has wrashled so long with the bottle, heere, that the man with the beard, hash almosht streeke vp hish heelsh.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: S'lid, the Clerke o'the Market, has beene to cry him all the Fayre ouer, here, for my Lords seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Tere he ish, pre de taik him hensh, and make ty best on him. How now woman o' shilke, vat ailsh ty shweet faish? art tou melancholy?

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: A little distemper'd with these enormities; shall I in∣treat a curtesie of you, Captaine?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Intreat a hundred, veluet voman, I vill doe it, shpeake out.

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: I cannot with modesty speake it out, but—

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: I vill doe it, and more, and more, for dee. What Vrsla, and't be bitch, and't be baud and't be!

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: How now Rascall? what roare you for? old Pimpe.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Heere, put vp de cloakes Vrsh; de purchase, pre dee now, shweet Vrsh, help dis good braue voman, to a Iordan, and't be.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: S'lid call your Captaine Iordan to her, can you not?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Nay, pre dee leaue dy consheits, and bring the veluet woman to de—

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: I bring her, hang her: heart must I find a common pot for euery punque i'your purlews?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: O good voordsh, Vrsh, it ish a guest o'veluet, i'fait la.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: Let her sell her hood, and buy a spunge, with a poxe to her, my vessell, employed Sir. I haue but one, and 'tis the bottome of an old bottle. An honest Proctor, and his wife, are at it, with∣in, if shee'll stay her time, so.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: As soone ash tou cansht shwet Vrsh. Of a valiant man I tinke I am the patientsh man i'the world, or in all Smithfield.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: How now Whit? close vapours, stealing your leaps? couering in corners, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: No fait, Captaine, dough tou beesht a vishe man, dy vit is a mile hence, now. I vas procuring a shmall courtesie, for a woman of fashion here.

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: Yes, Captaine, though I am Iustice of peace's wife, I doe loue Men of warre, and the Sonnes of the sword, when they come before my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Say'st thou so Filly? thou shalt haue a leape presently, I'le horse thee my selfe, else.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: Come, will you bring her in now? and let her talke her turne?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Gramercy good Vrsh, I tanke dee.

SP.SPEAKER: OVER.
SP.P: Master Ouerdoo shall thanke her.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. IIII. SCENE. V.
DIV2.STAGE: IOHN. WIN. VRSLA. KNOCKHVM. WHIT. OVERDOO. ALES.

SP.P: Good Ga'mere Vrs; Win, and I, are exceedingly beholden to you, and to Captaine Iordan, and Captaine Whit. Win, I'le be bold to leaue you, i'this good company, Win: for halfe an houre, or so Win, while I goe, and see how my matter goes forward, and if the Puppets be perfect: and then I'le come & fetch you, Win.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: Will you leaue me alone with two men, Iohn?

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: I, they are honest Gentlmen Win, Captaine Iordan, and Captaine Whit, they'll vse you very ciuilly, Win, God b'w'you, Win.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: What's her husband gone?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: On his false, gallop, Vrs, away.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: An' you be right Bartholmew-birds, now shew your selues so: we are vndone for want of fowle i'the Fayre, here. Here will be Zekiell Edgworth, and three or foure gallants, with him at night, and I ha' neither Plouer nor Quaile for 'hem: perswade this be∣tweene you two, to become a Bird o'the game, while I worke the veluet woman, within, (as you call her.)

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: I conceiue thee, Vrs! goe thy waies, doest thou heare, Whit? is't not pitty, my delicate darke chestnut here; with the fine leane head, large fore-head, round eyes, euen mouth, sharpe eares, long necke, thinne crest, close withers, plaine backe, deepe sides, short fillets, and full flankes: with a round belly, a plumpe but tocke, large thighes, knit knees, streight legges, short pasternes, smooth hoofes, and short heeles; should lead a dull honest wo∣mans life, that might liue the life of a Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Yes, by my fait, and trot, it is, Captaine: de honesht wo∣mans life is a scuruy dull life, indeed, la.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: How, Sir? is an honest womans life a scuruy life?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Yes fait, shweet heart, beleeue him, de leefe of a Bond. woman! but if dou vilt harken to me, I vill make tee a free-wo∣man, and a Lady: dou shalt liue like a Lady, as te Captaine saish.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P:
I, and be honest too sometimes: haue her wiers, and
her tires, her greene gownes, and veluet petticoates.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: I, and ride to Ware and Rumford i'dy Coash, shee de Players, be in loue vit 'hem; sup vit gallantsh, be drunke, and cost de noting.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Braue vapours!

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: And lye by twenty on'hem, if dou pleash shweet heart.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: What, and be honest still, that were fine sport.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Tish common, shweet heart, tou may'st doe it by my hand: it shall be iustified to ty husbands faish, now: tou shalt be as honesht as the skinne betweene his hornsh, la!

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Yes, and weare a dressing, top, and top-gallant, to com∣pare with ere a husband on 'hem all, for a fore-top: it is the va∣pour of spirit in the wife, to cuckold, now adaies; as it is the va∣pour of fashion, in the husband, not to suspect. Your prying cat-eyed-citizen, is an abominable vapour.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: Lord, what a foole haue I beene!

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Mend then, and doe euery ting like a Lady, heereafter, neuer know ty husband, from another man.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Nor any one man from another, but i'the darke.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: I, and then it ish no dishgrash to know any man.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: Helpe, helpe here.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: How now? what vapour's there?

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: O, you are a sweet Ranger! and looke well to your walks. Yonder is your Punque of Turnbull, Ramping Ales, has falne v∣pon the poore Gentlewoman within, and pull'd her hood ouer her eares,Alice en∣ers, beating he Iustice's wife. and her hayre through it.

SP.SPEAKER: OVE.
SP.P: Helpe, helpe, i'the Kings name.

SP.SPEAKER: ALE.
SP.P: A mischiefe on you, they are such as you are, that vndoe vs, and take our trade from vs, with your tuft-taffata hanches.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: How now Alice!

SP.SPEAKER: ALE.
SP.P: The poore common whores can ha' no traffique, for the priuy rich ones; your caps and hoods of veluet, call away our cu∣stomers, and lick the fat from vs.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: Peace you foule ramping Iade, you—

SP.SPEAKER: ALE.
SP.P: Od's foote, you Bawd in greace, are you talking?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: VVhy, Alice, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: ALE.
SP.P: Thou Sow of Smithfield, thou.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: Thou tripe of Turnebull.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Cat-a-mountaine-vapours! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: You know where you were taw'd lately, both lash'd, and slash'd you were in Bridewell.

SP.SPEAKER: ALE.
SP.P: I, by the same token, you rid that weeke, and broake out the bottome o'the Cart, Night-tub.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: VVhy, Lyon face! ha! doe you know who I am? shall I teare ruffe, slit wastcoat, make ragges of petticoat? ha! goe to, vanish, for feare of vapours. Whit, a kick, Whit, in the parting va∣pour. Come braue woman, take a good heart, thou shalt be a La∣dy, too.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Yes fait, dey shal all both be Ladies, and write Madame. I vill do't my selfe for dem. Doe, is the vord, and D is the middle letter of Madame, D D, put 'hem together, and make deeds, with∣out which, all words are alike, la.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: 'Tis true, Vrsla, take 'hem in, open thy wardrope, and fit 'hem to their calling. Greene-gownes, Crimson-petticoats, green women! my Lord Maiors green women! guests o'the Game, true bred. I'le prouide you a Coach, to take the ayre, in.

SP.SPEAKER: VVIN.
SP.P: But doe you thinke you can get one?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: O, they are as common as wheelebarrowes, where there are great dunghills. Euery Pettifoggers wife, has 'hem, for first he buyes a Coach, that he may marry, and then hee marries that hee may be made Cuckold in't: For if their wiues ride not to their Cuckolding, they doe 'hem no credit. Hide, and be hidden; ride, and be ridden, sayes the vapour of experience.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. IIIJ. SCENE. VI.
DIV2.STAGE: TROBLE-ALL. KNOCKHVM. VVHIT. QVARLOVS. EDGVVORTH. BRISTLE. WASPE. HAGGISE. IVSTICE. BVSY. PVRE-CRAFT.

SP.P: BY what warrant do's it say so?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Ha mad child o'the Pye-pouldres, art thou there? fill vs a fresh kan, Vrs, wee may drinke together.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: I may not drinke without a warrant, Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: S'lood, thou'll not stale without a warant, shortly. Whit, Giue mee pen, inke and paper. I'l draw him a warrant present∣ly.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: It must be Iustice Ouerdoo's?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: I know, man, Fetch the drinke, Whit.

SP.SPEAKER: VVHI.
SP.P: I pre dee now, be very briefe, Captaine; for de new Ladies stay for dee.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: O, as briefe as can be, here 'tis already. Adam Ouerdoo.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: VVhy, now, I'le pledge you, Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Drinke it off. I'll come to thee, anone, againe.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Well, Sir. You are now discharg'd:Quarlous to the Cut-purse▪ beware of being spi'd, hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P:
Sir, will it please you, enter in here, at Vrsla's; and take
part of a silken gowne, a veluet petticoate, or a wrought smocke; I am promis'd such: and I can spare any Gentleman a moity.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Keepe it for your companions in beastlinesse, I am none of 'hem, Sir. If I had not already forgiuen you a greater trespasse, or thought you yet worth my beating, I would instruct your man∣ners, to whom you made your offers. But goe your wayes, talke not to me, the hangman is onely fit to discourse with you; the hand of Beadle is too mercifull a punishment for your Trade of life. I am sorry I employ'd this fellow; for he thinks me such: Fa∣cinus quos inquinat, aequat. But, it was for sport. And would I make it serious, the getting of this Licence is nothing to me, without o∣ther circumstances concurre. I do thinke how impertinently I la∣bour, if the word bee not mine, that the ragged fellow mark'd: And what aduantage I haue giuen Ned Win-wife in this time now, of working her, though it be mine. Hee'll go neare to forme to her what a debauch'd Rascall I am, and fright her out of all good con∣ceipt of me: I should doe so by him, I am sure, if I had the oppor∣tunity. But my hope is in her temper, yet; and it must needs bee next to despaire, that is grounded on any part of a woman's dis∣cretion. I would giue by my troth, now, all I could spare (to my cloathes, and my sword) to meete my tatter'd sooth-sayer againe, who was my iudge i'the question, to know certainly whose word he has damn'd or sau'd. For, till then, I liue but vnder a Repreiue. I must seeke him. Who be these?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Ent Waspe wit the offi∣cers.Sir, you are a welsh Cuckold, and a prating Runt, and no Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: You say very well. Come put in his legge in the middle roundell, and let him hole there.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: You stinke of leeks, Metheglyn, and cheee. You Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Why, what is that to you, if you sit sweetly in the stocks in the meane time? if you haue a minde to stinke too, your bree∣ches sit close enough to your bumm. Sit you merry, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA
SP.P: How now, Numps?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: It is no matter, how; pray you looke off.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Nay I'll not offend you, Numps. I thought you had sate there to be seen.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: And to be sold, did you not? pray you mind your busi∣nesse, an' you haue any.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Cry you mercy, Numps. Do's your leg lie high enough?

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: How now, neighbour Haggise, what sayes Iustice Ouerdo's worship, to the other offenders?

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: Why, hee sayes iust nothing, what should hee say? Or where should he say? He is not to be found, Man. He ha' not been seen i'the Fayre, here, all this liue-long day, neuer since seuen a clocke i' the morning. His Clearks know not what to thinke on't. There is no Court of Pie-poulders yet. Heere they be return'd.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: What shall be done with 'hem, then? in your discretion?

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: I thinke wee were best put 'hem in the stocks, in discre∣tion (there they will be safe in discretion) for the valour of an houre, or such a thing, till his worship come.As they open the stockes, Waspe puts his shooe on his hand, and slips it in for his legge.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI
SP.P: It is but a hole matter, if wee doe, Neighbour Haggise, come, Sir, heere is company for you, heaue vp the stocks.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I shall put a tricke vpon your welsh diligence, per∣haps.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Put in your legge, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: What, Rabby Busy! is hee come?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: I doe obey thee, the Lyon may roare, but he cannot bite.They bring Busy, and put him in. I am glad to be thus separated from the heathen of the land, and put a part in the stocks, for the holy cause.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: VVhat are you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: One that reioyceth in his affliction, and sitteth here to prophesie, the destruction of Fayres and May-games, Wakes, and Whitson-ales, and doth sigh and groane for the reformation, of these abuses.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: And doe you sigh, and groane too, or reioyce in your affliction?

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: I doe not feele it, I doe not thinke of it, it is a thing with∣out mee. Adam, thou art aboue these battries, these contumelies. In te manca ruit fortuna, as thy friend Horace saies; thou art one, Quem neque pauperies, neque mors, neque vincula terrent,. And there∣fore as another friend of thine saies, (I thinke it be thy friend Per∣sius) Non te quaesicris extra.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: What's heere! a Stoick i'the stocks? the Foole is turn'd Philosopher.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Friend, I will leaue to communicate my spirit with you, if I heare any more of those superstitious reliques, those lists of Latin, the very rags of Rome, and patches of Poperie.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Nay, an'you begin to quarrel, Gentlemen, I'll leaue you. I ha' paid for quarrelling too lately: looke you, a deuice,He gets out. but shifting in a hand for a foot. God b'w'you.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Wilt thou then leaue thy brethren in tribulation?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: For this once, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Thou art a halting Neutrall stay him there, stop him: that will not endure the heat of persecution.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: How now, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Hee is fled, he is fled, and dares not sit it out.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: What, has he made an escape, which way? follow, neigh∣bour Haggise.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: O me! in the stocks! haue the wicked preuail'd?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Peace religious sister, it is my calling, comfort your selfe, an extraordinary calling, and done for my better standing, my su∣rer standing, hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: By whose warrant, by whose warrant, this?The mad-man enters.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: O, here's my man! dropt in, I look'd for.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: O good Sir, they haue set the faithfull, here to be won∣der'd at; and prouided holes, for the holy of the land.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Had they warrant for it? shew'd they Iusticce Ouerdoo's hand? if they had no warrant, they shall answer it.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Sure you did not locke the stocks sufficiently, neighbour Toby!

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: No! see if you can lock 'hem better.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: They are very sufficiently lock'd, and truely, yet some thing is in the mater.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: True, your warrant is the matter that is in question, by what warrant?

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: Mad man, hold your peace, I will put you in his roome else, in the very same hole, doe you see?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: How! is hee a mad-man!

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Shew me Iustice Ouerdoo's warrant. I obey you.

SP.SPEAKER: HAG.
SP.P: You are a mad foole, hold your tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Shewes his Kanne.In Iustice Ouerdoo's name, I drinke to you, and here's my warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Alas poore wretch! how it earnes my heart for him!

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: If hee be mad, it is in vaine to question him. I'le try though, friend: there was a Gentlewoman, shew'd you two names, some houre since, Argalus and Palemon, to marke in a booke, which of 'hem was it you mark'd?

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: I marke no name, but Adam Ouerdoo, that is the name of names, hee onely is the sufficient Magistrate; and that name I re∣uerence, shew it mee.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: This fellowes madde indeede: I am further off, now, then afore.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: I shall not breath in peace, till I haue made him some a∣mends.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Well, I will make another vse of him, is come in my head: I haue a nest of beards in my Truncke, one some thing like his.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: The watch-men come back againe. The mad-man fights with 'hem, and they leaue open the stocks.This mad foole has made mee that I know not whether I I haue lock'd the stocks or no, I thinke I lock'd 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Take Adam Ouerdoo in your minde, and feare nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: S'lid, madnesse it selfe, hold thy peace, and take that.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Strikest thou without a warrant? take thou that.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Wee are deliuered by miracle; fellow in fetters, let vs not refuse the meanes, this madnesse was of the spirit: The malice of the enemy hath mock'd it selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P:
Mad doe they call him! the world is mad in error, but hee is mad in truth: I loue him o'the sudden, (the cunning man sayd all true) and shall loue him more, and more. How well it becomes a man to be mad in truth! O, that I might be his yoake-fellow, and be mad with him, what a many should wee draw to
madnesse in truth, with vs!

SP.SPEAKER: BRI.
SP.P: How now! all scap'd? where's the woman? it is witchcraft!The watch missing them are affrigh∣ted. Her veluet hat is a witch, o' my conscience, or my key! t'one. The mad-man was a Diuell, and I am an Asse; so blesse me, my place, and mine office.

WEll, Lucke and Saint Bartholmew; out with the signe of our inuention, in the name of Wit, and do you beat the Drum, the while; All the fowle i'the Fayre, I meane, all the dirt in Smithfield, (that's one of Master Littlewit's Carwhitchets now) will be throwne at our Banner to day, if the matter do's not please the people. O the Motions, that I Lanthorne Leatherhead haue giuen light to, i' my time, since my Master Pod dyed! Ierusalem was a stately thing; and so was Niniue, and the citty of Norwich, and Sodom and Gomorrah;Pod was a Master of motions be∣fore him. with the rising o'the prentises; and pulling downe the bawdy houses there, vpon Shroue-Tuesday; but the Gunpowder-plot, there was a get-penny! I haue presented that to an eighteene, or twenty pence audience, nine times in an afternoone. Your home-borne proiects proue euer the best, they are so easie, and familiar, they put too much learning i'their things now o'dayes: and that I feare will be the spoile o'this. Little-wit? I say, Mickle-wit! if not too mickle! looke to your gathering there, good man Filcher.

SP.SPEAKER: FIL.
SP.P: I warrant you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: And there come any Gentlefolks, take two pence a piece, Sharkwell.

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.P: I warrant you, Sir, three pence, an'we can.

THis later disguise, I haue borrow'd of a Porter, shall carry me out to all my great and good ends;The Iustice comes in like a Porter. which how euer interrup∣ted, were neuer destroyed in me: neither is the houre of my seue∣rity yet come, to reueale my selfe, wherein cloud-like, I will breake out in raine, and haile, lightning, and thunder, vpon the head of enormity. Two maine works I haue to prosecute: first, one is to inuent some satisfaction for the poore, kinde wretch, who is out of his wits for my sake, and yonder I see him comming, I will walke aside, and proiect for it.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: I wonder where Tom Quarlous is, that hee returnes not, it may be he is strucke in here to seeke vs.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: See, heere's our mad-man againe.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: I haue made my selfe as like him, as his gowne, and cap will giue me leaue.Quarlous in the habit of the mad-man is mis∣taken by Mrs Pure-craft.

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: Sir, I loue you, and would be glad to be mad with you in truth.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: How! my widdow in loue with a mad-man?

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: Verily, I can be as mad in spirit, as you.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: By whose warrant? leaue your canting. Gentlewoman, haue I found you? (saue yee, quit yee, and multiply yee) where's your booke?He desires to see the booke of Mistresse Grace. 'twas a sufficient name I mark'd, let me see't, be not afraid to shew't me.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: What would you with it, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Marke it againe, and againe, at your seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Heere it is, Sir, this was it you mark'd.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Palemon? fare you well, fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: How, Palemon!

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Yes faith, hee has discouer'd it to you, now, and there∣fore 'twere vaine to disguise it longer, I am yours, Sir, by the be∣nefit of your fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: And you haue him Mistresse, beleeue it, that shall ne∣uer giue you cause to repent her benefit, but make you rather to thinke that in this choyce, she had both her eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: I desire to put it to no danger of protestation.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Palemon, the word, and Win-wife the man?

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: Good Sir, vouchsafe a yoakefellow in your madnesse, shun not one of the sanctified sisters, that would draw with you, in truth.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Away, you are a heard of hypocriticall proud Igno∣rants, rather wilde, then mad. Fitter for woods, and the society of beasts then houses, and the congregation of men. You are the se∣cond part of the society of Canters, Outlawes to order and Disci∣pline, and the onely priuiledg'd Church-robbers of Christendome. Let me alone. Palemon, the word, and Winwife the man?

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: I must vncouer my selfe vnto him, or I shall neuer enioy him, for all the cunning mens promises. Good Sir, heare mee, I am worth sixe thousand pound, my loue to you, is become my racke, I'll tell you all, and the truth: since you hate the hyporisie of the party-coloured brother-hood. These seuen yeeres, I haue beene a wilfull holy widdow, onely to draw feasts, and gifts from my in∣tangled suitors: I am also by office, an assisting sister of the Deacons, and a deuourer, in stead of a distributer of the alms. I am a speciall maker of marriages for our decayed Brethren, with our rich wid∣dowes; for a third part of their wealth, when they are marryed, for the reliefe of the poore elect: as also our poore handsome yong Virgins, with our wealthy Batchelors, or Widdowers; to make them steale from their husbands, when I haue confirmed them in the faith, and got all put into their custodies. And if I ha' not my bargaine, they may sooner turne a scolding drab, in to a silent Minister, then make me leaue pronouncing reprobation, and damna∣tion vnto them. Our elder, Zeale-of-the-land, would haue had me, but I know him to be the capitall Knaue of the land, making him∣selfe rich, by being made Feoffee in trust to deceased Brethren, and coozning their heyres, by swearing the absolute gift of their inhe∣ritance. And thus hauing eas'd my conscience, and vtter'd my heart, with the tongue of my loue: enioy all my deceits together. I beseech you. I should not haue reuealed this to you, but that in time I thinke you are mad, and I hope you'll thinke mee so too, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P:
Stand aside, I'le answer you, presently.He consider with him∣selfe of it. Why should not I marry this sixe thousand pound, now I thinke on't? and a good trade too, that shee has beside, ha? The tother wench, Winwife, is sure of; there's no expectation for me there! here I may make my selfe some sauer, yet, if shee continue mad, there's the question. It is money that I want, why should I not marry the money, when 'tis offer'd mee? I haue a License and all, it is but razing out one name, and putting in another. There's no playing with a man's fortune! I am resolu'd! I were truly mad, an' I would not! well, come your wayes, follow mee, an' you will be mad,
He takes her along with him.
The Iustice calls him. I'll shew you a warrant!

SP.SPEAKER: PVR.
SP.P: Most zealously, it is that I zealously desire.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Sir, let mee speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: By whose warrant?

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: The warrant that you tender, and respect so; Iustice Ouer∣doo's! I am the man, friend Trouble-all, though thus disguis'd (as the carefull Magistrate ought) for the good of the Republique, in the Fayre, and the weeding out of enormity. Doe you want a house or meat, or drinke, or cloathes? speake whatsoeuer it is, it shall be supplyed you, what want you?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Nothing but your warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: My warrant? for what?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: To be gone, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Nay, I pray thee stay, I am serious, and haue not many words, nor much time to exchange with thee; thinke what may doe thee good.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Your hand and seale, will doe me a great deale of good; nothing else in the whole Fayre, that I know.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: If it were to any end, thou should'st haue it willingly.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Why, it will satisfie me, that's end enough, to looke on; an' you will not gi' it mee, let me goe.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Alas! thou shalt ha' it presently: I'll but step into the Scriueners,The Iustice goes out. hereby, and bring it. Doe not go away.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Why, this mad mans shape, will proue a very fortunate one, I thinke! can a ragged robe produce these effects? if this be the wise Iustice, and he bring mee his hand, I shall goe neere to make some vse on't. Hee is come already!

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: and returns.Looke thee! heere is my hand and seale, Adam Ouerdoo, if there be any thing to be written, aboue in the paper, that thou want'st now, or at any time hereafter; thinke on't; it is my deed, I deliuer it so, can your friend write?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Hee vrgeth Mistresse Purecraft.Her hand for a witnesse, and all is well.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Why should not I ha' the conscience, to make this a bond of a thousand pound? now, or what I would else?

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Looke you, there it is; and I deliuer it as my deede a∣gaine.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Let vs now proceed in madnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: He takes her in with him.Well, my conscience is much eas'd; I ha' done my part, though it doth him no good, yet Adam hath offer'd satisfaction! The sting is remoued from hence: poore man, he is much alter'd with his affliction, it has brought him low! Now, for my other worke, reducing the young man (I haue follow'd so long in loue) from the brinke of his bane, to the center of safety. Here, or in some such like vaine place, I shall be sure to finde him. I will waite the good time.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. V. SCENE. IIJ.
DIV2.STAGE: COKES. SHAKRVVEL. IVSTICE. FIL∣CHER. IOHN. LANTERNE.

SP.P: HOw now? what's here to doe? friend, art thou the Master of the Monuments?

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.P: 'Tis a Motion, an't please your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: My phantasticall brother in Law, Master Bartholmew Cokes!

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: A Motion, what's that?He reads the Bill. The ancient moderne history of Hero, and Leander, otherwise called The Touchstone of true Loue, with as true a tryall of friendship, betweene Damon, and Pithias, two faithfull friends o'the Bankside? pretty i'faith, what's the mea∣ning on't? is't an Enterlude? or what is't?

SP.SPEAKER: FIL.
SP.P: Yes Sir, please you come neere, wee'll take your money within.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Backe with these children;The boyes o'the Fayre follow him. they doe so follow mee vp and downe.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: By your leaue, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: FIL.
SP.P: You must pay, Sir, an' you goe in.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Who, I? I perceiue thou know'st not mee: call the Ma∣ster o'the Motion.

SP.SPEAKER: SHA
SP.P: What, doe you not know the Author, fellow Filcher? you must take no money of him; he must come in gratis: Mr. Little-wit is a voluntary; he is the Author.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Peace, speake not too lowd, I would not haue any notice taken, that I am the Author, till wee see how it passes.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Master Littlewit, how do'st thou?

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Master Cokes! you are exceeding well met: what, in your doublet, and hose, without a cloake, or a hat?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I would I might neuer stirre, as I am an honest man, and by that fire; I haue lost all i'the Fayre, and all my acquaintance too; did'st thou meet any body that I know, Master Littlewit? my man Numps, or my sister Ouerdoo, or Mistresse Grace? pray thee Master Littlewit, lend mee some money to see the Interlude, here. I'le pay thee againe, as I am a Gentleman. If thou'lt but carry mee home, I haue money enough there.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: O, Sir, you shall command it, what, will a crowne serue you?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I think it well, what do we pay for comming in, fellowes?

SP.SPEAKER: FIL.
SP.P: Two pence, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Two pence? there's twelue pence, friend; Nay, I am a Gallant, as simple as I looke now; if you see mee with my man a∣bout me, and my Artillery, againe.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Your man was i'the Stocks, ee'n now, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Who, Numps?

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Yes faith.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: For what i' saith, I am glad o' that; remember to tell me on't anone; I haue enough, now! What manner of matter is this, Mr. Littl wit? What kind of Actors ha' you? Are they good A∣ctors?

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Pretty youthes, Sir, all children both old and yong, heer's the Master of 'hem—

SP.SPEAKER: (LAN.
SP.P: Leather∣head whis∣pers to Littl-wit.Call me not Leatherhead, but Lanterne.)

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Master Lanterne, that giues light to the businesse,

SP.SPEAKER: COK▪
SP.P: In good time, Sir, I would faine see 'hem, I would be glad drinke with the young company; which is the Tiring-house?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Troth, Sir, our Tiring-house is somewhat little, we are but beginners, yet, pray pardon vs; you cannot goe vpright in't.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: No? not now my hat is off? what would you haue done with me, if you had had me, feather, and all, as I was once to day? Ha' you none of your pretty impudent boyes, now; to bring stooles, fill Tabacco, fetch Ale, and beg money, as they haue at other houses? let me see some o'your Actors.

SP.SPEAKER: ION.
SP.P: Shew him 'hem, shew him 'hem. Master Lanterne, this is a Gentleman, that is a fauorer of the quality.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: I, the fauouring of this licencious quality, is the consump∣tion of many a young Gentleman; a pernicious enormity.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: What, doe they liue in baskets?

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: He brings them out in a basket.They doe lye in a basket, Sir, they are o'the small Play∣ers.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: These be Players minors, indeed. Doe you call these Play∣ers?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: They are Actors, Sir, and as good as any, none disprais'd, for dumb showes: indeed, I am the mouth of 'hem all!

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Thy mouth will hold 'hem all. I thinke, one Taylor, would goe neere to beat all this company, with a hand bound be∣hinde him.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: I, and eate 'hem all, too, an' they were in cake-bread.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I thanke you for that, Master Littlewit, a good est! which is your Burbage now?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: What meane you by that, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Your best Actor. Your Field?

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: Good ifaith! you are euen with me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P:
This is he, that acts young Leander, Sir. He is extream∣ly belou'd of the womenkind, they doe so affect his action, the
green gamesters, that come here, and this is louely Hero; this with the beard, Damon; and this pretty Pythias: this is the ghost of King Dionysius in the habit of a scriuener: as you shall see anone, at large.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Well they are a ciuill company, I like 'hem for that; they offer not to fleere, nor geere, nor breake iests, as the great Players doe: And then, there goes not so much charge to the fea∣sting of 'hem, or making 'hem drunke, as to the other, by reason of their littlenesse. Doe they vse to play perfect? Are they neuer fluster'd?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: No, Sir. I thanke my industry, and policy for it; they are as well gouern'd a company, though I say it— And heere is young Leander, is as proper an Actor of his inches; and shakes his head like an hostler.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: But doe you play it according to the printed booke? I haue read that.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: By no meanes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: No? How then?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: A better way, Sir, that is too learned, and poeticall for our audience; what doe they know what Hellespont is? Guilty of true loues blood? or what Abidos is? or the other Sestos hight?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Th'art i'the right, I do not know my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: No, I haue entreated Master Littlewit, to take a little paines to reduce it to a more familiar straine for our people.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: How, I pray thee, good Mr. Littlewit?

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: It pleases him to make a matter of it, Sir. But there is no such matter I assure you: I haue onely made it a little easie, and moderne for the times, Sir, that's all; As, for the Hellespont I ima∣gine our Thames here; and then Leander, I make a Diers sonne, a∣bout Puddle-wharfe: and Hero a wench o'the Banke-side, who go∣ing ouer one morning, to old fish-street; Leander spies her land at Trigsstayers, and falls in loue with her: Now do I introduce Cu∣pid, hauing Metamorphos'd himselfe into a Drawer, and hee strikes Hero in loue with a pint of Sherry, and other pretty passages there are, o'the friendship, that will delight you, Sir, and please you of iudgement.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I'll be sworne they shall; I am in loue with the Actors al∣ready, and I'll be allyed to them presently. (They respect gentle∣men, these fellowes) Hero shall be my fayring: But, which of my fayrings? (Le' me see) i'faith, my fiddle! and Leander my fiddle-sticke: Then Damon, my drum; and Pythias, my Pipe and the ghost of Dionysius, my hobby-horse. All fitted.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. V. SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: To them WIN-WIFE. GRACE. KNOCKHVM. WHITT. EDGVVORTH. VVIN. Mistris OVERDOO. And to them VVASPE.

SP.P: Looke yonder's your Cokes gotten in among his play-fellowes; I thought we could not misse him, at such a Spectacle.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Let him alone, he is so busie, he will neuer spie vs.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.P: Nay, good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Cokes is handling the Puppets.I warrant thee, I will not hurt her, fellow; what dost think me vnciuill? I pray thee be not iealous: I am toward a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH▪
SP.P: Well good Master Lanterne, make ready to begin, that I may fetch my wife, and looke you be perfect, you vndoe me else, i'my reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: I warrant you Sir, doe not you breed too great an expe∣ctation of it, among your friends: that's the onely hurter of these things.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: No, no, no.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I'll stay here, and see; pray thee let me see.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-VV.
SP.P: How diligent and troublesome he is!

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: The place becomes him, me thinkes.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: My ward, Mistresse Grace in the company of a stranger? I doubt I shall be compell'd to discouer my selfe, before my time!

SP.SPEAKER: FIL.
SP.P: Two pence a piece Gentlemen, an excellent Motion.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: The doore-keepers speake.Shall we haue fine fire-works, and good vapours!

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.P: Yes Captaine, and water-works, too.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: I pree dee, take a care o'dy shmall Lady, there, Edgworth; I will looke to dish tall Lady my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Welcome Gentlemen, welcome Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Predee, Mashter o'de Monshtersh, helpe a very sicke Lady, here, to a chayre, to shit in.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Presently, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: They bring Mistrs O∣uerdoo a chayre.Good fait now, Vrsla's Ale, and Aqua-vitae ish to blame for't; shit downe shweet heart, shit downe▪ and shleep a little.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Madame, you are very welcom hither.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Yes, and you shall see very good vapours.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Here is my care come! I like to see him in so good com∣pany;By Edge∣worth. and yet I wonder that persons of such fashion, should re∣sort hither!

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: This is a very priuate house, Madame.The Cut-purse courts Mistresse Litt wit.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Will it please your Ladiship sit, Madame?

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: Yes good-man. They doe so all to be Madame mee, I thinke they thinke me a very Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: What else Madame?

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: Must I put off my masque to him?

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: O, by no meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: How would my husband know mee, then?

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Husband? an idle vapour; he must not know you, nor you im; there's the true vapour.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Y, I will obserue more of this: is this a Lady, friend?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: I and is anoder Lady, shweet heart; if dou hasht a minde to 'hem gie me twelue pence from tee, and dou shalt haue eder-oder on 'hem!

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: I? This will prooue my chiefest enormity: I will follow this.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG,
SP.P: Is not this a finer life, Lady, then to be clogg'd with a husband?

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: Yes, a great deale. When will they beginne, trow? in the name o'the Motion?

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: By and by Madame, they stay but for company.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Doe you heare, Puppet. Master, these are tedious vapours; when begin you?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: We stay but for Master Littlewit, the Author, who is gone for his wife; and we begin presently.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: That's I, that's I.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: That was you, Lady; but now you are no such poore thing.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Hang the Authors wife, a running vapour! here be La∣dies, will stay for nere a Delia o'hem all.

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: But heare mee now, heere ish one o'de Ladish, a shleep, stay till shee but vake man.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: How now friends? what's heere to doe?

SP.SPEAKER: FIL.
SP.P: Two pence a piece, Sir, the best Motion, in the Fayre.The doore-keepers a∣gaine.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I beleeue you lye; if you doe, I'll haue my money a∣gaine, and beat you.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN.
SP.P: Numps is come!

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Did you see a Master of mine, come in here, a tall yong Squire of Harrow o'the Hill; Master Bartholmew Cokes?

SP.SPEAKER: FIL.
SP.P: I thinke there be such a one, within.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Looke hee be, you were best: but it is very likely: I wonder I found him not at all the rest. I ha' beene at the Eagle, and the blacke Wolfe, and the Bull with the fiue legges, and two pizzles; (hee was a Calfe at Vxbridge Fayre, two yeeres agone) And at the dogges that daunce the Morrice, and the Hare o' the Taber; and mist him at all these! Sure this must needs be some fine sight, that holds him so, if it haue him.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Come, come, are you ready now?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Presently, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Hoyday, hee's at worke in his Dublet, and hose; doe you heare, Sir? are you imploy'd? that you are bare headed, and so busie?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Hold your peace, Numpes; you ha' beene i'the Stocks, I heare.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Do's he know that? nay, then the date of my Authority is out; I must thinke no longer to raigne, my gouernment is at an end. He that will correct another, must want fault in himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Sententious Numps! I neuer heard so much from him, before.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Sure, Master Littlewit will not come; please you take your place, Sir, wee'll beginne.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I pray thee doe, mine eares long to be at it; and my eyes too. O Numps, i'the Stocks, Numps? where's your sword, Numps?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I pray you intend your game, Sir, let me alone.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Well then, we are quit for all. Come, sit downe, Numps; I'le interpret to thee: did you see Mistresse Grace? it's no mat∣ter, neither, now I thinke on't, tell mee anon.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: A great deale of loue, and care, he expresses.

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: Alas! would you haue him to expresse more then hee has? that were tyranny.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Peace, ho; now, now.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: Gentles, that no longer your expectations may wander,
Behold our chief Actor, amorous Leander.
With a great deale of cloth, lap'd about him like a Scarfe,
For he yet serues his father, a Dyer at Puddle wharfe,
Which place wee'll make bold with, to call it our Abidus,
As the Banke-side is our Sestos, and let it not be deny'd vs.
Now, as he is beating, to make the Dye take the fuller,
Who chances to come by, but faire Hero, in a Sculler;
And seeing Leanders naked legge, and goodly calfe,
Cast at him, from the boat, a Sheepes eye, and a halfe.
Now she is landed, and the Sculler come backe;
By and by, you shall see what Leander doth lacke.

P.HI: That is the Scullers name without controle.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: We doe heare you.

P.HI: Old cole? Is the Dyer turn'd Collier? how do you sell?
A pox o'your maners, kisse my hole here, and smell.
Kisse your hole, and smell? there's manners indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: Be hang'd; looke you yonder,
Old Cole, you must go hang with Master Leander.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. L.
SP.P: Here, Cole, what fayerest of Fayers, was that fare, that thou landedst but now a Trigsstayres?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: What was that, fellow? Pray thee tell me, I scarse vn∣derstand 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: Leander do's aske, Sir, what fayrest of Fayers,
Was the fare thhe landed, but now, at Trigsstayers?

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. C.
SP.P: It is louely Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. L.
SP.P: Nero?

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. C.
SP.P: No, Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: It is Hero.
Of the Bankside, he saith▪ to tell you truthwith out erring,
Is come ouer into Fish-street to eat some fresh herring.
Leander sayes no more, but as fast as he can,
Gets on all his best cloathes; and will after to the Swan.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Most admirable good, is't not?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Stay, Sculler.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: You must stay for Leander, and carry him to the wench.

P.HI: You Rogue, I am no Pandar.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: He sayes he is no Pandar. 'Tis a fine language; I vnder∣stand it, now.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Are you no Pandar, Goodman Cole? heer's no man sayes you are, You'll grow a hot Cole, it seemes, pray you stay for your fare.

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.L: VVould you ha' Leander come away? why 'pray' Sir, stay.
You are angry, Goodman Cole; I beleeue the faire Mayd
Came ouer w' you a' trust: tell vs Sculler, are you paid.

P.HI: I Hogrubber o' Pickt-hatch. Take you that.

L.NOTE: The Puppet strikes him ouer the pate

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Harme watch, harme catch, he sayes: very good i' faith, the Sculler had like to ha' knock'd you, sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Yes, but that his fare call'd him away.

P.HI: Row apace, row apace, row, row, row, row, row.
You are knauishly loaden, Sculler, take heed where you goe.
Knaue i' your face, Goodman Rogue.
Row, row, row, row, row, row.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Hee said knaue i' your face, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: I Sir, I heard him. But there's no talking to these watermen, they will ha' the last word

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: God's my life! I am not allied to the Sculler, yet; hee shall be Dauphin my boy. But my Fiddle-sticke do's fiddle in and out too much; I pray thee speake to him, on't: tell him, I would haue him tarry in my sight, more.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: I Pray you be content; you'll haue enough on him, Sir.

LG.L: Now gentles, I take it, here is none of you so stupid,
but that you haue heard of a little god of loue, call'd Cupid.
VVho out of kindnes to Leander, hearing he but (aw her,
this present day and houre, doth turne himselfe to a Drawer.
And because, he would haue their first meeting to be merry,
he strikes Hero in loue to him, with a pint of Sherry.
VVhich he tells her▪ from amorous Leander is sent her,
PVP. Lean∣der goes in∣to Mistris Hero's roomwho after him, into the roome of Hero, doth venter.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. IO:
SP.P: A pint of sacke, score a pint of sacke, i'the Conney.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Sack? you said but ee'n now it should be Sherry.

P.HI: Why so it is; sherry, sherry, sherry.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Sherry, sherry, sherry. By my troth he makes me merry. I must haue a name for Cupid, too. Let me see, thou mightst helpe me now, an' thou wouldest, Numps, at a dead lift, but thou art dream∣ing o' the stocks, still! Do not thinke on't, I haue forgot it: 'tis but a nine dayes wonder, man; let it not trouble thee.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I would the stocks were about your necke, Sir; conditi∣on I hung by the heeles in them, till the wonder were off from you, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Well said resolute Numps: but hearke you friend, where is the friendship, all this while, betweene my Drum, Damon; and my Pipe, Pythias?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: You shall see by and by, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: You thinke my Hobby-horse is forgotten, too; no, I'll see▪ 'hem all enact before I go; I shall not know which to loue best, else

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: This Gallant has interrupting vapours, troublesome va∣pours, Whitt, puffe with him.

SP.SPEAKER: WHIT.
SP.P: No, I pre dee, Captaine, let him alone. Hee is a Child i' faith, la'.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: Now gentles, to the freinds, who in number, are two,
and lodg'd in that Ale-house, in which faire Hero do's doe.
Damon (for some kindnesse done him the last weeke)
is come faire Hero, in Fish-streete, this morning to seeke:
Pythias do's smell the knauery of the meeting,
and now you shall see their true friendly greeting.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Whore-masterly slaue, you? very friendly, & familiar, that.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. Da.
SP.L: Whore-master i'thy face,
Thou hast lien with her thy selfe, I'll proue't i'this place.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Damon sayes Pythias has lien with her, himselfe, hee'll prooue't in this place.

P.HI: They are Whore-masters both, Sir, that's a plaine case.
Doe I ly, like a Rogue?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: A Pimpe, and a Scabbe?
I say between you, you haue both but one Drabbe.

P.HI: And you are a Pimpe, againe.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: And you are a Pimpe againe, he sayes.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: And a Scabbe againe, he sayes.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: And I say againe, you are both whore-masters againe,They fight.
and you haue both but one Drabbe againe.

P.HI: Do'st thou, do'st thou, do'st thou?

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. P.
SP.P: Downe with him, Damon

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. D.
SP.P: Pinke his guts, Pythias▪

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: What, so malicious?
will ye murder me, Masters both, i'mine owne house?

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Ho! well acted my Drum, well acted my Pipe, well acted still.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Well acted, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: I, both your hands, for▪ my sake! for you ha' both done well.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. D.
SP.P: Gramercy pure Pythias.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. P.
SP.P: Gramercy, Deare Damon.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Gramercy to you both, my Pipe, and my drum.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. P. D.
SP.P: Come now wee'll together to breakfast to Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: 'Tis well, you can now go to breakfast to Hero, you haue giuen many breakfast, with a hone and honero.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: How is't friend, ha' they hurt thee?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: O no!
Betweene you and I Sir, we doe but make show.
Thus Gentles you perceiue, without any deniall,
'twixt Damon and Pythias here, friendships true tryall.
Though hourely they quarrell thus, and roare each with other,
they fight you no more, then do's brother with brother.
But friendly together, at the next man they meet,
they let fly their anger as here you might see't.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Well, we haue seen't, and thou hast felt it, whatsoeuer thou sayest, what's next? what's next?

SP.SPEAKER: LEA.
SP.L: This while young Leander, with faire Hero is drinking,
and Hero growne drunke, to any mans thinking!
Yet was it not three pints of Sherry could flaw her.
till Cupid distinguish'd like Ionas the Drawer,
From vnder his apron, where his lechery lurkes,
put loue in her Sacke. Now marke how it workes.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. H.
SP.L: O Leander Leander, my deare my deare Leander,
I'le for euer be thy goose, so thou'lt be my gander

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Excellently well said, Fiddle, shee'll euer be his goose, so hee'll be her gander: was't not so?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: Yes, Sir, but marke his answer, now:

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. L·
SP.L: And sweetest of geese, before I goe to bed,
I'll swimme o're the Thames, my goose, thee to tread.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Braue! he will swimme o're the Thames, and tread his goose, too night, he sayes.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: I, peace, Sir, the'll be angry, if they heare you eaues-drop∣ping, now they are setting their match.

P.HI: But lest the Thames should be dark, my goose, my deare friend, let thy window be prouided of a candles end.
Feare not my gander, I protest, I should handle my matters very ill, if I had not a whole candle.
Well then, looke to't, and kisse me to boote.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Now, heere come the friends againe, Pythias, and Damon, and vnder their clokes,Damon and Pythias en∣ter. they haue of Bacon, a gammon.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: How, some wine there? there's company already, Sir, pray forbeare!

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. D.
SP.P: 'Tis Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Yes, but shee will not be taken, after sacke, and fresh herring, with your Dunmow-bacon.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. P
SP.P: You lye, it's Westfabian.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Westphalian you should say.

P.HI: If you hold not your peace, you are a Coxcombe, I would say.
What's here? what's here? kisse, kisse, vpon kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: I, Wherefore should they not? what harme is in this? 'tis Mistresse Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. D.
SP.P: Mistresse Hero's a whore.

P.HI: Is shee a whore? keepe you quiet, or Sir Knaue out of dore.

NOTE.HI: Heere the Puppets quarrell and fall together by the eares.

P.HI: I say, Knaue, out of doore.
I say, whore, out of doore.
Now you ha' something to doe: you must kisse her o' the arse shee sayes:
So we will, so we will.
O my hanches, O my hanches, hold, hold.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: Stand'st thou still?
Leander, where art thou? stand'st thou still like a sot,
and not offer'st to breake both their heads with a pot?
See who's at thine elbow, there! Puppet Ionas and Cupid.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. I.
SP.P: Vpon'hem Leander, be not so stupid.They fight.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: See, Cupid with a word has tane vp the brawle.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: These be fine vapours!

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: By this good day they fight brauely! doe they not, Numps?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Yes, they lack'd but you to be their second, all this while.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.L: This tragicall encounter, falling out thus to busie vs,
It raises vp the ghost of their friend Dionysius:
Not like a Monarch, but the Master of a Schoole,
in a Scriueners furr'd gowne, which shewes he is no foole.
for therein he hath wit enough to keepe himselfe warme.
O Demon he cries, and Pythias; what harme,
Hath poore Dionysius done you in his graue,
That after his death, you should fall out thus, and raue,
And call amorous Leander whore-master Knaue?

P.HI: I cannot, I will not, I promise you endure it.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Downe with Dagon, downe with Dagon; 'tis I, will no longer endure your prophanations.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: What meane you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: I wil remoue Dagon there, I say, that Idoll, that heathenish Idoll, that remaines (as I may say) a beame, a very beame, not a beame of the Sunne, nor a beame of the Moone, nor a beame of a bal∣lance, neither a house-beame, nor a Weauers beame, but a beame in the eye, in the eye of the brethren; a very great beame, an ex∣ceeding great beame; such as are your Stage players, Rimers, and Morrise-dancers, who haue walked hand in hand, in contempt of the Brethren, and the Cause; and beene borne out by instruments, of no meane countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Sir, I present nothing, but what is licens'd by authority.

SP.SPEAKER: BAS.
SP.P: Thou art all license, euen licentiousnesse it selfe, Shimei!

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: I haue the Master of the Reuell's hand for't, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: The Master of Rebells hand, thou hast; Satan's! hold thy peace, thy scurrility shut vp thy mouth, thy profession is dam∣nable, and in pleading for it, thou dost plead for Baal. I haue long opened my mouth wide, and gaped, I haue gaped as the oyster for the tide after thy destruction▪ but cannot compasse it by sute, or dispute; so thar I looke for a bickering, ere long, and then a battell.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Good Banbury-vapours.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Friend, you'ld haue an ill match on't, if you bicker with him here, though he be no man o'the fist, hee has friends that will goe to cuffes for him, Numps, will not you take our side?

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Sir, it shall not need, in my minde; he offers him a fairer course, to end it by disputation! hast thou nothing to say for thy selfe, in defence of thy quality?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Faith, Sir, I am not well studied in these controuersies, betweene the hypocrites and vs. But here's one of my Motion, Pup∣pet Donisius shall vndertake him, and I'le venture the cause on't.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Who? my Hobby-horse? will he dispute with him?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, and make a Hobby-Asse of him, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: That's excellent! indeed he lookes like the best scholler of 'hem all. Come, Sir, you must be as good as your word, now.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: I will not feare to make my spirit, and gifts knowne! as∣sist me zeale, fill me, fill me, that is, make me full.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: What a desperate, prophane wretch is this! is there any Ignorance, or impudence like his? to call his zeale to fill him against a Puppet?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: I know no fitter math, then a Puppet to commit with an Hypocrite!

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: First, I say vnto thee, Idoll, thou hast no Calling.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. D.
SP.P: You lie, I am call'd Dionisius.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: The Motion sayes you lie, he is call'd Dionisius ithe mat∣ter, and to that calling he answers.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: I meane no vocation, Idoll, no present lawfull Calling.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: The Motion asketh, if yours be a lawfull Calling?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Yes, mine is of the Spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP. D.
SP.P: Then Idoll is a lawfull Calling.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: He saies, then Idoll is a lawfull Calling! for you call'd him Idoll, and your Calling is of the spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Well disputed, Hobby-horse!

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Take not part with the wicked young Gallant▪ He neygh∣eth and hinneyeth, all is but hir nying Sophistry. I call him Idoll againe. Yet, I say, his Calling, his Profession is prophane, it is prophane, Idoll.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: It is not prophane, he sayes.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: It is prophane.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: It is prophane.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN
SP.P: Well said, confute him with not, still. You cannot beare him downe with your base noyse, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Nor he me, with his treble creeking, though he creeke like the chariot wheeles of Satan; I am zealous for the Cause—

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: As a dog for a bone.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: And I say, it is prophane, as being the Page of Pride, and the waiting woman of vanity.

P.HI: Yea? what say you to your Tire-women, then?

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Good.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP.
SP.P: Or feather-makers i'the Fryers, that are o'your faction of faith? Are not they with their perrukes, and their puffes, their fannes, and their huffes, as much Pages of Pride, and waiters vpon vanity? what say you? what say you? what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: I will not answer for them.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP.
SP.P: Because you cannot, because you cannot. Is a Bugle-maker a lawfull Calling? or the Confect-makers? such you haue there: or your French Fashioner? you'ld haue all the sinne within your selues, would you not? would you not?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: No, Dagon.

P.HI: What then, Dagonet? is a Puppet worse then these?

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Yes, and my maine argument against you, is, that you are an abomination: for the Male, among you, putteth on the ap∣parell of the Female, and the Female of the Male.

P.HI: You lye, you lye, you lye abominably.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Good, by my troth, he has giuen him the lye thrice.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP.
SP.P: It is your old stale argument against the Players, but it will not hold against the Puppets; for we haue neyther Male nor Female amongst vs. And that thou may'st see, if thou wilt,The Puppet takes vp his garment. like a malicious purblinde zeale as thou art!

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: By my faith, there he has answer'd you, friend; by playne demonstration.

SP.SPEAKER: PVP.
SP.P: Nay, I'le proue, against ere a Rabbin of'hem all, that my stan∣ding is as lawfull as his; that I speak by inspiration, as well as he; that I haue as little to doe with learning as he; and doe scorne her helps as much as he.

SP.SPEAKER: BVS,
SP.P: I am confuted, the Cause hath failed me.

SP.SPEAKER: LAN.
SP.P: Be conuerted, I pray you, and let the Play goe on!

SP.SPEAKER: BVS.
SP.P: Let it goe on. For I am changed, and will become a be∣holder with you!

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: That's braue i'saith, thou hast carryed it away, Hobby-horse, on with the Play!

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Stay, now do I forbid, I Adam Ouerdoo! sit still, I charge you.The Iustice discouers himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: What, my Brother i'law!

SP.SPEAKER: GRA.
SP.P: My wise Guardian!

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: It is time, to take Enormity by the fore head, and brand it▪ for, I haue discouer'd enough.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. V. SCENE. VI.
DIV2.STAGE: To them, QVARLOVS. (like the Mad-man) PVRE-CRAFT. (a while after) IOHN. to them TROV∣BLE-ALL. VRSLA. NIGHTIGALE.

SP.SPEAKER: QVAR.
SP.P: Nay, come Mistresse Bride. You must doe as I doe, now. You must be mad with mee, in truth. I haue heere Iustice Ouerdoo for it.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Peace good Trouble-all; come hither, and you shall trou∣ble nne.To the Cut∣purse, and Mistresse Litwit. I will take the charge of you, and your friend too, you also, young man shall be my care, stand there.

SP.SPEAKER: EDG.
SP.P: Now, mercy vpon mee.

SP.SPEAKER: KNO.
SP.P: Would we were away, Whit, these are dangerous va∣pours,The rest are stealing a∣way. best fall off with our birds, for feare o'the Cage.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Stay, is not my name your terror?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Yesh faith man, and it ish fot tat, we would be gone man.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: O Gentlemen! did you not see a wife of mine? I ha' lost my little wife, as I shall be trusted: my little pretty Win, I left her at the great woman's house in trust yonder, the Pig-womans, with Captaine Iordan, and Captaine Whit, very good men, and I cannot heare of her. Poore foole, I feare shee's stepp'd aside. Mo∣ther, did you not see Win?

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: If this graue Matron be your mother, Sir, stand by her, Et digito compesc labellum, I may perhaps spring a wife for you, anone. Brother Bartholmew, I am sadly sorry, to see you so lightly giuen, and such a Disciple of enormity: with your graue Gouer∣nour Humphrey: but stand you both there, in the middle place; I will reprehend you in your course. Mistresse Grace, let me rescue you out of the hands of the stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir, I am a kinsman of hers.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Are you so? of what name, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: WIN-W.
SP.P: Winwife, Sir▪

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P:
Master Winwife? I hope you haue won no wife of her, Sir. If you haue, I will examine the possibility of it, at fit leasure. Now, to my enormities: looke vpon mee, O London! and see mee, O Smithfield; The example of Iustice, and Mirror of Magistrates: the true top of formality, and scourge of enormity. Harken vnto my
labours, and but obserue my discoueries; and compare Hercules with me, if thou dar'st, of old; or Columbus; Magellan; or our countrey man Drake of later times: stand forth you weedes of enormity, and spread. First, Rabbi Busy, thou superlunaticall hypocrite, next,To Busy, To Lantern, To the horse courser, and Cutpurse. Then Cap. Whit, and Mistresse Littlewit. thou other extremity, thou prophane professor of Puppetry, little better then Poetry: then thou strong Debaucher, and Seducer of youth; witnesse this easie and honest young man: now thou E∣squire of Dames, Madams, and twelue-penny Ladies: now my greene Madame her selfe, of the price. Let mee vnmasque your Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: IOH.
SP.P: O my wife, my wife, my wife!

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Is she your wife? Redde te Harpocratem!

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: By your leaue, stand by my Masters, be vncouer'd.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: O stay him, stay him, helpe to cry, Nightingale; my pan,Enter Trou∣ble-all. my panne.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: NIG.
SP.P: Hee has stolne gammar Vrsla's panne.

SP.SPEAKER: TRO.
SP.P: Yes, and I feare no man but Iustice Ouerdoo.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Vrsla? where is she? O the Sow of enormity, this!To Vrsla, and Nigh∣tingale. wel∣come, stand you there, you Songster, there.

SP.SPEAKER: VRS.
SP.P: An' please your worship, I am in no fault: A Gentleman stripp'd him in my Booth, and borrow'd his gown, and his hat; and hee ranne away with my goods, here, for it.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS·
SP.P: Then this is the true mad-man, and you are the enormity!

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: You are i'the right, I am mad,To Quar∣lous. but from the gowne out∣ward.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Stand you there.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Where you please, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: OVER
SP.P: O lend me a bason, I am sicke, I am sicke;Mistresse Ouerdoo is sicke: and her husband is silenc'd. where's Mr. Ouerdoo? Bridget, call hither my Adam.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: WHI.
SP.P: Dy very owne wie, i'fait, worshipfull Adam.

SP.SPEAKER: OVER.
SP.P: Will not my Adam come at mee? shall I see him no more then?

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P:
Sir, why doe you not goe on with the enormity? are you opprest with it? I'le helpe you: harke you Sir, i'your eare, your Innocent young man, you haue tane such care of, all this day, is a Cutpurse; that hath got all your brother Cokes his things, and help'd you to your beating, and the stocks; if you haue a minde to hang him now, and shew him your Magistrates wit, you may▪ but I should think it were better, recouering the goods, and to saue your estimation in him. I thank you Sr. for the gift of your Ward, Mrs. Grace: look you, here is your hand & seale, by the way. Mr. Win-wife giue you ioy, you are Palemon, you are possest o'the Gentlewoman, but she must pay me value, here's warrant for it. And honest mad-man, there's thy gowne, and cap againe; I thanke thee for my wife. Nay, I can be mad, sweet heart, when I please, still; neuer feare me:To the wid∣dow.
And carefull Numps, where's he? I thanke him for my licence.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: Waspe mis∣seth the Li∣cence.How!

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: 'Tis true, Numps.

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I'll be hang'd then.

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: Loke i'your boxe, Numps, nay, Sir, stand not you fixt here, like a stake in Finsbury to be shot at, or the whipping post i'the Fayre, but get your wife out o'the ayre, it wil make her worse else; and remember you are but Adam, Flesh, and blood! you haue your frailty, forget your other name of Ouerdoo, and inuite vs all to supper. There you and I will compare our discoueries; and drowne the memory of all enormity in your bigg'st bowle at home.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: How now, Numps, ha' you lost it? I warrant, 'twas when thou wert i'the stocks: why dost not speake?

SP.SPEAKER: WAS.
SP.P: I will neuer speak while I liue, againe, for ought I know.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: Nay, Humphrey, if I be patient, you must be so too; this pleasant conceited Gentleman hath wrought vpon my iudgement, and preuail'd: I pray you take care of your sicke friend, Mistresse Alice, and my good friends all—

SP.SPEAKER: QVA.
SP.P: And no enormities.

SP.SPEAKER: IVS.
SP.P: I inuite you home, with mee to my house, to supper: I will haue none feare to go along, for my intents are Ad correctionem, non ad destructionem; Ad aedificandum, non ad diruendum: so lead on.

SP.SPEAKER: COK.
SP.P: Yes, and bring the Actors along, wee'll ha'the rest o'the Play at home.

DIV1.HEAD: The EPILOGVE.
DIV1.L: YOur Maiesty hath seene the Play, and you
can best allow it from your care, and view.
You know the scope of Writers, and what store,
of leaue is giuen them, if they take not more,
And turne it into licence: you can tell
if we haue vs'd that leaue you gaue vs, well▪
Or whether wee to rage, or licence breake,
or be prophane, or make prophane men speake?
This is your power to iudge (great Sir) and not
the enuy of a few. Which if wee haue got,
Wee value lesse what their dislike can bring,
if it so happy be, t'haue pleas'd the King.

DIV1.P: THE DIUELL IS AN ASSE: A COMEDIE ACTED IN THE YEARE, 1616. BY HIS MAIESTIES SERVANTS.

Q.P: Ficta voluptatis Causâ, sint proxima veris.

DIV1.P: LONDON, Printed by I. B. for ROBERT ALLOT, and are to be sold at the signe of the Beare, in Pauls Church-yard. 1631.

LIST.ITEM: Sir POVLE EITHER-SIDE. A Lawyer, and Iustice.

DIV1.HEAD: The Prologue.
DIV1.L: THe DIVELL is an ASSE. That is, to day,
The name of what you are met for, a new Play▪
Yet Grandee's, would you were not come to grace
Our matter, with allowing vs no place.
Though you presume SATAN a subtill thing,
And may haue heard hee's worne in a thumbe-ring;
Doe not on these presumptions, force vs act,
Incompasse of a cheese-trencher. This tract
Will ne'er admit our vice, because of yours.
Anone, who, worse then you, the fault endures
That your selues make? when you will thrust and spurne,
And knocke vs o'the elbowes, and hid, turne;
As if, when wee had spoke, wee must be gone,
Or, till wee speake, must all runne in, to one,
Like the young adders, at the old ones mouth?
Would wee could stand due North; or had no South,
If that offend: or were Muscouy glasse,
That you might looke our Scenes through as they passe.
We know not how to affect you. If you'll come
To see new Playes, pray you affoord vs roome,
And shew this, but the same face you hae done
Your deare delight, the Diuell of Edmunton.
Or, if, for want of roome it must mis-carry,
'Twill be but Iustice, that your censure tarry,
Till you giue some. And when sixe times you ha' seen't,
If this Play doe not like, the Diuell is in't.

SP.L: HOh, hoh, hoh, hoh, hoh, hoh, hoh, hoh, &c.
To earth? and why to earth, thou foolish Spirit?
What wold'st thou do on earth?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: For that, great Chiefe!
As time shal work, I do but ask my mon'th.
Which euery petty pui'nee Diuell has;
Within that terme, the Coutt of Hell will heare
Something, may gaine a longer grant, perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: SAT.
SP.L: For what? the laming a poore Cow, or two?
Entring a Sow, to make her cast her farrow?
Or crossing of a Mercatwomans Mare,
'Twixt this and Totnam? these were wont to be
Your maine atchieuements, Pug, you haue some plot, now,
Vpon a ronning of Ale, to stale the yest,
Or keepe the churne so, that the butter come not;
Spight o' the housewiues cord, or her hot spit?
Or some good Ribibe, about Kentish Towne,
Or Hogsden, you would hang now, for a witch,
Because shee will not let you play round Robbin:
And you'll goe sowre the Cittiens Creame 'gainst Sunday?
That shee may be accus'd for't, and condemn'd,
By a Middlesex Iury, to the satisfaction
Of their offended friends, the Londoners wiues
Whose teeth were set on edge with it? Foolish feind,
Stay i'your place, know your owne strengths, and put not
Beyond the spheare of your actiuity.
You are too dull a Diuell to be trusted
Forth in those parts, Pug, vpon any affayre
That may concerne our name, on earth. It is not
Euery ones worke. The state of Hell must care
Whom it imployes, in point of reputation,
Heere about London. You would make, thinke
An Agent, to be sent, for Lancashire,
Proper inough; or some parts of Northumberland,
So yo' had good instructions, Pug.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: O Chiefe!
You doe not know, deare Chiefe, what there is in mee.
Proue me but for a fortnight, for a weeke,
And lend mee but a Vice, to carry with mee,
To practice there-with any play-fellow,
And, you will see, there will come more vpon't,
Then you'll imagine, pretious Chiefe.

SP.SPEAKER: SAT.
SP.L: What Vice?
What kind wouldst th'haue it of?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Why, any Fraud;
Or Couetousnesse; or Lady Vanity;
Or old Iniquity: I'll call him hither.

SP.SPEAKER: INI.
SP.L: What is he, calls vpon me, and would seeme to lack a Vice▪
Ere his words be halfe spoken, I am with him in a trice;
Here, there, and euery where, as the Cat is with the mice:
True vetus Iniquitas. Lack'st thou Cards, friend, or Dice?
I will teach thee cheate, Child, to cog, lye, and swagger,
And euer and anon, to be drawing forth thy dagger:
To sweare by Gogs-nownes, like a lusty Inuentus,
In a cloake to thy heele, and a hat like a pent-house.
Thy breeches of three fingers, and thy doublet all belly,
With a Wench that shall feede thee, with cock-stones and gelly.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Is it not excellent, Chiefe? how nimble he is!

SP.SPEAKER: INI.
SP.L: Child of hell, this is nothing! I will fetch thee a leape
From the top of Pauls-steeple, to the Standard in Cheepe:
And lead thee a daunce, through the streets without faile,
Like a needle of Spaine, with a thred at my tayle.
We will suruay the Suburbs, and make forth our sallyes,
Downe Petticoate-lane, and vp the Smock-allies,
To Shoreditch, Whitechappell, and so to Saint Kathernes.
To drinke with the Dutch there, and take forth their patternes:
From thence, wee will put in at Custome-house key there,
And see, how the Factors, and Prentizes play there,
False with their Masters; and gueld many a full packe,
To spend it in pies, at the Dagger, and the Woolsacke.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Braue, braue, Iniquity! will not this doe, Chiefe?

SP.SPEAKER: INI.
SP.L: Nay▪ boy, I wil bring thee to the Bawds, and the Roysters,
At Belins gate, feasting with claret-wine, and oysters,
From thence shoot the Bridge, childe, to the Cranes i'the Vintry,
And see, there the gimblets, how they make their entry!
Or, if thou hadst rather, to the Strand downe to all,
'Gainst the Lawyers come dabled from Westminster-hall
And marke how they cling, with their clyents together,
Like Iuie to Oake; so Veluet to Leather:
Ha, boy, I would shew thee.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Rare, rare!

SP.SPEAKER: DIV.
SP.L: Peace, dotard,
And thou more ignorant thing, that so admir'st.
Art thou the spirit thou seem'st? so poore? to choose
This, for a Vice, t'aduance the cause of Hell,
Now? as Vice stands this present yeere? Remember,
What number it is. Six hundred and sixteene.
Had it but beene fiue hundred, though some sixty
Aboue; that's fifty yeeres agone, and six,
(When euery great man had his Vice stand by him,
In his long coat, shaking his wooden dagger)
I could consent, that, then this your graue choice
Might haue done that, with his Lord Chiefe, the which
Most of his chamber can doe now. But Pug,
As the times are, who is it, will receiue you?
What company will you goe to? or whom mix with?
Where canst thou carry him? except to Tauernes?
To mount vp on a joynt-stoole, with a Iewes-trumpe,
To put downe Cokeley, and that must be to Citizens?
He ne're will be admitted, there, where Vennor comes.
Hee may perchance, in taile of a Sheriffes dinner,
Skip with a rime o'the Table, from New-nothing,
And take his Almaine-leape into a custard,
Shall make my Lad Maioresse, and her sisters,
Laugh all their hoods ouer their shoulders. But,
This is not that will doe, they are other things
That are receiu'd now vpon earth, for Vices;
Stranger, and newer: and chang'd euery houre.
They ride 'hem like their horses off their legges,
And here they come to Hell, whole legions of'hem,
Euery weeke tyr'd. Wee, still striue to breed,
And reare 'hem vp new ones; but they doe not stand,
When they come there: they turne 'hem on our hands.
And it is fear'd they haue a stud o'their owne
Will put downe ours. Both our breed, and trade
VVill suddenly decay, if we preuent not.
Vnlesse it be a Vice of quality,
Or fashion, now, they take none from vs. Car-men
Are got into the yellow starch, and Chimney-sweepers
To their tabacco, and strong-waters, Hum,
Meath, and Obarni. VVe must therefore ayme
At extraordinary subtill ones, now,
VVhen we doe send to keepe vs vp in credit.
Not old Iniquities. Get you e'ne backe, Sir,
To making of your rope of sand againe.
You are not for the manners, nor the times:
They haue their Vices, there, most like to Vertues;
You cannnot know 'hem, apart, by any difference:
They weare the same clothes, eate the same meate▪
Sleepe i'the selfe-same beds, ride i'those coaches.
Or very like, foure horses in a coach,
As the best men and women. Tissue gownes,
Garters and roses, fourescore pound a paire,
Embroydred stockings, cut-worke smocks, and shirts,
More certaine marks of lechery, now, and pride,
Then ere they were of true nobility!
But Pug, since you doe burne with such desire
To doe the Common-wealth of Hell some seruice▪
I am content, assuming of a body,
You goe to earth, and visit men, a day.
But you must take a body ready made, Pug,
I can create you none: nor shall you forme
Your selfe an aery one, but become subiect
To all impression of the flesh, you take,
So farre as humane frailty. So, this morning,
There is a handsome Cutpurse hang'd at Tiborne,
Whose spirit departed, you may enter his body:
For clothes imploy your credit, with the Hangman,
Or let our tribe of Brokers furnish you.
And, looke, how farre your subtilty can worke
Thorow those organs, with that body, spye
Amongst mankind, (you cannot there want vices,
And therefore the lesse need to carry 'hem wi'you)
But as you make your soone at nights relation,
And we shall find, it merits from the State,
You shall haue both trust from vs, and imployment.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Most gracious Chiefe!

SP.SPEAKER: DIV.
SP.L: Onely, thus more I bind you,
He shewes Fitz-dot∣trel to him, comming forth.To serue the first man that you meete; and him
I'le shew you, now: Obserue him. You' is hee,
You shall see, first, after your clothing. Follow him:
But once engag'd, there you must stay and fixe;
Not shift, vntill the midnights cocke doe crow.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Any conditions to be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: DIV.
SP.P: Away, then.

SP.L: I, they doe, now, name Bretnor, as before,
They talk'd of Gresham, and of Doctor Fore-man,
Francklin, and Fiske, and Sauory (he was in too)
But there's not one of these, that euer could
Yet shew a man the Diuell, in true sort.
They haue their christalls, I doe know, and rings,
And virgin parchment, and their dead-mens culls
Their rauens wings, their lights, and pentacles,
With characters; I ha' seene all these. But—
Would I might see the Diuell. I would giue
A hundred o'these pictures, to see him
Once out of picture. May I proue a cuckold,
(And that's the one maine mortall thing I feare)
If I beginne not, now, to thinke, the Painters
Haue onely made him. 'Slight, he would be seene,
One time or other else. He would not let
An ancient gentleman, of a good house,
As most are now in England, the Fitz-dottrel's,
Runne wilde, and call vpon him thus in vaine,
As I ha' done this twelue mone'th. If he be not,
At all, why, are there Coniurers? If they be not,
Why, are there lawes against 'hem? The best artists
Of Cambridge, Oxford, Middlesex, and London,
Essex, and Kent, I haue had in pay to raise him,
These fifty weekes, and yet h'appeares not. 'Sdeath,
I shall suspect, they, can make circles onely
Shortly, and know but his hard names. They doe say,
H'will meet a man (of himselfe) that has a mind to him.
If hee would so, I haue a minde and a halfe for him:
He should not be long absent. Pray thee, come
I long for thee. An' I were with child by him,
