SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Your halfe. You know, that Guilt-head must ha' twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: And what's your ring there? shall I ha' none o'that?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: O, thats to be giuen to a Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: Is't so?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: By that good light, it is.

SP.SPEAKER: EV.
SP.L: Come, gi'me
Ten pieces more, then.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: EV.
SP.L: For Guilt-head? Sir,
Do'you thinke, I'll 'low him any such share:

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: You must.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Must I? Doe you your musts, Sir, I'll doe mine,
You wi'not part with the whole, Sir? Will you? Goe too.
Gi' me ten pieces!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: By what law, doe you this?

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: E'n Lyon-law, Sir, I must roare else.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Good!

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: Yo' haue heard, how th'Asse made his diuisions, wisely?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: And, I am he: I thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: EV.
SP.P: Much good do you, Sr.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: I shall be rid o'this tyranny, one day?

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Not,
While you doe eate; and lie, about the towne, here;
And coozen i'your bullions; and I stand
Your name of credit, and compound your businesse;
Adiourne your beatings euery terme; and make
New parties for your proiects. I haue, now,
A pretty tasque, of it, to hold you in
W' your Lady Tayle-bush: but the toy will be,
How we shall both come off?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Leaue you your doubting.
And doe your portion, what's assign'd you: I
Neuer fail'd yet.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: With reference to your aydes?
You'll still be vnthankfull. Where shall I meete you, anon?
You ha' some feate to doe alone, now, I see;
You wish me gone, well, I will finde you out,
And bring you after to the audit.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: S'light!
There's Ingines share too, I had forgot! This raigne
Is too-too-vnsuportable! I must
Quit my selfe of this vassalage! Ingine! welcome.

SP.P: HOw goes the cry?

SP.SPEAKER: ING.
SP.P: Excellent well!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Wil't do?
VVhere's Robinson?

SP.SPEAKER: ING.
SP.L: Here is the Gentleman, Sir.
VVill vndertake t'himselfe. I haue acquainted him,

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: VVhy did you so?

SP.SPEAKER: ING.
SP.L: VVhy, Robinson would ha'told him,
You know. And hee's a pleasant wit! will hurt
Nothing you purpose. Then, he'is of opinion,
That Robinson might want audacity,
She being such a gallant. Now, hee has beene,
In Spaine, and knowes the fashions there; and can
Discourse; and being but mirth (hee saies) leaue much,
To his care:

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: But he is too tall!

SP.SPEAKER: ING.
SP.L: For that,
He has the brauest deuice!He excepts at his sta∣ture. (you'll loue him for't)
To say, he weares Cioppinos: and they doe so
In Spaine. And Robinson's as tall, as hee.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Is he so?

SP.SPEAKER: ING.
SP.P: Euery iot.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Nay, I had rather
To trust a Gentleman with it, o'the two.

SP.SPEAKER: ING.
SP.P: Pray you goe to him, then, Sir, and salute him.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Sir, my friend Ingine has acquainted you
With a strange businesse, here.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: A merry one, Sir.
The Duke of Drown'd-land, and his Dutchesse?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Yes, Sir.
Now, that the Coniurers ha' laid him by,
I ha' made bold, to borrow him a while;

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: With purpose, yet, to put him out I hope
To his best vse?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: For that small part,
That I am trusted with, put off your care:
I would not lose to doe it, for the mirth,
Will follow of it; and well, I haue a fancy.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Sir, that will make it well.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: You will report it so.
Where must I haue my dressing?

SP.SPEAKER: ING.
SP.P: At my house, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: You shall haue caution, Sir, for what he yeelds,
To six pence.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: You shall pardon me. I will share, Sir,
I' your sports, onely: nothing i'your purchase.
But you must furnish mee with complements,
To th' manner of Spaine; my coach, my guarda duenn'as;

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Ingine's your Pro'uedor. But, Sir, I must
(Now I'haue entred trust wi'you, thus farre)
Secure still i' your quality, acquaint you
With somewhat, beyond this. The place, design'd
To be the Scene, for this our mery matter,
Because it must haue countenance of women,
To draw discourse, and offer it, is here by,
At the Lady Taile-bushes.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: I know her, Sir,
And her Gentleman huisher.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Mr Ambler?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Sir, It shall be no shame to mee, to confesse
To you, that wee poore Gentlemen, that want acres,
Must for our needs, turne fooles vp, and plough Ladies
Sometimes, to try what glebe they ae: and this
Is no vnfruitefull piece. She, and I now,
Are on a proiect, for the fact, and venting
Of a new kinde of fucus (paint, for Ladies)
To serue the kingdome: wherein shee her selfe
Hath trauell'd, specially, by way of seruice
Vnto her sexe, and hopes to get the Monopoly,
As the reward, of her inuention.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: What is her end, in this?

SP.SPEAKER: EV.
SP.L: Merely ambition,
Sir, to grow great, and court it with the secret:
Though shee pretend some other. For, she's dealing,
Already, vpon caution for the shares,
And Mr. Ambler, is hee nam'd Examiner
For the ingredients; and the Register
Of what is vented; and shall keepe the Office.
Now, if shee breake with you, of this (as I
Must make the leading thred to your acquaintance,
That, how experience gotten i'your being
Abroad, will helpe our businesse) thinke of some
Pretty additions, but to keepe her floting:
It may be, shee will offer you a part,
Any strange names of—

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Sr, I haue my'instructions.
Is it not high time to be making ready?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Yes, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: ING.
SP.P: The foole's in sight, Dottrel.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Away, then.
REturn'd so soone?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Yes, here's the ring: I ha'seal'd.
But there's not so much gold in all the row, he saies—
Till' come fro' the Mint. 'Tis tane vp for the gamesters.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: There's a shop-shift! plague on'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: He do's sweare it.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: He'll sweare, and forsweare too, it is his trade,
You should not haue left him.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: S'lid, I can goe backe,
And beat him, yet.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: No, now let him alone.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I was so earnest, after the maine Businesse,
To haue this ring, gone.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: True, and 'tis time.
I haue learn'd, Sir, sin' you went, her Ladiship ats
With the Lady Tail bush, here, hard by.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: I'the lane here?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Yes, if you' had a seruant, now of presence,
Well cloth'd, and of an aëy voluble tongue,
Neither too bigge, or little for his mouth,
That could deliuer your wiues complement;
To send along withall.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I haue one Sir,
A very handsome, gentleman-like-fellow,
That I doe meane to make my Dutchesse Vsher—
I entertain'd him, but this morning, too:
I'll call him to you. The worst of him, is his name!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: She'll take no note of that, but of his message.Hee shewes him his Pug.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Diuell! How like you him, Sir. Pace, go a little.
Let's see you moue.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: He'll serue, Sr, giue it him:
And let him goe along with mee, I'll helpe
To present him, and it.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Looke, you doe sirah,
Discharge this well, as you expect your place.
Do'you heare, goe on, come off with all your honours.
I would faine see him, do it.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Trust him, with it;Giues him instructions.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Remember kissing of your hand, and answering
With the French-time, in flexure of your body.
I could now▪ so instruct him— and for his words—

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: I'll put them in his mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: O, but I haue 'hem
O'the very Academies.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Sir, you'll haue vse for 'hem,
Anon, your selfe, I warrant you: after dinner,
When you are call'd.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: S'light, that'll be iust play-time.He longs to .
It cannot be, I must not lose the play!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Sir, but you must, if she appoint to sit.
And, shee's president.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: S'lid, it is the Diuell!Because it is the Diuell.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: And, 'twere his Damme too, you must now apply
Your selfe, Sir, to this, wholly; or lose all.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: If I could but see a piece—

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Sr. Neuer think on't.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Come but to one act, and I did not care—
But to be seene to rise, and goe away,
To vex the Players, and to punish their Poet—
Kepe him in awe!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: But say, that he be one,
Wi'not be aw'd! but laugh at you. How then?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Then he shall pay for 'his dinner himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Perhaps,
He would doe that twice, rather then thanke you.
Come, get the Diuell out of your head, my Lord,
(I'll call you so in priuate still) and take
Your Lord ship i'your minde. You were, sweete Lord,He puts him in mind of his quarrell.
In take to bring a Businesse to the Office.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Why should no you, Sr, carry it o'your selfe,
Before the Office be vp? and shew the world,
You had no need of any mans direction;
In point, Sir, of sufficiency. I speake
Against a kinsman, but as one that tenders
Your graces good.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I thanke you; to proceed—

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: To Publications: ha▪ your Deed drawne presently.
And leaue a blancke to put in your Feoffes
One, two, or more, as you see cause—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I thank you
Heartily, I doe thanke you. Not a word more,
I pray you, as you loue mee. Let mee alone.
That I could not thinke o'this, as well, as hee?He is angry with him∣selfe.
O, I could beat my infinite blocke-head—!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Come, we must this way.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: How far is't.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Hard by here
Ouer the way. Now, to atchieue this ring,
He thikes how to coo∣zen the bea∣rer, of the ring.From this same fellow, that is to assure it;
Before hee giue it. Though my Spanish Lady,
Be a young Gentleman of meanes, and scorne
To share, as hee doth say, I doe not know
How such a toy may tempt his Lady-ship:
And therefore, I thinke best, it be assur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Sir, be the Ladies braue, wee goe vnto?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: O, yes.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: And shall I see 'hem, and speake to 'hem?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: What else? ha'you your false-beard about you? Traines.

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Questions his man.Yes,

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: And is this one of your double Cloakes?

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: The best of 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Be ready then. Sweet Pifall!
COme, I must busse—

SP.SPEAKER: PIT.
SP.P: Away.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: I'll set thee vp again.
Offers to kisse.Neuer feare that: canst thou get ne'r a bird?
No Thrushes hungry? Stay, till cold weather come,
I'll help thee to an Onsell, or, a Field-fare.
She runs in, in haste: he followes.Who's within, with Madame?

SP.SPEAKER: PIT.
SP.P: I'll tell you straight.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Please you stay here, a while Sir, I'le goe in.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: I doe so long to haue a little venery,
While I am in this body! I would tast
Pug leaps at Pitfall's comming in.Of euery sinne, a little, if it might be
After the māner of man! Sweet-heart!

SP.SPEAKER: PIT.
SP.P: What would you, Sr?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Nothing but fall in, to you, be your Black-bird,
My pretty pit (as the Gentleman said) your Throstle:
Lye tame, and taken with you; here'is gold!
To buy you so much new stuffes, from the shop,
Traine's in his false cloak, brings a false mes∣sage, and gets the ring. Mere-craft followes pre∣sently, and askes for it. Ent. Train's as himselfe againe.As I may take the old vp —

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.L: You must send, Sir.
The Gentleman the ring.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: There 'tis. Nay looke,
Will you be foolish, Pit,

SP.SPEAKER: PIT.
SP.P: This is strange rudenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Deare Pit.

SP.SPEAKER: PIT.
SP.P: I'll call, I sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Where are you, Sr?
Is your ring ready? Goe with me.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: I sent it you.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Me? When? by whom?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: A fellow here, e'en now,
Came for it i'your name.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: I sent none, sure.
My meaning euer was, you should deliuer it,
Your selfe: So was your Masters charge, you know.
What fellow was it, doe you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Here,
But now, he had it.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Saw you any? Traines?

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: The Gentleman saw him.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Enquire.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: I was so earnest vpon her, I mark'd not!The Diuell confessth himselfe co∣zen'd.
My diuellish Chiefe has put mee here in flesh,
To shame mee! This dull body I am in,
I perceiue nothing with! I offer at nothing,
That will succeed!

SP.SPEAKER: TRA.
SP.P: Sir, she saw none, she saies.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Satan himselfe, has tane a shape t'abuse me.
It could not be else!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: This is aboue strange!Mere-craft accuseth him of negli∣gence.
That you should be so retchlesse. What'll you do, Sir?
How will you answer this, when you are question'd?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Run from my flesh, if I could▪ put off mankind!
This's such a scorne! and will be a new exercise,
For my Arch-Duke! Woe to the seuerall cudgells,
Must suffer, on this backe! Can you no succours? Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Alas! the vse of it is so present,

SP.SPEAKER: PVG
SP.L: I aske,He asketh ayde.
Sir, credit for another, but till to morrow?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: There is not so much time, Sir. But how euer,
The Lady is a noble Lady, and will
(To saue a Gentleman from check) be intreated
To say, she ha's receiu'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Do you thinke so?Mere-craft promiseth faintly, yet comforts him.
Will shee be won?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: No doubt, to such an office,
It will be a Lady's brauery, and her pride.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: And not be knowne on't after, vnto him?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: That were a treachery! Vpon my word,
Be confident. Returne vnto your master,
My Lady President sits this after-noone,
Ha'stan the ring, commends her seruices
nto your Lady-Dutchesse. You may say
She's a ciuill Lady, and do's giue her
All her respects, already: Bad you, tell her
She liues, but to receiue her wish'd commandements,
And haue the honor here to kisse her hands:
For which shee'll stay this houre yet. Hasten you
Your Prince, away.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: And Sir,The Diuel is doubtfull. you will take care
Th'excuse be perfect?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: You confesse your feares.
Too much.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: The shame is more, I'll quit you of either.

SP.L: A Pox vpo' referring to Commissioners,
I'had rather heare that it were past the seales:
Your Courtiers moue so Snaile-like i'your Businesse.
Wuld I had not begun wi'you.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: We must moue,
Madame, in order, by degrees: not iump.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Why, there was Sr. Iohn Monie-man could iump
A Businesse quickely.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: True, hee had great friends,
But, because some, sweete Madame, can leape ditches,
Wee must not all shunne to goe ouer bridges.
The harder parts, I make account are done:
He flatters her.Now, 'tis referr'd. You are infinitly bound
Vnto the Ladies, they ha' so cri'd it vp!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Doe they like it then?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: They ha' sent the Spanish-Lady,
To gratulate with you—

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: I must send 'hem thankes
And some remembrances.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: That you must, and visit 'hem.
Where's Ambler?

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Lost, to day, we cannot heare of him.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Not Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: No in good faith. They say he lay not
At home, to night. And here has fall'n a Businesse
Betweene your Cousin, and Master Manly, has
Vnquieted vs all.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: So I heare, Madame.
Pray you how was it?

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Troth, it but appeares
Ill o'your Kinsmans part. You may haue heard,
That Manly is a sutor to me, I doubt not:

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: I guess'd it, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: And it seemes, he trusted
Your Cousin to let fall some faire reports
Of him vnto mee.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Which he did!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: So farre
From it, as hee came in, and tooke him rayling
Against him.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: How! And what said Manly to him?

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Inough, I doe assure you: and with that scorne
Of him, and the iniury, as I doe wonder
How Euerill bore it! But that guilt vndoe's
Many mens valors

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Here comes Manly.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: Madame,Manly of∣fer to be gone.
I'll take my leaue—

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: You sha'not goe, i'faith.
I'll ha' you stay, and see this Spanish miracle,
Of our English Ladie.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: Let me pray your Ladiship,
Lay your commands on me, some other time.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Now, I protest: and I will haue all piec'd,
And friends againe.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: It will be but ill solder'd▪

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: You are too much affected with it.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: I cannot
Madame, but thinke on't for th'iniustice.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Sir,
His kinsman here is sorry.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Not I, Madam,
I am no kin to him, wee but call Cousins,Mere-craft denies him.
And if wee were, Sir, I haue no relation
Vnto his crimes.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: You are not vrged with 'hem.
I can accuse, Sir, none but mine owne iudgement,
For though it were his crime, so to betray mee:
I'am sure, 'twas more mine owne, at all to trust him.
But he, therein, did vse but his old manners,
And sauour strongly what hee was before.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Come, he will change!

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: Faith, I must neuer think it.
Nor were it reason in mee to expect
That for my sake, hee should put off a nature
Hee suck'd in with his milke. It may be Madam,
Deceiuing trust, is all he has to trust to:
If o, I shall be loath, that any hope
Of mine, should bate him of his meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Yo'are sharp, Sir.
This act may make him honest!

SP.SPEAKER: MAN
SP.L: If he were
To be made honest, by an act of Parliament,
I should not alter, i'my faith of him.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Eyther-side!
Welcome, deare Either-side! how hast thou done, good wench?She spies the Lady Ey∣ther-side.
Thou hast beene a stranger! I ha' not seene thee, this weeke.

SP.P: EVer your seruant, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Where hast'hou beene?
I did so long to see thee.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: Visiting, and so tyr'd!
I protest, Madame, 'tis a monstrous trouble!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: And so it is. I sweare I must to morrow,
Beginne my visits (would they were ouer) at Court.
It tortures me, to thinke on'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: I doe heare
You ha' cause, Madam, your sute goes on.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Who told thee?

SP.SPEAKER: EYT.
SP.P: One, that can tell: Mr. Eyther-side.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: O, thy husband!
Yes faith, there's life in't, now: It is referr'd.
If wee once see it vnder the seales, wench, then,
Haue with 'hem for the great Carroch, sixe horses,
And the two Coach-men, with my Ambler, bare,
And my three women: wee will liue, i'faith,
The examples o'the towne, and gouerne it.
I'le lead the fashion still.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: You doe that, now,
Sweet Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: O, but then, I'll euery day
Bring vp some new deuice. Thou and I, Either-side,
Will first be in it, I will giue it thee;
And they shall follow vs. Thou shalt, I sweare,
Weare euery moneth a new gowne, out of it.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Thanke you good Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Pray thee call mee Taile-bush
As I thee, Either-side; I not loue this, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: EYT.
SP.L: Then I protest to you, Taile-bush, I am glad
Your Businesse so succeeds.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Thanke thee, good Eyther-side.

SP.SPEAKER: EYT.
SP.L: But Master Either-side tells me, that he likes
Your other Businesse better.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Which?

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: O'the Tooth-picks.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: I neuer heard on't.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Aske Mr. Mere craft.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Madame? H'is one, in a word, I'll trust his malice,
With any mans credit, I would haue abus'd!

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: Mere-craft hath whis∣per'd with while.Sir, if you thinke you doe please mee, in this,
You are deceiu'd!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: No, but because my Lady,
Nam'd him my kinsman; I would satisfie you,
What I thinke of him: and pray you, vpon it
To iudge mee!

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: So I doe: that ill mens friendship,
Is as vnfaithfull, as themselues.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Doe you heare?
Ha'you a Businesse about Tooth-picks?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Yes, Madame.
Did I ne'r tell't you? I meant to haue offer'd it
Your Lady-ship▪ on the perfecting the pattent.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: How is't!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: For seruing the whole state with Tooth-picks;The Tooth-picks.
(Somewhat an intricate Businesse to discourse) but—
I shew, how much the Subiect is abus'd,
First, in that one commodity? then what diseases,
And putrefactions in the gummes are bred,
By those are made' of' adultrate, and false wood?
My plot, for reformation of these, followes.
To haue all Tooth-picks, brought vnto an office,
There seal'd; and such as counterfait 'hem▪ mulcted.
And last, for venting 'hem to haue a booke
Printed, to teach their vse, which euery childe
Shall haue throughout the kingdome, that can read,
And learne to picke his teeth by. Which beginning
Earely to practice, with some other rules,
Of neuer sleeping with the mouth open, chwing
Some graines of masticke,Traines his man whis∣pers him. will preserue the breath
Pure, and so free from tayn!— ha'what is't? sai'st thou?

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Good faith, it sounds a very pretty Bus'nesse!

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: So Mr Either-side saies, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: The Lady is come.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Is she? Good, waite vpon her in. My Ambler
Was neuer so ill absent. Either-side,
How doe I looke to day? Am I not drest,She lookes in her glasse
Spruntly?

SP.SPEAKER: IT.
SP.P: Yes, verily, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Pox o' Madame,
Will you not leaue that?

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Yes, good Taile-bush.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: So?
Sounds not that better? What vile Fucus is this,
Thou hast got on?

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: 'Tis Pearle.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Pearle? Oyster-shells:
As I breath, Either-side, I know't. Here comes
(They say) a wonder, sirrah, has beene in Spaine!
Will teach vs all! shee's sent to mee, from Court.
To gratulate with mee! Pr'y thee, let's obserue her,
What faults she has, that wee may laugh at 'hem,
When she is gone,

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: That we will heartily, Tail-bush.Wittipol enters.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: O, mee! the very Infanta of the Giants!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Here is a noble Lady, Madame, come,
Wittipol i drest like a Spanish Lady. Excuses him selfe for not kissing.From your great friends, at Court, to see your Ladi-ship:
And haue the honour of your acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Sir.
She do's vs honour.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Pray you, say to her Ladiship,
It is the manner of Spaine, to imbrace onely,
Neuer to kisse. She will excuse the custome!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Your vse of it is law. Please you, sweete, Madame,
To take a seate.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Yes, Madame. I' haue had
The fauour, through a world of faire report
o know your vertues, Madame; and in that
Name, haue desir'd the happinesse of presenting
My seruice to your Ladiship!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Your loue, Madame,
I must not owne it else.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Both are due, Madame,
To your great vndertakings.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Great? In troth, Madame,
They are my friends, that thinke 'hem any thing:
f I can doe my sexe (by 'hem) any seruice,
I'haue my ends, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: And they are noble ones,
That make a multitude beholden, Madame▪
The common-wealth of Ladies, must acknowledge from you.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Except some enuious, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Yo'are right in that, Madame,
Of which race, I encountred some but lately.
ho ('t seemes) haue studyed reasons to discredit
Your businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: How▪ sweet Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Nay, the parties
Wi'not be worth your pause— Most ruinous things, Madame,
That haue put off all hope of being recouer'd
To a degree of handsomenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: But their reasons, Madame?
I would faine heare.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Some Madame, I remember.
They say, that painting quite destroyes the face—

SP.SPEAKER: ET.
SP.P: O, that's an old one, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: There are new ones, too.
Corrupts the breath; hath left so little sweetnesse
In kissing, as 'tis now vs'd, but for fashion:
And shortly will be taken for a punishment.
Decayes the fore-teeth, that should guard the tongue;
And suffers that runne riot euer-lasting!
And (which is worse) some Ladies when they meete
Manly be∣gins to know him.Cannot be merry, and laugh, but they doe spit
In one anothers faces!

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: I should know
This voyce, and face too:

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: Then they say, 'tis dangerous
To all the falne, yet well dispos'd Mad-dames,
That are industrious, and desire to earne
Their liuing with their sweate! For any distemper
Of heat, and motion, may displace the colours;
And if the paint once runne about their faces,
Twenty to one, they will appeare so ill-fauour'd,
Their seruants run away, too, and leaue the pleasure
Imperfect, and the reckoning als' vnpay'd.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Pox, these are Poets reasons.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Some old Lady
That keepes a Poet, has deuis'd these scandales.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: Faith we must haue the Poets banish'd, Madame,
As Master Either-side saies.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Master Fitz dottrel?
And his wife: where? Madame, the Duke of Drown'd-land,
That will be shortly.

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.P: Is this my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: The same.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. IIIJ. SCENE. IV.
DIV2.STAGE: FITZ-DOTTREL. Mistresse FITZ-DOT∣TRELL. PVG. to them.

SP.P: YOur seruant, Madame!

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: How now? Friend? offended,
That I haue found your haunt here?

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: No,Wittipol whispers with Man∣ly. but wondring
At your strange fashion'd venture, hither.

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: It is
To shew you what they are, you so pursue.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: I thinke't will proue a med'cine against marriage;
To know their manners.

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.P: Stay, and profit then.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: The Lady, Madame, whose Prince has brought her, here,
To be instructed.

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.P: Please you sit with vs, Lady.Hee presents Mistresse Fitz-dot∣trel.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: That's Lady-President.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: A goodly woman!
I cannot see the ring, though.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Sir, she has it.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: But, Madame, these are very feeble reasons!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: So I vrg'd Madame, that the new complexion,
Now to come forth, in name o'your Ladiship's fucus,
Had no ingredient—

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: But I durst eate, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: So do they, in Spaine.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Sweet Madam be so liberall,
To giue vs some o'your Spanish Fucuses!

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.P: They are infinit, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: So I heare, they haue
VVater of Gourdes, of Radish, the white Beanes,
Flowers of Glasse, of Thistles, Rose-marine.
Raw Honey, Mustard-seed, and Bread dough-bak'd,
The crums o'bread, Goats-milke, and whites of Egges,
Campheere, and Lilly-roots, the fat of Swannes,
Marrow of Veale, white Pidgeons, and pine-kernells,
The seedes of Nettles, perse'line, and hares gall.
Limons, thin-skind—

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: How, her Ladiship has studied
Al excellent things!

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: But ordinary, Madame.
No, the true rarities, are th'Aluagada,
And Argentaa of Queene Isabella!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: I, what are their ingredients, gentle Madame?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Your Allum Scagliola, or Pol-dipedra;
And Zuccarino; Turpentine of Abezzo.
VVash'd in nine waters: Soda di leuante,
Or your Ferne ashes; Beniamin di gotta;
Grasso di serpe; Porcelletto marino;
Oyles of Lentisco; Zucche Mugia; make
The admirable Vernish for the face,
Giues the right luster; but two drops rub'd on
VVih a piece of scarlet, makes a Lady of sixty
Looke at sixteen. But, aboue all, the water
Of the white Hen, of the Lady Estifanias!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: O, I, that same, good Madame, I haue heard of:
How is it done?

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: Madame, you take your Hen,
Plume it, and skin it, cleanse it o'the inwards:
Then chop it, bones and all: adde to foure ounces
Of Carrnuacins, Pipitas, Sope of Cyprus,
Make the decoction, streine it. Then distill it,
And keepe it in your galley-pot well, glidder'd:
Three drops preserues from wrinkles, warts, spots, moles,
Blemish, or Sun-burnings, and keepes the skin
In decimo sexto, euer bright, and smooth,
As any looking-glasse; and indeed, is call'd
The Virgins milke for the face, Oglio reale;
A Ceruse, neyther cold or heat, will hurt;
And mixt with oyle of myrrhe, and the red Gilli-flower
Call'd Cataputia; and flowers of Rouistico;
Makes the best muta, or dye of the whole world.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Deare Madame, will you let vs be familiar?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Your Ladiships seruant.

SP.SPEAKER: MER▪
SP.P: How do you like her.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Admirable!
Hee is iea∣lous about his ring, and Mere-craft deli∣uers it.But, yet, I cannot see the ring.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MER▪
SP.L: I must
Deliuer it, or marre all. This foole's so iealous.
Madame— Sir, weare this ring, and pray you take knowledge,
'Twas sent you by his wife. And giue her thanks,
Doe not you dwindle, Sir, beare vp.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: I thanke you, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: But for the manner of Spaine! Sweet, Madame, let vs
Be bold, now we are in: Are all the Ladies,
There, i'the fashion?

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: None but Grandee's, Madame,
O' the clasp'd traine, which may be worne at length, too,
Or thus, vpon my arme.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: And doe they weare
Cioppino's all?

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.P: If they be drest in punto, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Guilt as those are? madame?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Of Goldsmiths work, madame▪
And set with diamants: and their Spanish pumps
Of perfum'd leather.

SP.SPEAKER: TAI.
SP.L: I should thinke it hard
To go in 'hem▪ madame.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: At the first, it is, madame.

SP.SPEAKER: TAI.
SP.P: Do you neuer fall in 'hem?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Neuer.

SP.SPEAKER: EI.
SP.L: I sweare, I should
Six times an houre.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: But you haue men at hand, still,
To helpe you, if you fall?

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: Onely one, madame,
The Guardo-duennas, such a little old man,
As this.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Alas! hee can doe nothing! this!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: I'll tell you, madame, I saw i'the Court of Spaine once,
A Lady fall i'the Kings sight, along.
And there shee lay, flat spred, as an Vmbrella,
Her hoope here crack'd; no man durst reach a hand
To helpe her, till the Guarda-duenn'as came,
VVho is the person onel'allow'd to touch
A Lady there: and he but by this finger.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Ha' they no seruants, madame, there? nor friends?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: An Escudero, or so madame, that wayts
Vpon 'hem in another Coach, at distance,
And when they walke, or daunce, holds by a hand-kercher,
Neuer presumes to touch 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: This's sciruy!
And a forc'd grauity! I doe not like it.
I like our owne much better.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: 'Tis more French,
And Courtly ours.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: And tasts more liberty.
VVe may haue our doozen of visiters, at once,
Make loue t'vs.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: And before our husbands?

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: Hus∣band?
As I am honest, Tayle-bush I doe thinke
If no body should loue mee, but my poore husband,
I should e'n hang my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Fortune forbid, wench:
So faire a necke should haue so foule a neck-lace,

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: 'Tis true, as I am handsome!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: I receiu'd, Lady,
A token from you, which I would not bee
Rude to refuse, being your first remembrance.

SP.SPEAKER: (FIT.
SP.P: O, I am satisfied now!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Do you see it, Sir.)

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: But since you come, to know me, neerer, Lady,
I'll begge the honour, you will weare it for mee,
It must be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. FIT.
SP.P: Sure I haue heard this tongue.Wittipol giues Mi∣stresse Fitz-dottrel. Mere-craft murmures, He is satisfi∣ed, now he sees it.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: What do you meane, Sr?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Would you ha'me merce∣nary?
We'll recompence it anon, in somewhat else,

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I doe not loue to be gull'd, though in a toy.
VVife, doe you heare? yo' are come into the Schole, wife,
VVhere you may learne, I doe perceiue it, any thing!
How to be fine, or faire, or great, or proud,
Or what you will, indeed, wife; heere 'tis taught.
And I am glad on't, that you may not say,
Another day, when honours come vpon you,
You wanted meanes. I ha' done my parts: beene,
He vpbraids her, with his Bill of costs.To day, at fifty pound charge, first, for a ring,
To get you entred. Then left my new Play,
To wait vpon you, here, to see't confirm'd.
That I may say, both to mine owne eyes, and eares,
Senses, you are my witnesse, sha' hath inioy'd
All helps that could be had, for loue, or money—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. FIT.
SP.P: To make a foole of her.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Wife, that's your malice,
The wickednesse o' you nature to interpret
Your husbands kindesse thus. But I'll not leaue;
Still to doe good, for your deprau'd affections:
Intend it. Bend this stubborne will; be great.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Good Madame, whom do they vse in messages?

SP.SPEAKER: WI.
SP.P: They cōmonly vse their slaues, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: TAI.
SP.L: And do's your Ladiship.
Thinke that so good, Madame?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: no, indeed, Madame; I,
Therein preferre the fashion of England farre,
Of your young delicate Page, or discreet Vsher,

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: And I goe with your Ladiship, in opinion,
Directly for your Gentleman-vsher,
There's not a finer Officer▪ goes on ground.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: If hee be made and broken to his place, once.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Nay, so I presuppose him.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: And they are fitter
Managers too, Sir, but I would haue 'hem call'd
Our Escudero's.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Good.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Say, I should send
To your Ladiship, who (I presume) has gather'd
All the deare secrets, to know how to make
Pastillos of the Dutchesse of Braganza,
Coquettas, Almoiauana's, Mantecada's,
Alcoreas, Mustaccioli; or say it were
The Peladore of Isabella, or balls
Against the itch, or aqua nanfa, or oyle
Of lessamine for gloues, of the Marquesse Muja;
Or for the head, and hayre: why, these are offices

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Fit for a gentleman, not a slaue. They onely
Might aske for your piueti, Spanish-cole,
To burne, and sweeten a roome: but the Arcana
Of Ladies Cabinets—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Should be else where trusted.
He enters himselfe with the Ladie'sYo'are much about the truth. Sweet honoured Ladies,
Let mee fall in wi'you. I'ha' my female wit,
As well as my male. And I doe know what sutes
A Lady of spirit, or a woman of fashion!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: And you would haue your wife such.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Yes, Madame, aërie,
Light; not to plaine dishonesty, I meane:
But, somewhat o'this side.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: I take you, Sir.
H'has reason Ladies. I'll not giue this rush
For any Lady, that cannot be honest
Within a thred.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Yes, Madame, and yet venter
As far for th'other, in her Fame—

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: As can be;
Coach it to Pimlico; daunce the Saraband;
Heare, and talke bawdy; laugh as loud, as a larum;
Squeake, spring, do any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: In young company, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Or afore gallants. If they be braue, or Lords,
A woman is ingag'd.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I say so, Ladies,
It is ciuility to deny vs nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: You talke of a Vniuersity! why,The Diuell admires him. Hell is
A Grammar-schoole to this!

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: But then,
Shee must not lose a looke on stuffes, or cloth, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Nor no course fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: She must be guided, Madame
By the clothes he weares, and company he is in;
Whom to salute, how farre—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I ha' told her this.
And how that bawry too, vpo' the point,
Is (in it selfe) as ciuill a discourse—

SP.SPEAKER: WIT▪
SP.P: As any other affayre of flesh, what euer.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: But shee will ne'r be capable, shee is not
So much as comming, Madame; I know not how
She loes all her opportunities
With hoping to be forc'd. I'haue entertain'd
A gentleman, a younger brother, here,
Whom I would faine breed vp, her Escudero,He shews his Pug.
Against some expectation's that I haue,
And she'll not countenance him.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: What's his name?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Diuel, o' Darbi-shire.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Blesse vs from him!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Diuell?
Call him De uile, sweet Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. FI
SP.P: What you please, Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: De-uile's a prettier name!

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: And sounds, me thinks,
As it came in with the Conquerour—

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: Ouer smocks!
What things they are? That nature should be at leasure
Euer to make 'hem! my woing is at an end.Manly goes out with in∣dignation.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: What can he do?

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Let's heare him.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Can he manage?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Please you to try him, Ladies. Stand forth, Diuell.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Was all this but the preface to my torment?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Come, let their Ladiships see your honours.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: O,
Hee makes a wicked leg.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: As euer I saw!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Fit for a Diuell.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Good Madame, call him De-uile.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: De-uile,They begin their Cate∣chisme. what property is there most required
I' your conceit, now, in the Escudero?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Why doe you not speake?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: A setled discreet pase, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: I thinke, a barren head, Sir, Mountaine-like,
To be expos'd to the cruelty of weathers—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I, for his Valley is beneath the waste, Madame,
And to be fruitfull there, it is sufficient.
Dulnesse vpon you! Could not you hit this?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Good Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: He then had had no barren head.He strikes him.
You daw him too much, in troth, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I must walke
With the French sticke, like an old vierger for you,The Diuell prayes.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: O, Chiefe, call mee to Hell againe, and free mee.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Do you murmur now?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Not I, Sr.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: What do you take
M•. Deuile, the height of your employment,
In the true perfect Escudero?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: When?
What doe you answer?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: To be able, Madame,
First to enquire, then report the working,
Of any Ladies physicke, in sweete phrase,

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Yes, that's an act of elegance, and importance.
But what aboue?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: O, that I had a goad for him.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: To find out a good Corne-cutter.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Out on him!

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Most barbarous!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Why did you doe this, now?
Of purpose to discredit me? you damn'd Diuell.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Sure, if I be not yet, I shall be. All
My daies in Hell, were holy-daies to this!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: 'Tis labour lost, Madame?

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: H'is a dull fellow
Of no capacity!

SP.SPEAKER: TAI
SP.L: Of no discourse!
O, if my Ambler had beene here!

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: I, Madame;
You talke of a man, where is there such another?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Mr. Deuile, put case, one of my Ladies, heere,
Had a fine brach: and would imploy you forth
To treate 'bout a conuenient match for her.
What would you obserue?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: The color, and the size, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: And nothing else?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: The Moon, you calfe, the Moone!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: I, and the Signe.

SP.SPEAKER: TAI.
SP.P: Yes, and receits for pronenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Then when the Puppies came, what would you doe?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Get their natiuities cast!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: This's wel. What more?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Consult the Almanack-man which would be least?
Which cleaneliest?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: And which silentest? This's wel, madame!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: And while she were with puppy?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Walke her out,
And ayre her euery morning!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Very good!
And be industrious to kill her fleas?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Yes!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: He will make a pretty proficient.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Who,
Comming from Hell, could looke for such Catechising?
The Diuell is an Asse. I doe acknowledge it.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Fitz-dot∣trel admires Wittipol.The top of woman! All her sexe in abstract!
I loue her, to each syllable, falls from her.

SP.SPEAKER: TAI.
SP.L: Good madame giue me leaue to goe aside with him!
And try him a little!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Do, and I'll with-draw, Madame,
The Diuell praies again.VVith this faire Lady: read to her, the while.

SP.SPEAKER: TAI.
SP.P: Come, Sr.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Deare Chiefe, relieue me, or I perish.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Lady, we'll follow. You are not iealous Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT
SP.L: He giues his wife to him, taking him to be a La∣dy.O, madame! you shall see. Stay wife, behold,
I giue her vp heere, absolutely, to you,
She is your owne. Do with her what you will!
Melt, cast, and forme her as you shall thinke good!
Set any stamp on! I'll receiue her from you
As a new thing, by your owne standard!

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.P: Well, Sir!

SP.L: BVt what ha' you done i'your Dependance, since?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: O, it goes on, I met your Cousin, the Master—

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: You did not acquaint him, Sr?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Faith, but I did, Sr.
And vpon better thought, not without reason!
He being chiefe Officer, might ha'tane it ill, else,
As a Contempt against his Place, and that
In time Sir, ha'drawne on another Dependance.
No, I did finde him in good termes, and ready
To doe me any seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: So he said, to you?
But Sr, you do not know him.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: VVhy, I presum'd
Because this bus'nesse of my wiues, requir'd mee,
I could not ha' done better: And hee told
Me, that he would goe presently to your Councell,
A Knight, here, i'the Lane—

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Yes, Iustice Either-side.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT:
SP.L: And get the Feoffment drawne, with a letter of Atturney,
For liuerie and seisen!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: That I knowe's the course.
But Sir, you meane not to make him Feoffee?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Nay, that I'll pause on!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: How now little Pit-fall.

SP.SPEAKER: PIT.
SP.L: Your Cousin Master Euer-ill, would come in—
But he would know if Master Manly were heere.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: No, tell him, if he were, I ha'made his peace!Mere-craft whispers a∣gainst him.
Hee's one, Sir, has no State, and a man knowes not,
How such a trust may tempt him.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: I conceiue you.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: Sr. this same deed is done here.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Pretty Plutarchus?
Art thou come with it? and has Sir Paul view'd it?

SP.SPEAKER: PLV.
SP.P: His hand is to the draught.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: VVill you step in, Sr.
And read it?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: I pray you a word wi'you.Eueril whi∣spers against Mere-craft.
Sir Paul Eitherside will'd mee gi' you caution,
VVhom you did make Feoffee: for 'tis the trust
O'your whole State: and though my Cousin heere
Be a worthy Gentleman, yet his valour has
At the tall board bin question'd; and we hold
Any man so impeach'd, of doubtfull honesty!
I will not iustifie this; but giue it you
To make your profit of it: if you vtter it,
I can forsweare it!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: I beleeue you, and thanke you, Sir.

SP.L: BE not afraid, sweet Lady: yo' are trusted
To loue, not violence here; I am no rauisher,
But one, whom you, by your faire trust againe,
May of a seruant make a most true friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. FI.
SP.L: And such a one I need, but not this way:
Sir, I confesse me to you, the meere manner
Of your attempting mee, this morning tooke mee,
And I did hold m'inuention, and my manners,
Were both engag'd, to giue it a requitall;
But not vnto your ends: my hope was then,
(Though interrrupted, ere it could be vtter'd)
That whom I found the Master of such language,
That braine and spirit, for such an enterprise,
Could not, but if those succours were demanded
To a right vse, employ them vertuously!
And make that profit of his noble parts,
Which they would yeeld. Sr, you haue now the ground,
To exercise them in: I am a woman;
That cannot speake more wretchednesse of my selfe,
Then you can read; match'd to a masse of folly;
That euery day makes haste to his owne ruine;
The wealthy portion, that I brought him, spent▪
And (through my friends neglect) no ioynture made me.
My fortunes standing in this precipice,
Tis Counsell that I want, and honest aides:
And in this name, I need you, for a friend!
Neuer in any other; for his ill,
Must not make me, Sr, worse.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: O friend! forsake not
Manly, con∣ceal'd this while, shews himselfe.The braue occasion, vertue offers you,
To keepe you innocent: I haue fear'd for both;
And watch'd you, to preuent the ill I fear'd.
But, since the weaker side hath so assur'd mee,
Let not the stronger fall by his owne vice,
Or be the lesse a friend, cause vertue needs him.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Vertue shall neuer aske my succours twice;
Most friend, most man; your Counsells are commands:
Lady, I can loue goodnes in you, more
Then I did Beauty; and doe here intitle
Your vertue, to the power, vpon a life
You shall engage in any fruitfull seruice,
Euen to forfeit.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Madame: Do you heare, Sir,
We haue another leg-strain'd, for this Dottrel.Mere-craft takes Witti∣pol aside, & moues a pro∣iect for him∣selfe.
He' ha's a quarrell to carry, and ha's caus'd
A deed of Feoffment, of his whole estate
To be drawne yonder; h'ha'st within: And you,
Onely, he meanes to make Feoffee. H'is falne
So desperatly enamour'd on you, and talkes
Most like a mad-man: you did neuer heare
A Phret so in loue with his owne fauour!
Now, you doe know, 'tis of no validity
In your name, as you stand; Therefore aduise him
To put in me. (h'is come here:) You shall share Sir.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. IV. SCENE. VIJ.
DIV2.STAGE: VVITTIPOL. Mistresse FITZ-DOTTREL. MANLY. MERE-CRAFT. FITZ-DOT∣TRELL. EVERILL. PLVTARCHVS.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Madame, I haue a suit to you; and afore-hand,
I doe bespeake you; you must not deny me,
I will be graunted.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Sir, I must know it, though.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: No Lady; you must not know it: yet, you must too.
For the trust of it, and the fame indeed,
Which else were lost me. I would vse your name,
But in a Feoffment: make my whole estate
Ouer vnto you: a trifle, a thing of nothing,
Some eighteene hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.L: Alas! I vnderstand not
Those things Sir. I am a woman, and most loath,
To embarque my selfe—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: You will not slight me, Madame?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Nor you'll not quarrell me?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: No, sweet Madame, I haue
Already a dependance; for which cause
I doe this: let me put you in, deare Madame,
I may be fairely kill'd.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: You haue your friends, Sir,Hee hopes to be the man.
About you here, for choice.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: She tells you right, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Death, if she doe, what do I care for that?
Say, I would haue her tell me wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Why, Sir,
If for the trust, you'll let me haue the honor
To name you one.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Nay, you do me the honor, Madame:
She designes Manly.Who is't?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: This Gentleman:

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: O, no, sweet Madame,
'is friend to him, with whom I ha' the dependance.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Who might he bee?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: One Wittipol: do you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: Alas Sir, he, a toy: This Gentleman
A friend to him? no more then I am Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: But will your Ladyship vndertake that, Madame?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Yes, and what else, for him, you will engage me.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: What is his name?

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.P: His name is Eustace Manly.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: VVhence do's he write himselfe?

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.P: of Middle-sex, Esquire.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Say nothing, Madame. Clerke, come hether
VVrite Eustace Manly, Squire o' Middle-sex.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: What ha' you done, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: Nam'd a gentleman,
That I'll be answerable for, to you, Sir.
Had I nam'd you, it might ha' beene suspected:
This way, 'tis safe.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Come Gentlemen, your hands,
Eueril ap∣plaudes it.For witnes.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: VVhat is this?

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: You ha' made Election
Of a most worthy Gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: VVould one of worth
Had spoke it: whence it comes, it is
Rather a shame to me, then a praise.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: Sir, I will giue you any Satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: Be silent then: "falshood commends not truth.

SP.SPEAKER: PLV.
SP.L: You do deliuer this, Sir, as your deed.
To th'vse of Mr. Manly?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Yes: and Sir—
VVhen did you see yong Wittipol? I am ready,
For processe now; Sir, this is Publication.
He shall heare from me, he would needes be courting
My wife, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: Yes: So witnesseth his Cloake there.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Fitz-dot∣trel is suspi∣cious of Manly still.Nay good Sir, —Madame, you did vndertake—

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.P: VVhat?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: That he was not Wittipols friend.

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: I heare
Sr. no confession of it.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: O she know's not;
Now I remember, Madame! This young Wittipol,
VVould ha' debauch'd my wife, and made me Cuckold,
Through a casement; he did fly her home
To mine owne window: but I think I sou't him,
And rauih'd her away, out of his pownces.
I ha' sworne to ha'him by the eares: I feare
The toy, wi' not do me right.

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: No? that were pitty!
VVhat right doe you aske, Sir? Here he is will do't you?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Wittipol discouers himselfe.Ha? Wittipol?

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: I Sir, no more Lady now,
Not Spaniard!

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: No indeed, 'tis Wittipol.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Am I the thing I fear'd?

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: A Cuckold? No Sir,
But you were late in possibility,
I'll tell you so much.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: But your wife's too vertuous!

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: VVee'll see her Sir, at home, and leaue you here,
To be made Duke o' Shore-ditch with a proiect.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Theeues, rauishers.

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: Crie but another note, Sir,
I'll marre the tune, o' your pipe!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Gi'me my deed, then.He would haue his again.

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: Neither: that shall be kept for your wiues good,
VVho will know, better how to vse it.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Ha'
To feast you with my land?

SP.SPEAKER: VVIT.
SP.L: Sir, be you quiet,
Or I shall gag you, ere I goe, consult
Your Master of dependances; how to make this
A second businesse, you haue time Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT·
SP.L: Oh!
VVhat will the ghost of my wise Grandfather,VVitipol bfflees him, and goes out
My learned Father, with my worshipfull Mother,
Thinke of me now, that left me in this world
In state to be their Heire? that am become
A Cuckold, and an Asse, and my wiues Ward;
Likely to loose my land; ha' my throat cut:
All, by her practice!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Sir, we are all abus'd!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: And be so still! VVho hinders you, I pray you,
Let me alone, I would enioy my selfe,
And be the Duke o' Drown'd Land, you ha' made me.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Sir, we must play an after-game o' this

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: But I am not in case to be a Gam-ster:
I tell you once againe—

SP.SPEAKER: MER
SP.L: You must be rul'd
And take some counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Sir, I do hate counsell,
As I do hate my wife, my wicked wife!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: But we may thinke how to recouer all:
If you will act.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I will not think; nor act;
Nor yet recouer; do not talke to me?
I'll runne out o' my witts, rather then heare;
I will be what I am, Fabian Fitz-Dottrel,
Though all the world say nay to't.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Let's follow him.
BVt ha's my Lady mist me?

SP.SPEAKER: PIT.
SP.L: Beyond telling!
Here ha's been that infinity of strangers!
And then she would ha' had you, to ha' sampled you
VVith one within, that they are now a teaching;
And do's pretend to your ranck.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: Good fellow Pit-fall,
Tel Mr. Mere-craft, I intreat a word with him.
Pitfall goes out.This most vnlucky accident will goe neare
To be the losse o' my place; I am in doubt!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: VVith me? what say you Mr Ambler?

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: Sir,
I would beseech your worship stand betweene
Me, and my Ladies displeasure, for my absence.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: O, is that all? I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: I would tell you Sir
But how it happened.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Briefe, good Master Ambler,
Put your selfe to your rack: for I haue tasque
Mere-craft seemes full of businesse.Of more importance.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: Sir you'll laugh at me!
But (so is Truth) a very friend of mine,
Finding by conference with me, that I liu'd
Too chast for my complexion (and indeed
Too honest for my place, Sir) did aduise me
If I did loue my selfe (as that I do,
I must confesse)

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Spare your Parenthesis.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: To gi' my body a little euacuation—

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Well, and you went to a whore?

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: No, Sr. I durst not
(For feare it might arriue at some body's eare,
It should not) trust my selfe to a common house;
Ambler tels this with ex∣traordinary speed.But got the Gentlewoman to goe with me,
And carry her bedding to a Conduit-head,
Hard by the place toward Tyborne, which they call
My L. Majors Banqueting-house. Now Sir, This morning
Was Execution; and I ner'e dream't on't,
Till I heard the noise o' the people, and the horses;
And neither I▪ nor the poore Gentlewoman
Durst stirre, till all was done and past: so that
I' the Interim, we fell a sleepe againe.Hesiags

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Nay, if you fall, from your gallop, I am gone Sr.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: But, when I wak'd, to put on my cloathes, a sute,
I made new for the action, it was gone,
And all my money, with my purse, my seales,
My hard-wax, and my table-bookes, my studies,
And a fine new deuise, I had to carry
My pen, and inke, my ciuet, and my tooth-picks,
All vnder one. But, that which greiu'd me, was
The Gentlewomans shoes (with a paire of roses,
And garters, I had giuen her for the businesse)
So as that made vs stay, till it was darke.
For I was faine to lend her mine, and walke
In a rug, by her, barefoote, to Saint Giles'es.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: A kind of Irish penance! Is this all, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.P: To satisfie my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: I will promise you, Sr.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.P: I ha' told the true Disaster.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: I cannot stay wi'you
Sir, to condole; but gratulate your returne.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: An honest gentleman, but he's neuer at leisure
To be himselfe: He ha's such tides of businesse.
O, Call me home againe, deare Chiefe, and put me
To yoaking foxes, milking of Hee-goates,
Pounding of water in a morter, lauing
The sea dry with a nut-shell, gathering all
The leaues are falne this Autumne, drawing farts
Out of dead bodies, making ropes of sand,
Catching the windes together in a net,
Mustring of ants, and numbring atomes; all
That hell, and you thought exquisite torments, rather
Then stay me here, a thought more: I would sooner
Keepe fleas within a circle, and be accomptant
A thousand yeere, which of'hem and how far
Out leap'd the other, then endure a minute
Such as I haue within. There is no hell
To a Lady of fashion. All your tortures there
Ambler comes in, & suruayes himAre pastimes to it. 'T would be a refreshing
For me, to be i'the sire againe, from hence.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.P: This is my suite, and those the shoes and roses!

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Th' haue such impertinent vexations,
A generall Councell o' diuels could not hit—
Pug per∣ceiues it, and starts.Ha! This is hee, I tooke a sleepe with his Wench,
And borrow'd his cloathes. What might I doe to balke him?

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.P: Do you heare, Sr?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Answ. him but not to th'purpose

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.P: He answers quite from the purpose.What is your name, I pray you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Is't so late Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: I aske not o' the time, but of your name, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: I thanke you, Sir. Yes it dos hold Sir, certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: Hold, Sir? What holds? I must both hold, and talke to you
About these clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: A very pretty lace!
But the Taylor cossend me.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: No, I am cossend
By you! robb'd.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG·
SP.L: Why, when you please Sir, I am
For three peny Gleeke, your man

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: Pox o'your gleeke,
And three pence. Giue me an answere.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Sir,
My master is the best at it.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: Your master!
Who is your Master.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Let it be friday night.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.P: What should be then?

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Your best songs Thom. o' Be∣t'lem

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: I thinke, you are he. Do's he mocke me trow, from pur∣pose?
Or do ot I speake to him, what I meane?
Good Sir your name.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Only a couple a' Cocks Sir,
If we can get a Widgin, 'tis in season.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: For Scep∣ticks.He hopes to make on o' these Scipticks o' me
(I thinke I name 'hem right) and do's not fly me.
I wonder at that! 'tis a strange confidence!
I'll prooue another way, to draw his answer.
It is the easiest thing Sir, to be done.
As plaine, as fizzling: roule but wi' your eyes,
And foame at th'mouth. A little castle-soape
Will do't, to rub your lips: And then a nutshell,
With toe, and touch-wood in it to spit fire,
Did you ner'e read, Sir, little Darrels tricks,
With the boy o' Burton, and the 7. in Lancashire,
Sommers at Nottingham? All these do teach it.
And wee'll giue out, Sir, that your wife ha's bewitch'd you:They repaire their old plot

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: And practised with those two, as Sorcerers.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: And ga' you potions, by which meanes you were
Not Compos mentis, when you made your feoffment.
There's no recouery o' your state, but this:
This, Sir, will sting.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: And moue in a Court of equity.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: For, it is more then manifest, that this was
A plot o' your wiues, to get your land.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: I thinke it.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: Sir it appeares.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Nay, and my cossen has knowne
These gallants in these shapes.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: T' haue don strange things, Sir▪
One as the Lady, the other as the Squire.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: How, a mans honesty may be fool'd! I thought him
A very Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: So did I: renounce me else.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: But this way, Sir, you'll be reueng'd at height.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: Vpon 'hem all.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Yes faith, and since your Wife
Has runne the way of woman thus, e'en giue her —

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Lost by this hand, to me; dead to all ioyes
Of her deare Dottrell, I shall neuer pitty her:
That could, pitty her selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Princely resolu'd Sir,
And like your selfe still, in Potentià.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. V. SCENE. IV.
DIV2.STAGE: MERE-CRAFT, &c. to them. GVILT-HEAD. SLEDGE-PLVTARCHVS. SERIEANTS.

SP.P: GVilt-head what newes.?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: O Sir, my hundred peices:Fitz-dot∣trel askes for his money·
Let me ha' them yet.

SP.SPEAKER: GVI.
SP.L: Yes Sir, officers
Arrest him.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Me?

SP.SPEAKER: SER.
SP.P: I arrest you.

SP.SPEAKER: SLE.
SP.L: Keepe the peace,
I charge you gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Arrest me? Why?

SP.SPEAKER: GVI.
SP.L: For better security, Sir. My sonne Plutarchus
Assures me, y'are not worth a groat.

SP.SPEAKER: PLV.
SP.L: Pardon me, Father,
I said his worship had no foote of Land left:
And that I'll iustifie, for I writ the deed.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Ha' you these tricks i'the citty?

SP.SPEAKER: GVI.
SP.L: Yes, and more.
Arrest this gallant too, here, at my suite.

SP.SPEAKER: SLE.
SP.L: I, and at mine.Meaning Mere-craft He owes me for his lodging
Two yeere and a quarter.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Why M. Guilt-head, Land-Lord,
Thou art not mad, though th'art Constable
Puft vp with th'pride of the place? Do you heare, Sirs.
Haue I deseru'd this from you two? for all
My paines at Court, to get you each a patent

SP.SPEAKER: GVI.
SP.P: The Pro∣ject of forksFor what?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Vpo' my proiect o' the forkes,

SP.SPEAKER: SLE.
SP.P: Forkes? what be they?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: The laudable vse of forkes,
Brought into custome here, as they are in Italy,
To th'sparing o' Napkins. That, that should haue made
Your bellowes goe at the forge, as his at the fornace.
I ha' procur'd it, ha' the Signet for it,
Dealt with the Linnen-drapers, on my priuate,
By cause, I fear'd, they were the likelyest euer
To stirre against, to crosse it: for 'twill be
A mighty sauer of Linnen through the kingdome
(As that is one o' my grounds, and to spare washing)
Now, on you two, had I layd all the profits.
Guilt-had to haue the making of all those
O god and siluer, for the better personages;
And you, of those of Steele for the common sort.
And both by Pattent, I had brought you your seales in.

Sledge is brought a∣bout.
And Guilt-head comes.But now you haue preuented me, and I thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: SLE.
SP.P: Sir, I will bayle you, at mine owne ap-perill.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Nay choose.

SP.SPEAKER: PLV.
SP.P: Do you so too, good Father.

SP.SPEAKER: CVI.
SP.L: I like the fashion o' the proiect, well,
The forkes! It may be a lucky one! and is not
Intricate, as one would say, but fit for
Plaine heads, as ours, to deale in. Do you heare
Officers, we discharge you.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Why this shewes
A little good nature in you, I confesse,
But do not tempt your friends thus. Little Guilt-head,
Aduise your sire, great Guilt-head from these courses:
And, here, to trouble a great man in reuersion,
For a matter o' fifty on a false Alarme,
Away, it shewes not well. Let him get the pieces
And bring 'hem. Yo'll heare more else.
O Master Sledge, are you here? I ha' been to seeke you.
You are the Constable, they say. Here's one
That I do charge with Felony, for the suite
He weares, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Who? M. Fitz-Dottrels man?
Ware what you do, M. Ambler.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.L: Sir, these clothes
I'll sweare, are mine: and the shooes the gentlewomans
I told you of: and ha' him afore a Iustice,
I will.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: My master, Sir, will passe his word for me.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.P: O, can you speake to purpose now?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Not I,Fitz-dot∣trel dis∣claimes him.
If you be such a one Sir, I will leaue you
To your God fathers in Law. Let twelue men worke.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG
SP.P: Do you heare Sir, pray, in priuate.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: well, what say you?
Briefe, for I haue no time to loose▪

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: Truth is, Sir,
I am the very Diuell, and had leaue
To take this body, I am in, to serue you:
Which was a Cutpurses, and hang'd this Morning▪
And it is likewise true, I stole this suite
To clth me with. Bu Sir let me not goe
To prison for it. I haue hitherto
Lost time, done nothing; showne, indeed, no part▪
O' my Diuels nature. Now, I will so helpe
Your malice, 'gainst these parties: so aduance
The businesse, that you haue in hand of witchcraft,
An your possession, as my selfe were in you.
Teach you uch tricks, to make your belly swell,
And your eyes turne, to foame, to stare, to gnash
Your teeth together, and to beate your selfe,
Laugh loud, and faine six voices—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Out you Rogue!
You most infernall counterfeit wretch! Auaunt!
Do you thinke to gull me with your▪ Aesops Fables?
Here take him to you, I ha' no part in him.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Away, I do disclaime, I will not heare you.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: What said he to you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Like a lying raskallAnd sends him away.
Told me he was the Diuel.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: How! a good iest!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: And that he would teach me, such fine diuels tricks
For our new resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: O' pox on him,
'Twas excellent wisely done, Sir, not to trust him▪

SP.SPEAKER: MER
SP.L: Why, if he were the Diuel, we sha' not need him,
If you'll be rul'd. Goe throw your selfe on a bed, Sir,Mere-craft giues the in∣structions to him and the rest.
And faine you ill. Wee'll not be seene wi' you,
Till after, that you haue a fit: and all
Confirm'd within. Keepe you with the two Ladies
And perswade them. I'll to Iustice Either-side,
And possesse him with all. Traines shall seeke out Ingine,
And they two fill the towne with't, euery cable
Is to be veer'd. We must employ out all
Our emissaries now; Sir, I will send you
Bladders and Bellowes. Sir, be confident,
'Tis no hard thing t'out doe the Deuill in:
A Boy o' thirteene yeere old made him an Asse
But 'toher day.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Well, I'll beginne to practice,
And scape the imputation of being Cuckold,
By mine owne act.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: yo'are right.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Come, you ha' put
Your selfe to a simple coyle here, and your freinds,
By dealing with new Agents, in new plots.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: No more o' that, sweet cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: What had you
To doe with this same Wittipol, for a Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Question not tha: 'tis done.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: You had some straine
'Boue E la?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: I had indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: And, now, you crack for't.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Do not vpbraid me.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Come, you must be told on't;
You are so couetous, still, to embrace
More then you can, that you loose all.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: 'Tis right.
What would you more, then Guilty? Now, your succours.
HEre you are lodg'd, Sir, you must send your garnish,
Pug is brought to New-gate.If you'll be priuat.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: There it is, Sir, leaue me.
To New-gate, brought? How is the name of Deuill
Discredited in me! What a lost fiend
Shall I be, on returne? My Cheife will roare
n triumph, now, that I haue beene on earth,
A day, and done no noted thing, but brought
That body back here, was hang'd out this morning.
Enter Ini∣quity the Vice.Well! would it once were midnight, that I knew
My vtmost. I thinke Time be drunke, and sleepes;
He is so still, and moues not! I doe glory
Now i'my torment. Neither can I expect it,
I haue it with my fact.

SP.SPEAKER: INI.
SP.L: Child of hell, be thou merry:
Put a looke on, as round, boy, and red as a cherry.
Cast care at thy posternes; and firke i'thy fetters,
They are ornaments, Baby, haue graced thy betters:
Looke vpon me, and hearken. Our Cheife doth salute thee,
And least the coldyron should chance to confute thee,
H' hath sent thee, grant-paroll by me to stay longer
A moneth here on earth, against cold Child, or honger

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: How? longer here a moneth?

SP.SPEAKER: ING.
SP.L: Yes, boy, till the Session,
That so thou mayest haue a triumphall egression.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.P: In a cart, to be hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: ING.
SP.L: No, Child, in a Carre,
The charriot of Triumph, which most of them are.
And in the meane time, to be greazy, and bouzy,
And nasty, and filthy, and ragged and louzy,
With dam'n me, renounce me, and all the fine phrases;
That bring, vnto Tiborne, the plentifull gazes.

SP.SPEAKER: PVG.
SP.L: He is a Diuell! and may be our Cheife!
The great Superiour Diuell! for his malice:
Arch-diuel! I acknowledge him. He knew
What I would suffer, when he tie'd me vp thus
In a rogues body: and he has (I thanke him)
His tyrannous pleasure on me, to confine me
To the vnlucky carkasse of a Cutpurse,
Wherein I could do nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: DIV.
SP.L: Impudent fiend,
Stop thy lewd mouth.The great Deuill en∣ters, and vp∣braids him with all his dayes worke. Doest thou not shame and tremble
To lay thine owne dull damn'd defects vpon
An innocent case, there? Why thou heauy slaue!
The spirit, that did possesse that fresh before
Put more true life, in a finger, and a thumbe,
Then thou in the whole Masse. Yet thou rebell'st
And murmur'st? What one profer hast thou made,
Wicked inough, this day, that might be call'd
Worthy thine owne, much lesse the name that sent thee?
First, thou did'st helpe thy selfe into a beating
Promptly, and with t endangered'st too thy tongue:
A Diuell, and could not keepe a body intire
One day! That, for our credit. And to vindicate it,
Hinderd'st (for ought thou know'st) a deed of darknesse:
Which was an act of that egregious folly,
As no one, to'ard the Diuel, could ha' thought on.
This for your acting! but for suffering! why
Thou hast beene cheated on, with a false beard,
And a turn'd cloake. Faith, would your predecessour
The Cutpurse, thinke you, ha' been so? Out vpon thee,
The hurt th'hast don, to let men know their strength,
And that the'are able to out-doe a diuel
Put in a body, will for euer be
A scarre vpon our Name! whom hast thou dealt with,
Woman or man, this day, but haue out-gone thee
Some way, and most haue prou'd the better fiendes?
Yet, you would be imploy'd? Yes, hell shall make you
Prouinciall o' the heaters! or Bawd-ledger,
For this side o' the towne! No doubt you'll render
A rare accompt of things. Bane o' your itch,
And scratching for imployment. I'll ha' brimstone
To al lay it sure, and fire to sindge your nayles off,
But, that I would not such a damn'd dishonor
Sticke on our state, as that the diuell were hang'd;
And could not saue a body, that he tooke
From Tyborne, but it must come thither againe:Iniquity takes him on his back.
You should e'en ride. But, vp away with him—

SP.SPEAKER: INI.
SP.L: Mount, dearling of darkenesse, my shoulders are broad:
He that caries the fiend, is sure of his loade.
The Diuell was wont to carry away the euill;
But, now, the Euill out-carries the Diuell.

SP.P: O mee!

SP.SPEAKER: KEE.
SP.L: 1. What's this? 2. A ce of Iustice Hall
A great noise is heard to New∣gate, and the Kepers come out af∣frighted.Is broken downe. 3. Fough! what of brimstone
Is here? 4. The prisoner's dead, came in bt now▪

SP.SPEAKER: SHA
SP.P: Ha? where? 4. Look here.

SP.SPEAKER: KEE.
SP.L: S'lid, I shuld know his coun∣tenance!
It is Gill-Cut-purse, was hang'd out, this morning!

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.L: 'Tis he! 2. The Diuell, sure, has a hand in this!
3. What shall wee doe?

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.L: Carry the newes of it
Vnto the Sherifes. 1. And to the Iustices.
4. This strange! 3. And sauours of the Diuell, strongly!
2. I' ha' the sulphure of Hell-coale i'my nose.
1. Fough.

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.P: Carry him in. 1. Away. 2. How ranke it is!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. V. SCENE. VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir POVLE. MERE-CRAFT. EVER-ILL. TRAINES. PITFALL. FITZ-DOTTREL. {To them} VVITTIPOL-MANLY. Mistresse FITZ-DOT∣TREL. INGINE. To them} GVILT-HEAD. SLEDGE. to them} SHACKLES.

SP.L: THis was the notablest Conspiracy,
The Iustice comes out wondring, and the rest informing him.That ere I heard of.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Sir, They had giu'n him potions,
That did enamour him on the counterfeit Lady—

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Iust to the time o'deliuery o'the deed—

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: And then the witchcraft 'gan't' appeare, for streight
He fell into his fit.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Of rage at first, Sir,
Which since has so increased.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Good Sr. Poule, see him,
And punish the impostors.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: Therefore I come, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Let Mr Etherside alone, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: Do you heare?
Call in the Constable, I will haue him by:
H'is the Kings Officer! and some Cittizens,
Of credit! I'll discharge my conscience clearly.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, and send for his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: And the two Sor∣cerers,
By any meanes!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: I thought one a true Lady,
I should be sworne. So did you, Eyther-si?

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.P: Yes, by that light, would I might e'r stir else, Tailbush.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: And the other a ciuill Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: But▪ Madame,
You know what I told your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: I now see it:
I was prouiding of a banquet for 'hem.
After I had done instructing o'the fellow
Deuile, the Gentlemans man

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Who's found a thiefe, Madam.
And to haue rob'd your Vsher, Master Ambler,
This morning.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: I'l tell you more, anon.He beginnes his fit.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Gi me some garlicke, garlicke, garlicke, garlicke.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Harke the poore Gentleman, how he is tormented!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: My wife is a whore, I'll kisse her no more: and why?
Ma'st not thou be a Cuckold, as well as I?
Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: That is the Diuell speakes, and laughes in him.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: Do you thinke so, Sr.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: I discharge my conscience.The Iustice interpret all:

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: And is not the Diuell good company? Yes, wis.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: How he changes, Sir, his voyce!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: And a Cuckold is
Where ere hee put his head, with a a Waion,
If his hornes be forth, the Diuells companion!
Looke, looke, looke, else.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: How he foames!

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: And swells!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: O, me! what's that there, rises in his belly!

SP.SPEAKER: EIT.
SP.L: A strange thing! hold it downe:

SP.SPEAKER: TRA. PIT.
SP.P: We cannot, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: 'Tis too apparent this!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Wittipol, Wittipol.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: How now, what play ha' we here.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: What fine, new matters?Wittipol, and Manly▪ and Mistr. Fitz-dot∣trel enter.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: The Cockscomb, and the Couerlet.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: O strang impudēce!
That these should come to face their sinne!

SP.SPEAKER: EVE:
SP.L: And out-face
Iustice, they are the parties, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: Say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Did you marke, Sir, vpon their comming in,
How he call'd Wittipol.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: And neuer saw 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: I warrant you did I, let 'hem play a while.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Buz, buz, buz, buz.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.L: Lasse poore Gentleman!
How he is tortur'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. FI.
SP.L: Fie, Master Fitz-dottrel!
What doe you meane to counterfait thus?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT:
SP.L: O, ô,His wife goes to him.
Shee comes with a needle, and thrusts it in,
Shee pulls out that, and shee puts in a pinne,
And now, and now, I doe not know how, nor where,
But shee pricks mee heere, and shee pricks me there: ôh, ôh:

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: Woman forbeare.

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: What, Sr?

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: A practice soule
For one so faire:

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: Hath this, then, credit with you?

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: Do you beleeue in't?

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: Gentlemen, I'll discharge
My conscience: 'Tis a cleare conspiracy!
A darke, and diuellish practice! I detest it!

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.P: The Iustice sure will proue to be the merrier!

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: This is most strange, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: Come not to confront
Authority with insolence: I tell you,
I doe detest it. Here comes the Kings Constable,
And with him a right worshipfull Commoner;
My good friend, Master Guilt-head! I am glad
I can before such witnesses, professe
My conscience, and my detestation of it.
Horible! most vnaturall! Abominable!

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: Thy whis∣per him.You doe not tumble enough.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Wallow, gnash:

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: O, how he is vexed!

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: 'Tis too manifest.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: Giue him more soap to foame with, now lie still.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: And giue soape to act with.And act a little.

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: What do's he now, Sr.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: Shew
The taking of Tabacco, with which the Diuell
Is so delighted.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Hum!

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: And calls for Hum.
You takers of strong Waters, and Tabacco,
Marke this.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Yellow, yellow, yellow, yellow, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: That's Starch! the Diuells Idoll of that colour.
He ratifies it, clapping of his hands.
The proofes are pregnant.

SP.SPEAKER: GVI.
SP.P: How the Diuel can act!

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: He is the Master of Players! Master Guilt-head,
And Poets, too! you heard him talke in rime!
I had forgot to obserue it to you, ere while!

SP.SPEAKER: TAY.
SP.P: Sir Poule interrets Figm a lers game.See, he spits fire.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: O no, he plaies at Figgum,
The Diuell is the Author of wicked Figgum—

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: Why speake you not vnto him?

SP.SPEAKER: WIT.
SP.L: If I had
All innocence of man to be indanger'd,
And he could saue, or ruine it: I'ld not breath
A syllable in request, to such a fellow,
I'd rather fall.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: ô they whisper, they whisper, whisper. &c.
Wee shall haue more, of Diuells a score,
To come to dinner, in mee the sinner.

SP.SPEAKER: EYT.
SP.P: Alas, poore Gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: Put 'hem asunder.
Keepe 'hem one from the other.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: Are you phrenticke, Sir,
Or what graue dotage moues you, to take part
VVith so much villany? wee are not afraid
Either of law, or triall; let vs be
Examin'd what our ends were, what the meanes,
To worke by; and possibility of those meanes.
Doe not conclude against vs, ere you heare vs.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: I will not heare you, yet I will conclude
Out of the circumstances.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.P: VVill you so, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: Yes, they are palpable:

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: Not as your folly:

SP.SPEAKER: POV:
SP.L: I will discharge my conscience, and doe all
To the Meridian of Iustice:

SP.SPEAKER: GVI.
SP.L: You doe well, Sir:

SP.SPEAKER: FT.
SP.L: Prouide mee to eat, three or foure dishes o'good meat,
I'll feast them, and their traines, a Iustice head and braines
Shall be the first.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: The Diuell loues not Iustice,
There you may see.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: A spare-rib o' my wife,
