And a whores purt'nance! a Guilt-head whole.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: Be not you troubled, Sir, the Diuell speakes it.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Yes, wis, Knight, shite, Poule, Ioule, owle, foule, troule, boule.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: Crambe, another of the Diuell's games!

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.L: Speake, Sir, some Greeke, if you can. Is not the Iustice
A solemne gamester?

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: Peace.

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: Hee curses
In Greeke I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: Your Spanish, that I taught you.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Quebrémos el ojo de burlas,

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: How? your rest—
Let's breake his necke in iest, the Diuell saies,

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Di grátia, Signòr miose haúte denári fataméne parte.

SP.SPEAKER: MER.
SP.P: What, would the Diuell borrow money?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Ouy,
Ouy Monsieur, ùn pàuure Diable! Diablet in!

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: It is the diuell, by his seuerall languages.

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.P: Where's St. Poule Ether-side?

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.L: Here, what's the mat∣ter?Enter the Keeper of New-gate.

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.L: O! such an accident falne out at Newgate, Sir:
A great piece of the prison is ent downe!
The Diuell has beene there, Sir, in the body—
Of the young Cut-purse, was hang'd out this morning,
But, in new clothes, Sir, euery one of vs know him.
These things were found in his pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: AMB.
SP.P: Those are mine, Sr.

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.L: I thinke he was commited on your charge, Sir.
For a new felony

SP.SPEAKER: AMB▪
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.L: Hee's gone, Sir, now,
And left vs the dead body. But withall, Sir,
Such an infernall stincke, and steame behinde,
You cannot see St. Pulchars Steeple, yet.
They smell't as farre as Ware, as the wind lies,
By this time, sure.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Is this vpon your credit, friend?Fitz-dot∣trel leaues counterfai∣ting.

SP.SPEAKER: SHA.
SP.P: Sir, you may see, and satisfie your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Nay, then, 'tis time to leaue off counterfeiting.
Sir I am not bewitch'd, nor haue a Diuell:
No more then you. I doe defie him, I,
And did abuse you. These two Gentlemen
Put me vpon it. (I haue faith against him)
They taught me all my tricks. I will tell truth,
And shame the Feind. See, here, Sir, are my bellowes,
And my false belly, and my Mouse, and all
That should ha' come forth?

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: Sir, are not you asham'd
Now of your solemne, serious vanity?

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: I will make honorable amends to truth.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: And so will I. But these are Coozeners, still;
And ha' my land, as plotters, with my wife:
Who, though she be not a witch, is worse, a whore.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: Sir, you belie her. She is chaste, and vertuous,
And we are honest. I doe know no glory
A man should hope, by venting his owne follyes,
But you'll still be an Asse, in spight of prouidence.
Please you goe in, Sir, and heare truths, then iudge 'hem:
And make amends for your late rashnesse; when,
You shall but heare the paines and care was taken,
To saue this foole from ruine (his Grace of Drown'd land)

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: My land is drown'd indeed—

SP.SPEAKER: POV.
SP.P: Peace.

SP.SPEAKER: MAN.
SP.L: And how much
His modest, and too worthy wife hath suffer'd
By mis-construction, from him, you will blush,
First, for your owne beliefe, more for his actions!
His land is his: and neuer, by my friend,
Or by my selfe, meant to another vse,
But for her succours, who hath equall right.
If any other had worse counsells in't,
(I know I speake to those can apprehend mee)
Let 'hem repent 'hem, and be not detected.
It is not manly to take ioy, or pride
In humane errours (wee doe all ill things,
They doe 'hem worst that loue 'hem, and dwell there,
Till the plague comes) The few that haue the seeds
Of goodnesse left, will sooner make their way
To a true life, by shame, then punishment.

DIV1.HEAD: The Epilogue.
DIV1.L: THus, the Proiecter, here, is ouer-throwne.
But I haue now a Proiect of mine owne,
If it may passe: that no man would inuite
The Poet from vs, to sup forth to night,
If the play please. If it displeasant be,
We doe presume, that no man will: nor wee.

DIV1.P: THE STAPLE OF NEVVES. A COMEDIE ACTED IN THE YEARE, 1625. BY HIS MAIESTIES SERVANTS.

Q.L: Aut prodesse volunt, aut delectare poetae:
Aut simul & iucunda, & idonea dicere vitae

DIV1.P: LONDON, Printed by I. B. for ROBERT ALLOT, and are to be sold at the signe of the Beare, in Pauls Church-yard. 1631.

LIST.ITEM: PENI-BOY. the Sonne, the heire and Suiter.
CYMBAL. Master of the Staple, and prime Ieerer.
ALMANACH Doctor in Physick, and Ieerer.
PICKLOCK. Man o' law, and Emissary Westminster.
PYED-MANTLE. Pursiuant at armes, and Heraldet.
REGISTER. Of the Staple, or Office.
NATHANEEL. First Clerke of the Office.
THO: BARBR. Second Clerke of the Office.
BROKER. Secretary, and Gentleman vsher to her Grace.
LICK-FINGER. A Master Cooke, and parcell Poet.
FASHIONER. The Taylor of the times.

DIV1.HEAD: THE INDVCTION.
DIV1.STAGE: The PROLOGVE enters. After him, Gossip MIRTH. Gos. TATLE. Gos. EX∣PECTATION. and Gossip CENSVRE. 4. Gentlewomen LADY-like attyred.

P.HI: FOr your owne sake, not ours—

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: Come Gossip, be not asham'd. The Play is the Staple of Newes, and you are the Mistresse, and Lady of Tatle, let's ha' your opinion of it: Do you heare Gentleman? what are you? Gentleman-vsher to the Play? pray you helpe vs to some stooles here.

SP.SPEAKER: PROLOGVE.
SP.P: Where? o' the Stage, Ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: Yes, o' the Stage; wee are persons of quality, I assure you, and women of fashion; and come to see, and to be seene: My Gos∣sip Tatle here, and Gossip Expectation, and my Gossip Censure, and I am Mirth, the daughter of Christmas, and spirit of Shrouetide. They say, It's merry when Gossips meet, I hope your Play will be a merry one!

SP.SPEAKER: PROLOGVE
SP.P: Or you will make it such, Ladies. Bring a forme here, but what will the Noblemen thinke, or the graue Wits here, to see you seated on the bench thus?

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: Why, what should they thinke? but that they had Mothers, as we had, and those Mothers had Gossips (if their children were christned) as we are, and such as had a longing to see Playes, and sit vpon them, as wee doe, and arraigne both them, and their Poëts.

SP.SPEAKER: PROLOGVE.
SP.P: O! Is that your purpose? Why, Mrs. Mirth, and Ma∣dame Tatle, enioy your delights freely.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: Looke your Newes be new, and fresh, Mr. Prologue, and vntainted, I shall find them else, if they be stale, or flye-blowne, quickly!

SP.SPEAKER: PROLOGVE.
SP.P: Wee aske no fauour from you, onely wee would entreate of Madame Expectation—

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION.
SP.P: What, Mr. Prologue?

SP.SPEAKER: PROLOGVE.
SP.P: That your Ladi-ship would expect no more then you vnderstand.

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION.
SP.P: Sir, I can expect enough!

SP.SPEAKER: PROLOGVE.
SP.P: I feare too much, Lady, and teach others to do the like?

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION.
SP.P: I can doe that too, if I haue cause.

SP.SPEAKER: PROLOGVE.
SP.P: Cry you mercy, you neuer did wrong, but with iust cause. What's this, Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: Curiosity, my Lady Censure.

SP.SPEAKER: PROLOGVE.
SP.P: O Curiosity! you come to see, who weares the new sute to day? whose clothes are best penn'd, what euer the part be? which Actor has the best legge and foote? what King playes without cuffes? and his Queene without gloues? who rides post in stockings? and daunces in bootes?

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: Yes, and which amorous Prince makes loue in drinke, or doe's ouer-act prodigiously in beaten satten, and, hauing got the tricke on't, will be monstrous still, in despight of Counsell!

SP.SPEAKER: BOOK-HOLDER.
SP.P: The Tire∣men enter to mend the lights.Mend your lights, Gentlemen. Master Pro∣logue, beginne.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: Ay me!

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION,
SP.P: Who's that?

SP.SPEAKER: PROLOGVE.
SP.P: Nay, start not Ladies, these carry no fire-workes to fright you, but a Torch i' their hands, to giue light to the businesse. The truth is, there are a set of gamesters within, in trall of a thing call'd a Play, and would faine be deliuerd of it: and they haue intreated me to be their Man-Midwife, the Prologue; for they are like to haue a hard labour on't.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: Then the Poet has abus'd himselfe, like an Asse, as hee is.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: No, his Actors will abuse him enough, or I am deceiu'd. Yonder he is within (I was i' the Tiring-house a while to see the Actors drest) rowling himselfe vp and downe like a tun, i' the midst of 'hem, and spurges, neuer did vessel of wort, or wine worke so! His sweating put me in minde of a good Shrouing dish (and I beleeue would be taken vp for a seruice of state somewhere, an't were knowne) a stew'd Poet▪ He doth sit like an vnbrac'd Drum with one of his heads beaten out: For, that you must note, a Poet hath two heads, as a Drum has, one for making, the other repeating, and his repeating head is all to pieces: they may gather it vp i' the tiring-house; for hee hath torne the booke in a Poeticall fury, and put himselfe to silence in dead Sacke, which, were there no other vexa∣tion, were sufficient to make him the most miserable Embleme of patience.

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: The Prologue, peace.

DIV1.HEAD: THE PROLOGVE FOR THE STAGE.
DIV1.L: FOr your owne sakes, not his, he bad me say,
Would you were come to heare, not see a Play.
Though we his Actors must prouide for those,
Who are our guests, here, in the way of showes,
The maker hath not so; he'ld haue you wise,
Much ather by your eares, then by your eyes:
And prayes you'll not preiudge his Play for ill,
Because you marke it not, and sit not still;
But haue a longing to salute, or talke
With such a female, and from her to walke
With your discourse, to what is done, and where,
How, and by whom, in all the towne; but here.
Alas! what is it to his Scene, to know
How many Coaches in Hide-parke did show
Last spring, what fare to day at Medleyes was,
If Dunstan, or the Phoenix best wine has?
They are things—But yet, the Stage might stand as wel,
If it did neither heare these things, nor tell.
Great noble wits, be good vnto your selues,
And make a difference 'twixt Poetique elues,
And Poets: All that dable in the inke,
And defile quills, are not those few, can thinke,
Conceiue, expresse, and steere the soules of men,
As with a rudder, round thus, with their pen.
He must be one that can instruct your youth,
And keepe your Acme in the state of truth,
Must enterprize this worke, marke but his wayes,
What flight he makes, how new; And then he sayes,
If that not like you, that he sends to night,
'Tis you haue left to iudge, not hee to write▪

DIV1.HEAD: THE PROLOGVE FOR THE COVRT.
DIV1.L: A Worke not smelling of the Lampe, to night,
But fitted for your Maiesties disport,
And writ to the Meridian of your Court,
VVee bring; and hope it may produce delight:
The rather, being offered, as a Rite
To Schollers, that can iudge, and faire report
The sense they heare, aboue the vulgar sort
Of Nut-crackers, that onely come for sight.
Wherein, although our Title, Sir, be Newes.
Wee yet aduenture, here, to tell you none;
But shew you common follies, and so knowne,
That though they are not truths, th'innocent Muse
Hath made so like, as Phant'sie could them state,
Or Poetry, without scandall, imitate.

SP.L: GRamercie Letherleg: Get me the Spurrier,His Shooe∣maker has pull'd on a new payre of bootes; and hee walks in his Gowne, wastcoate, and trouses, expecting his Taylor.
And thou hast fitted me.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: I'll do't presently.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Look to me, wit, and look to my wit, Land,
That is, looke on me, and with all thine eyes,
Male, Female, yea, Hermaphroditicke eyes,
And those bring all your helpes, and perspicills,
To see me at best aduantage, and augment
My forme as I come forth, for I doe feele
I will be one, worth looking after, shortly.
Now, by and by, that's shortly. He rawes foorth his watch, and sets it on the Table. 't strikes! One, two,
Three, foure, fiue, six. Inough, inough, deare watch,
Thy pulse hath beate inough. Now sleepe, and rest;
Would thou couldst make the time to doe so too:
I'll winde thee vp no more. The houre is come
So long expected! There, there, He throws off his gowne drop my wardship,
My pupill age, and vassalage together.
And Liberty, come throw thy selfe about me,
In a rich suite, cloake, hat, and band, for now
I'le sue out no mans Liuery, but miny owne,
I stand on my owne feete, so much a yeere,
Right, round, and sound, the Lord of mine owne ground,
And (to ryme to it) threescore thousand Pound!
He goes to the doore, and lookes.Not come? Not yet? Taylor thou art a vermine,
Worse then the same thou prosecut'st, and prick'st
In subtill seame— (Go too, I say no more)
Thus to retard my longings: on the day
I doe write man, to beat thee. One and twenty,
Snce the clock strooke, compleat! and thou wilt feele it
Thou foolish Animall! I could pitty him,
(An' I were not heartily angry with him now)
For this one peece of folly he beares about him,
To dare to tempt the Furie of an heyre,
T' aboue two thousand a yeere; yet hope his custome!
Well, Mr. Fashioner, theres some must breake—
A head, for this your breaking. Are you come, Sir,

SP.P: GOd giue your worship ioy.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: What? of your staying?
And leauing me to stalke here in my trowses,
Like a tame Her'n-sew for you?

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: I but waited
Below, till the clocke strooke.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Why, if you had come
Before a quarter, would it so haue hurt you,
In reputation, to haue wayted here?

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: No, but your worship might haue pleaded nonage,
If you had got 'hem on, ere I could make
Iust Affidauit of the time.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: That iest
Has gain'd thy pardon, thou had'st liu'd, condemn'd
To thine owne hell else, neuer to haue wrought
Stitch more for me, or any Peniboy,
I could haue hindred thee: but now thou art mine.
For one and twenty yeeres, or for three liues,
Chuse which thou wilt, I'll make thee a Copy-holder,
He sayes his sute.And thy first Bill vnquestion'd. Helpe me on.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.P: Presently, Sir, I am bound vnto your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Thou shalt be, when I haue seal'd thee a Lease of my Cu∣stome.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.P: Your worps, Barbar is without.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IN.
SP.L: Who? Thom?
Come in Thom: set thy things vpon the Boord
And spread thy clothes, lay all forth in procinctu,
And tell's what newes?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: O Sir, a staple of newes!
Or the New Staple, which you please.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: An Office, Sir, a braue young Office set vp.
I had forgot to tell your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: For what?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: To enter all the Newes, Sir, o' the time,

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: And vent it as occasion serues! A place
Of huge commerce it will be!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Pray thee peace,
I cannot abide a talking Taylor: let Thom
(He's a Barber) by his place relate it,
What is't, an Office, Thom?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Newly erected
Here in the house, almost on the same floore,
Where all the newes of all sorts shall be brought,
And there be examin'd, and then registred,
And so be issu'd vnder the Seale of the Office,
As Staple Newes; no other newes be currant.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: 'Fore me, thou speak'st of a braue busines, Thom.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: Nay, if you knew the brain that hatch'd it Sr—

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I know thee wel inough: giue him a loaf, Thom—
Quiet his mouth, that Ouen will be venting else.
Proceed—

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: He tels you true Sr. Mr Cymbal,
Is Master of the Office, he proiected it,
Hee lies here i'the house: and the great roomes
He has taken for the Office, and set vp
His Deskes and Classes, Tables and his Shelues,

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: He's my Customer, and a Wit Sir, too.
But, h' has braue wits vnder him—

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Yes, foure Emissaries,

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Emissaries? stay, there's a fine new word, Thom!
'Pray God it signifie any thing, what are Emissaries?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Men imploy'd outward, that are sent abroad
To fetch in the commodity.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: From all regions
Where the best newes are made.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: Or vented forth.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.P: By way of exchange, or trade.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Nay, thou wilt speak—

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.P: My share Sr. there's enough for both.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Goe on then,Hee giues the Taylor leaue to talk.
Speake all thou canst: me thinkes, the ordinaries
Should helpe them much.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: Sir, they haue ordinaries,
And extraordinaries, as many changes,
And variations, as there are points i'the compasse.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: But the 4. Cardinall Quarters—

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I, those Thom—

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: The Court, Sir, Pauls, Exchange, and Westminster-hall.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Who is the Chiefe? which hath preceedencie?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: The gouernour o'the Staple, Master Cymball.
He is the Chiefe; and after him the Emissaries:
First Emissary Court, one Master Fitton,
He's a Ieerer too.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.P: A Wit.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Or halfe a Wit, some of them are Halfe-wits,
Two to a Wit, there are a set of 'hem.
Then Master Ambler, Emissary Paules,
A fine pac'd gentleman, as you shall see, walke
The middle Ile: And then my Froy Hans Buz,
A Dutch-man; he's Emissary Exhange.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.P: I had thought Mr. Burst the Marchant had had it.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: No,
He has a rupture, hee has sprung a leake,
Emissarie Westminster's vndispos'd of yet;
Then the Examiner, Register, and two Clerkes,
They mannage all at home, and sort, and file,
And seale the newes, and issue them.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Thom, deare Thom.
What may my meanes doe for thee, aske, and haue it,
I'd faine be doing some good. It is my birth-day.
And I'd doe it betimes, I feele a grudging
Of bounty, and I would not long lye fallow.
I pray thee thinke, and speake, or wish for something.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: I would I had but one o' the Clerkes places,
I'this Newes Office,.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Thou shalt haue it, Thom,
If siluer, or gold will fetch it; what's the rate?
At what is't set i'the Mercat?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: Fiftie pound, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: An't were a hundred, Thom, thou shalt not want it.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.P: The Taylor leapes, and embraceth him.O Noble Master!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: How now Aesops Asse!
Because I play with Thom, must I needes runne
Into your rude embraces? stand you still, Sir;
Clownes fawnings, are a horses salutations.
How do'st thou like my suite, Thom?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Mr Fashioner
Has hit your measures, Sir, h'has moulded you,
And made you, as they say.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: No, no, not I,
I am an Asse, old Aesops Asse.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Nay, Fashioner,
I can doe thee a good turne too, be not musty,
Though thou hast moulded me, as little Thom sayes,
He drawes out his poc∣kets.(I thinke thou hast put me in mouldy pockets.)

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: As good,
Right Spanish perfume, the Lady Estifania's,
They cost twelue pound a payre.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Thy bill will say so.
I pray thee tell me, Fashioner, what Authors
Thou read'st to helpe thy inuention? Italian prints?
Or Arras hangings? They are Taylors Libraries.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.P: I scorne such helps.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: O, though thou art a silk-worme!
And deal'st in sattins and veluets, and rich plushes,
Thou canst not spin all formes out of thy selfe;
They are quite other things: I thinke this suite
Has made me wittier, then I was.

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: Belieue it Sir,
That clothes doe much vpon the wit, as weather
Do's on the braine; and thence comes your prouerbe;
The Taylor makes the man: I speake by experience
Of my owne Customers. I haue had Gallants,
Both Court and Countrey, would ha' fool'd you vp
In a new suite, with the best wits, in being,
And kept their speed, as long as their clothes lasted
Han'some, and neate; but then as they grew out
At the elbowes againe, or had a staine, or spot,
They haue sunke most wretchedly.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: What thou report'st,
Is but the common calamity, and seene daily;
And therefore you 'haue another answering prouerbe:
A broken sleeue keepes the arme backe,

SP.SPEAKER: FAS.
SP.L: 'Tis true, Sir.
And thence wee say, that such a one playes at peepe-arme.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Doe you so? it is wittily sayd. I wonder, Gentlemen,
And men of meanes will not maintaine themselues
Fresher in wit, I meane in clothes, to the highest.
For hee that's out o' clothes, is out o'fashion,
And out of fashion, is out of countenance,
And out o' countenance, is out o' Wit.
Is not Rogue Haberdasher come?

SP.SPEAKER: HAB.
SP.L: Yes, here, Sir.They are all about him, busie.
I ha' beene without this halfe houre.

SP.SPEAKER: P IV.
SP.L: Giue me my hat.
Put on my Girdle. Rascall, sits my Ruffe well?

SP.SPEAKER: LIN.
SP.P: In print.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Slaue.

SP.SPEAKER: LIN.
SP.P: See your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: s this same hat
O'the blocke passant? Do not answer mee,
I cannot stay for an answer. I doe feele
The powers of one and twenty, like a ide
Flow in vpon mee, and perceiue an Heyre,
Can Coniure vp all spirits in all circles,
Rogue, Rascall, Slaue▪ giue tradesmen their true names,
And they appeare to 'hem prsently.

SP.SPEAKER: LIN.
SP.P: For profit.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Come cast my cloake about me, I'll goe see,
This Office Thom, and be trimm'd afterwards.
I'll put thee in possession, my prime worke!
Gods so▪ my Spurrier! put hem on boy, quickly,His Spurri∣er comes in.
lost my Spurres with too much speed.
Good morning to my Ioy, My iolly Peni-boy!
The Lord, and the Prince of plenty!
I come to see what riches, Thou bearest in thy breeches,
The first of thy one and twenty▪
What, doe thy pockets gingle? Or shall wee neede to mingle
Our strength both of foote and horses!
These fellows looke so eager, As if they would beleaguer
An Heyre in the midst of his forces!
I hope they be no Srieants! That hang vpon thy margents.
This Rogue has the Ioule of a Iaylor▪

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: O Founder, no such matter, My Spurrier, and my Hatter,The young Peny-boy answers in tune.
My Linnen man, and my Taylor.
Thou should'st haue beene brought in too, Shoomaker,
If the time had beene longer, and Thom Barber.
How do'st thou like my company, old Canter?
Doe I not muster a braue troupe? all Bill-men?
Present your Armes, before my Founder here,
This is my Founder, this same learned Canter!
He brought me the first newes of my fathers death,
He takes the bils, and puts them vp in his pockets.I thanke him, and euer since, I call him Founder▪
Worship him, boyes, I'll read onely the summes.
And passe 'hem streight.

SP.SPEAKER: SHO.
SP.P: Now Ale.

SP.SPEAKER: REST.
SP.P: And strong Ale blesse him.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Gods so, some Ale, and Sugar for my Founder!
Good Bills, sufficient Bills, these Bills may passe.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: I do not like those paper-squibs, good Master.
They may vndoe your store, I meane, of Credit,
And fire your Arsenall, if case you doe not
In time make good those outerworkes, your pockets,
And take a Garrison in of some two hundred,
To beat these Pyoners off, that carry a Mine
Would blow you vp, at last. Secure your Casamates,
Here Master Picklocke, Sir, your man o' Law,
And learn'd Attrney, has sent you a Bag of munition.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What is't?

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: Three hundred pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: I'll dispatch 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Do, I would haue your strengths lin'd, and perfum'd
With Gold, as well as Amber.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: God a mercy,
Come, Ad soluendum, boyes! there, there, and there, &c.
He payes all.I looke on nothing but Totalis.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA·
SP.L: See!
The difference 'twixt the couetous, and the prodigall!
"The Couetous man neuer has money! and
"The Prodigall will haue none shortly!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Ha,
What saies my Founder? I thanke you, I thanke you Sirs.

SP.SPEAKER: ALL.
SP.P: God blesse your worship, and your worships Chanter.

SP.SPEAKER: P CA.
SP.L: I say't is nobly done, to cherish Shop-keepers,
And pay their Bills, without examining thus.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Alas! they haue had a pittifull hard time on't,
A long vacation, from their coozening.
Poore Rascalls, I doe doe it out of charity.
I would aduance their trade againe, and haue them
Haste to be rich, sweare, and forsweare wealthily,
What doe you stay for, Sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: SPV.
SP.L: To my boxe Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Your boxe, why, there's an angel, if my Spurres
He giues the Spurrier, to his boxe.Be not right Rippon.

SP.SPEAKER: SPV.
SP.L: Giue me neuer a penny
If I strike not thorow your bounty with the Rowells.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Do'st thou want any money Founder?

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Who, Sr. I,
Did I not tell you I was bred i'the Mines,
Vnder Sir Beuis Bullion.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: That is true,
I quite forgot, you Myne-men want no money,
Your streets are pau'd with 't: there, the molten siluer
Runns out like creame, on cakes of gold.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: And Rubies
Doe grow like Strawberries.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: 'Twere braue being there!
Come Thom, we'll go to the Office now.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: What Office?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Newes Office, the New Staple; thou shalt goe too,
'Tis here i'the house, on the same floore, Thom. sayes,
Come, Founder, let vs trade in Ale, and nutmegges.
WHat, are those Desks fit now? set forth the Table,
The Carpet and the Chayre: where are the Newes
That were examin'd last? ha' you fil'd them vp?

SP.SPEAKER: CLE.
SP.P: Not yet, I had no time.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: Are those newes registred,
That Emissary Buz sent in last night?
Of Spinola, and his Egges?

SP.SPEAKER: CLE.
SP.P: Yes Sir, and fil'd.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.P: What are you now vpon?

SP.SPEAKER: CLE.
SP.L: That our new Emissary
Westminster, gaue vs, of the Golden Heyre.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: Dispatch, that's newes indeed, and of importance.
What would you haue good woman?

SP.SPEAKER: WO.
SP.L: I would haue Sir,
A groatsworth of any Newes, I care not what,A countrey-woman waites there.
To carry downe this Saturday, to our Vicar.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: O! You are a Butterwoman, aske Nathaniel
The Clerke, there.

SP.SPEAKER: CLE.
SP.L: Sir, I tell her, she must stay
Till Emissary Exchange, or Pauls send in,
And then I'll fit her.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: Doe good woman, haue patience,
It is not now, as when the Captaine liu'd.

SP.SPEAKER: CLE.
SP.L: You'll blast the reputation of the Office,
Now i'the Bud, if you dispatch these Groats,
So soone: let them attend in name of policie.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. I. SCENE. V.
DIV2.STAGE: PENIBOY. CYMBAL. FITTON. THO: BARBER. CANTER.

SP.P: IN troth they are dainty roomes; what place is this?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: This is the outer roome, where my Clerkes sit▪
And keepe their sides, the Register i'the midst,
The Examiner, he sits priuate there, within,
And here I haue my seuerall Rowles, and Fyles
Of Newes by the Alphabet, and all put vp
Vnder their heads.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: But those, too, subdiuided?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Into Authenticall, and Apocryphall.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Or Newes of doubtfull credit, as Barbers newes.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: And Taylors Newes, Porters, and Watermens newes,

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Whereto, beside the Corant, and Gazetti.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: I haue the Newes of the season.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: As vacation newes,
Terme-newes, and Christmas-newes.

SP.SPEAKER: CIM.
SP.P: And newes o' the faction.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: As the Reformed newes, Protestant newes,

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: And Pontificiall newes, o all which seuerall,
The Day-bookes, Characters, Precedents are kept.
Together with the names of speciall friends—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: And men of Correspondence i'the Countrey—

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Yes, of all ranks, and all Religions.—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Factors, and Agents—

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Liegers, that lie out
Through all the Shires o'the kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: This is fine!
And beates a braue relation! but what sayes
Mercurius Britannicus to this?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM
SP.P: O Sir, he gaines by't halfe in halfe.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Nay more
I'll stan to't. For, where he was wont to get
In, hungry Captaines▪ obscure Statesmen.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Fellowes
To drinke with him in a darke roome in a Tauerne,
And eat a Sawsage.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: We ha' seen't,

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: As faine,
To keepe so many politique pennes
Going, to feed the presse.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: And dish ou newes,
Were't true, or false.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Now all that charge is sau'd
The publique Chronicler.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: How, doe you call him there?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: And gentle Reader.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: He that has the maidenhead
Of all the bookes.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Yes, dedicated to him,

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Or rather prostituted.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: You are right, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: No more shall be abus'd, nor countrey-Parsons
O' the Inquisition, nor busie Iustices,
Trouble the peace, and both torment themselues,
And their poore ign'rant Neighbours with enquiries
After the many, and most innocent Monsters,
That neuer came i'th' Counties they were charg'd with.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Why, me thinkes Sir, if the honest common people
Will be abus'd, why should not they ha' their pleasure,
In the belieuing Lyes, are made for them;
As you i'th' Office, making them your selues?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: O Sir! it is the printing we oppose.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: We not forbid that any Newes, be made,
But that 't be printed; for when Newes is printed,
It leaues Sir to be Newes. while 'tis but written —

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Though it be ne're so false, it runnes Newes still.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: See diuers mens opinions! vnto some,
The very printing of them, makes them Newes;
That ha' not the heart to beleeue any thing,
But what they see in print.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I, that's an Error
Ha's abus'd many; but we shall reforme it,
As many things beside (we haue a hope)
Are crept among the popular abuses.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Nor shall the Stationer cheat vpon the Time,
By buttering ouer againe—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: once, in Seuen Yeares,
As the age doates—

SP.SPEAKER: CYM:
SP.L: And growes forgetfull o'them,
is antiquated Pamphlets, with new dates.
But all shall come from the Mint.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Fresh and new stamp'd,

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: With the Office-Seale, Staple Commoditie.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: And if a man will assure his Newes, he may:
Two-pence a Sheet he shall be warranted,
And haue a policie for't.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Sir, I admire
The method o' your place; all things within't
Are so digested, fitted, and compos'd,
As it shewes Wit had married Order.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: The best wee could to inuite the Times.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: It ha's
Cost sweat, and freesing.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: And some broken sleepes
Before it came to this.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: I easily thinke it.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: But now it ha's the shape—

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: And is come forth.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: A most polite neat thing! with all the limbs,
As sense can tast!

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: It is Sir, though I say it,
As well-begotten a busines, and as fairely
Helpt to the World.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: You must be a Mid-wife Sir!
Or els the sonne of a Mid-wife! (pray you pardon me)
Haue helpt it forth so happily! what Newes ha' you?
Newes o' this morning? I would faine heare some
Fresh, from the forge (as new as day, as they say.)

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: And such we haue Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: Shew him the last Rowle,
Of Emissary West-minster's, The Heire.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Come nearer, Thom:

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.L: There is a braue yong Heire
Pey reioy∣ceth, that he .Is come of age this morning, Mr. Peny-boy.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: That's I!

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.P: His Father dy'd on this day seuenth-night.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: True!

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.L: At sixe o'the Clocke i'the morning, iust a weeke
hom: of it.Ere he was One and Twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I am here, Thom!
Proceed, I pray thee.

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.L: An old Canting Begger
Brought him first Newes, whom he has entertain'd,
Call in the Canter. Hee giues the Clerke.To follow him, since.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Why, you shall see him! Founder,
Come in; no Follower, but Companion,
I pray thee put him in, Friend. There's an Angell—
Thou do'st not know, hee's a wise old Fellow,
Though he seeme patch'd thus, and made vp o' peeces,
Founder, we are in, here, in, i'the Newes-Office!
In this dayes Rowle, already! I doe muse
How you came by vs Sir's!

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: One Master Pick-locke
A Lawyer, that hath purchas'd here a place,
This morning, of an Emissary vnder me.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Emissarie Westminster.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Gaue it into th'Office,

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: For his Essay, his peece.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: My man o' Law!
Hee's my Attorney, and Sollicitour too!
A fine pragmaticke! what's his place worth?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: A Nemo-scit, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: 'Tis as Newes come, in,

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: And as they are issued. I haue the iust mcoytie
For my part: then the other mocytie
Is parted into seuen. The foure Emissaries;
Whereof my Cozen Fitton here's for Court,
Ambler for Pauls, and Buz for the Exchange,
Picklocke, for Westminster, with the Examiner,
And Register, they haue full parts: and then one part
Is vnder-parted to a couple of Clarkes;
And there's the iust diuision of the profits!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Ha' you those Clarks Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: There is one Desk empty,
But it has many Suitors.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Sir, may I
Present one more and carry it, if his parts
Or Gifts, (which you will, call'hem)

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Be sufficient Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: What are your present Clarkes habilities?
How is he qualified?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM▪
SP.L: A decay'd Stationer
He was, but knowes Newes well, can sort and ranke 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: And for a need can make 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: True Paules bred,
I'the Church-yard.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: And this at the West-dore,
O'th other side, hee's my Barber Thom,
A pretty Scholler, and a Master of Arts,
Was made, or went out Master of Arts in a throng,
At the Vniuersitie; as before, one Christmas,
He got into a Masque at Court, by his wit,
And the good meanes of his Cythern, holding vp thus
For one o'the Musique, Hee's a nimble Fellow!
And alike skil'd in euery liberall Science,
As hauing certaine snaps of all, a neat,
Quick-vaine, in forging Newes too. I doe loue him,
And promis'd him a good turne, and I would doe it.
Whats your price? the value?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Fifty pounds, Sr.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Get in Thom, take possession, I install thee;
Here, tell your money; giue thee ioy, good Thom;Hee buyes Thom a Clerkes place.
And let me heare from thee euery minute of Newes,
While the New Staple stands, or the Office lasts,
Which I doe wish, may ne're be lesse for thy sake.

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.L: The Emissaries, Sir, would speake with you,
And Master Fitton, they haue brought in Newes,
Three Bale together.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Sr, you are welcome, here.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: So is your creature.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Businesse calls vs off, Sir,They take leaue of Pe∣ny-boy, and Canter.
That may concerne the Office.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Keepe me faire, Sir,
Still i'your Staple, I am here your friend,
On the same flooer.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: We shall be your seruants.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: How dost thou like it, Founder?

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: All is well,
But that your man o' law me thinks appeares not
In his due time. O! Here comes Masters worship.
HOw do's the Heyre, bright Master Peniboy?
Is hee awake yet in his One and Twenty?
Why, this is better farre, then to weare Cypresse,
Dull smutting gloues, or melancholy blacks,
And haue a payre of twelue-peny broad ribbands
Laid out like Labells.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I should ha' made shift
To haue laught as heartily in my mourners hood,
As in this Suite, if it had pleas'd my father
To haue beene buried, with the Trumpeters:

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: The Heralds of Armes, you meane.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I meane,
All noyse, that is superfluous!

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: All that idle pompe,
And vanity of a Tombe-stone, your wise father
Did, by his will, preuent. Your worship had—

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: A louing and obedient father of him,
I know it: a right, kinde-natur'd man,
To dye so opportunely.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: And to settle
All things so well, compounded for your ward ship
The weeke afore, and left your state entyre
Without any charge vpon't.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I must needes say,
I lost an Officer of him, a good Bayliffe,
And I shall want him; but all peace be with him,
I will not wish him aliue, againe; not I,
For all my Fortune; giue your worship ioy
O'your new place, your Emissary-ship,
I'the Newes Office.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: Know you, why I bought it Sr?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: To worke for you, and carry a myne
Against the Master of it, Master Cymball;
Who hath a plot vpon a Gentlewoman,
Was once design'd for you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Me?

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Your father,
Old Master Peni-boy, of happy memory,
And wisdome too, as any i'the County,
Carefull to finde out a fit match for you,
In his owne life time (but hee was preuented)
Left it in writing in a Schedule here,
To be annexed to his Will; that you,
His onely Sonne, vpon his charge, and blessing,
Should take due notice of a Gentlewoman,
Soiourning with your vncle, Richer Peni-boy.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: A Cornish Gentlewoman, I doe know her,
Mistresse, Pecunia doe-all.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: A great Lady,
Indeede shee is, and not of mortall race,
Infanta of the Mines; her Graces Grandfather,
Was Duke, and Cousin to the King of Ophyr,
The Subterranean, let that passe. Her name is,
Or rather, her three names are (for such shee is)
Aurelia Clara Pecunia, A great Princesse,
Of mighty power, though shee liue in priuate
With a contracted family! Her Secretary—

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: Who is her Gentleman-vsher too.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: One Broker,
And then two Gentlewomen; Mistresse Statute,
And Mistresse Band, with Waxe the Chambermaide,
And Mother Mortgage, the old Nurse, two Groomes,
Pawne, and his fellow; you haue not many to bribe, Sir.
The worke is feizible, and th'approches easie,
By your owne kindred. Now, Sir, Cymball thinkes,
The Master here, and gouernor o'the Staple,
By his fine arts, and pompe of his great place
To draw her! He concludes, shee is a woman!
And that so soone as sh' heares of the New Office,
Shee'll come to visit it, as they all haue longings
After new sights, and motions! But your bounty,
Person, and brauery must atchieue her.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Shee is
The talke o'the time▪ th'aduenture o'the age!

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: You cannot put your selfe vpon an action
Of more importance.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: All the world are suiters to her.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: All sorts of men, and all professions!

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: You shall haue stall-fed Doctors, cram'd Diuines
Make loue to her, and with those studied
And perfum'd flatteries, as no rome can stinke
More elegant, then where they are.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Well chanted
Old Canter thou singst true.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: And (by your leaue)
Good Masters worship, some of your veluet coate
Make corpulent curt'ies to her, till they cracke for't.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: There's Doctor Almanack wooes her, one of the Ieerers,
A fine Physitian.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Your Sea-captaine, Shun field,
Giues out hee'll goe vpon the Cannon for her.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Though his lowd mouthing get him little credit,

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Young Master Pyed mantle, the fine Herrald
Professes to deriuer her through all ages,
From all the Kings, and Queenes, that euer were.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: And Master Madrigall, the crowned Poet
Of these our times, doth offr at her praises
As faire as any, when it shall please Apollo,
That wit and rime may meete both in one subiect.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: And you to beare her from all these, it will be—

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: A work of fame.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: Of honor.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: Celebration.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: Worthy your name.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: The Peni-boyes to liue in't,

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: It is an action you were built for, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: And none but you can doe it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I'll vndertake it,

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: And carry it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Feare me not, for since I came
Of mature age, I haue had a certaine itch
In my right eye, this corner, here, doe you see?
To doe some worke, and worthy of a Chronicle.

DIV1.HEAD: The first Intermeane after the first Act.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: How now Gossip! how doe's the Play please you?

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: Very scuruily, me thinks, and sufficiently naught.

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION.
SP.P: As a body would wish: here's nothing but a young Prodigall, come of age, who makes much of the Barber, buyes him a place in a new Office, i'the ayre, I know not where, and his man o'Law to follow him, with the Begger to boote, and they two helpe him to a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: I, shee is a proper piece! that such creatures can broke for.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: I cannot abide that nasty fellow, the Begger, if hee had beene a Court-Begger in good clothes; a Begger in veluet, as they say, I could haue endur'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: Or a begging scholler in blacke, or one of these beggerly Poets, gossip, that would hang vpon a young heyre like a horseleech.

SP.SPEAKER: EXPEC.
SP.P: Or a thred-bare Doctor of Physicke, a poore Quackesaluer.

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: Or a Sea-captaine, halfe steru'd.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: I, these were tolerable Beggers, Beggers of fashion! you shall see some such anon!

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: I would faine see the Foole, gossip, the Foole is the finest man t'the company, they say, and has all the wit: Hee is the very Iustice o' Peace o'the Play, and can cemmit whom hee will, and what hee will, errour, absurdity, as the toy takes him, and no man say, blacke is his eye, but laugh at him.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: But they ha' no Foole i' this Play, I am afraid, gossip.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: It's a wise Play, then.

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION.
SP.P: They are all fooles, the rather, in that.

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: Like enough.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: My husband, (Timothy Tatle, God rest his poore soule) was wont to say, there was no Play without a Foole, and a Diuell in't; he was for the Diuell still God blesse him. The Diuell for his money, would hee say, I would faine see the Diuell. And why would you so faine see the Diuell? would I say. Because hee has hornes, wife, and may be a cuckold, as well as a Diuell, hee would answer: You are e'en such another, husband, quoth I. Was the Diuell euer married? where doe you read, the Dill was euer so honorable to commit Matrimony; The Play will tell vs, that, sayes hee, wee'll goe see't to morrow, the Diuell is an Asse. Hee is an errant learn'd man, that made it, and can write, they say, and I am fouly deceiu'd, but hee can read too.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: I remember it gossip, I went with you, by the same token, Mrs. Trouble Truth diswaded vs, and told vs, hee was a prophane Poet, and all his Playes had Diuels in them. That he kept schole vpo' the Stage, could coniure there, aboue the Schole of Westminster, and Doctor Lamb too: not a Play he made, but had a Diuell in it. And that he would learne vs all to make our husbands Cuckolds at Playes: by another token, that a young married wife i'the company, said, shee could finde in her heart to steale thither, and see a little o'the vanity through her masque, and come practice at home.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: O, it was, Mistresse—

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: Nay, Gossip, I name no body. It may be 'twas my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION.
SP.P: But was the Diuell a proper man, Gossip?

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: As fine a gentleman▪ of his inches, as euer I saw trusted to the Stage▪ or any where else: and lou'd the common wealth, as well as ere a Pa∣triot of 'hem all: hee would carry away the Vice on his backe, quicke to Hell, in euery Play where he came, and reforme abuses.

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION.
SP.P: There was the Diuell of Edmonton, no such man, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: The Coniurer coosen'd him with a candles end, hee was an Asse.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: But there was one Smug, a Smith, would haue made a horse laugh, and broke his halter, as they say.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: O, but the poore man had got a shrewd mischance, one day.

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION.
SP.P: How, Gossip?

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: He had drest a Rogue Iade i'the morning, that had the Stag∣gers, and had got such a spice of 'hem himselfe, by noone, as they would not away all the Play time, doe what hee could, for his heart.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: 'Twas his part, Gossip, he was to be drunke, by his part.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: Say you so, I vnderstood not so much.

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTA.
SP.P: Would wee had such an other part, and such a man in this play, I feare 'twill be an excellent dull thing.

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: Expect, intend it.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. II. SCENE. I.
DIV2.STAGE: PENI-BOY. Sen. PECVNIA. MORTGAGE. STATVTE. BAND. BROKER.

SP.L: YOur Grace is sad me thinks, and melancholy!
You doe not looke vpon me with that face,
As you were wont, my Godnesse, bright Pecunia:
Although your Grace be falne, of two i'the hundred,
In vulgar estimation; yet am I,
You Graces seruant still: and teach this body,
To bend, and these my aged knees to buckle,
In adoration, and iust worship of you.
Indeed, I doe confesse, I haue no shape
To make a minion of, but I'm your Martyr,
Your Graces Martyr. I can heare the Rogues,
As I doe walke the streetes, whisper, and point,
There goes old Peni-boy, the slaue of money,
Rich Peni-boy, Lady Pecunia's drudge,
A sordid Rascall, one that neuer made
Good meale in his sleep, but sells the acates are sent him,
Fish, Fowle, and venison, and preserues himselfe,
Like an old hoary Rat, with mouldy pye-crust.
This I doe heare, reioycing, I can suffer
This, and much more, for your good Graces sake.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: Why do you so my Guardian? I not bid you,
Cannot my Grace be gotten, and held too,
Without your selfe-tormentings, and your watches,
Your macerating of your body thus
With cares, and scantings of your dyet, and rest?

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: O, no, your seruices, my Princely Lady,
Cannot with too much zeale of rites be done,
They are so sacred.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: But my Reputation.
May suffer, and the worship of my family,
When by o seruile menes they both are sought.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: You are a noble, young, free, gracious Lady,
And would be euery bodies, in your bounty,
But you must not be so. They are a few
That know your merit, Lady, and can valew't.
Your selfe scarce vnderstans your proper powers.
They are all-mighty, and that wee your seruants,
That haue the honour here to stand so neere you,
Know; and can vse too. All this Nether-world
Is yours, you command it, and doe sway it,
The honour of it, and the honesty,
The reputation, I, and the religion,
(I was about to say, and had not err'd)
Is Queene Pecunia's. For that stile is yours,
If mortals knew your Grace, or their owne good.

SP.SPEAKER: MOR.
SP.P: Please your Grace to retire.

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: I feare your Grace
Hath ta'ne too much of the sharpe ayre.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: O no!
I could endure to take a great deale more
(And with my constitution, were it left)
Vnto my choice, what thinke you of it, Statute?

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: A little now and then does well, and keepes
Your Grace in your complexion.

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.P: And true temper.

SP.SPEAKER: MOR.
SP.L: But too much Madame▪ may encrease cold rheumes,
Nouish catarrhes, greene sicknesses, and agues,
And put you in consumption

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Best to take
Aduice of your graue women, Noble Madame,
They know the state o'your body, and ha'studied
Your Graces health.

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: And honour. Here'll be visitants,
Or Suitors by and by; and 'tis not fit
They find you here.

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: 'Twill make your Grace too cheape
To giue them audience presently.

SP.SPEAKER: MOR.
SP.L: Leaue your Secretary,
To answer them.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.P: Waite you here. Broker.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: I shal Madame.
And doe your Graces trusts with diligence.
WHat luck's this? I am come an inch too late,
Doe you heare Sir? Is your worship o'the family
Vnto the Lady Pecunia?

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: I serue her Grace, Sir,
Aurelia Clara Pecunia, the Infanta.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.L: Has she all those Titles, and her Grace besides,
I must correct that ignorance and ouer-sight,
Before I doe present. Sir, I haue drawne
A Pedigree for her Grace, though yet a Nouice
In that so noble study.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: A Herald at Armes?

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.P: No Sir, a Pursiuant, my name is Pyed-mantle.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: Good Master Pyed-mantle.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.L: I haue deduc'd her.—

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: From all the Spanish Mines in the West-Indi'es,
I hope: for she comes that way by her mother,
But, by her Grand-mother, she's Dutches of Mines.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.P: From mans creation I haue brought her.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: No further?
Before Sr, long before, you haue done nothing else,
Your Mines were before Adam, search your Office,
Rowle fiue and twenty, you will finde it so,
I see you are but a Nouice, Master Pyed-mantle.
If you had not told mee so.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.L: Sir, an apprentise
In armoiry. I haue read the Elements,
And Accidence, and all the leading bookes,
And I haue, now, vpon me a great ambition,
How to be brought to her Grace, to kisse her hands.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: Why, if you haue acquaintance with Mistresse Statute,
Or Mistresse Band, my Ladies Gentlewomen,
They can induce you. One is a Iudges Daughter,
But somewhat stately; th'other Mistresse Band,
Her father's but a Scriuener, but shee can
Almost as much with my Lady, as the other,
Especially, if Rose Waxe the Chambermaid
Be willing. Doe you not know her, Sir, neither?

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.P: No in troth Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: She's a good plyant wench,
And easie to be wrought, Sir, but the Nurse
Old mother Mortgage, if you haue a Tenement,
Or such a morsell? though shee haue no teeth,
Shee loues a sweet meat, any thing that melts
In her warme gummes, she could command it for you
On such a trifle, a toy. Sir, you may see,
How for your loue, and this so pure complexion,
(A perfect Sanguine) I ha' ventur'd thus,
The straining of a ward, opening a doore
Into the secrets of our family:

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.L: I pray you let mee know, Sir, vnto whom
I am so much beholden; but your name.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: My name is Broker, I am Secretary,
And Vsher, to her Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.P: Good Master Broker!

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: Good Mr. Pyed-mantle.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.L: Why? you could do me,
If you would, now, this fauour of your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: Truely, I thinke I could: but if I would,
I hardly should, without, or Mistresse Band,
Or Mistresse Statute, please to appeare in it.
Or the good Nurse I told you of, Mistresse Mortgage▪
We know our places here, wee mingle not
One in anothers sphere, but all moue orderly,
In our owne orbes; yet wee are all Concentricks.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I'll waite a better season.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: Doe,
And study the right meanes, get Mistresse Band
Broker makes a mouth at him. He ieeres him againe. Old Peny-boy leapsTo vrge on your behalfe, or little Waxe.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.L: I haue a hope, Sir, that I may, by chance,
Light on her Grace, as she's taking the ayre:

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: That ayre of hope, has blasted many an ayrie
Of Castrills like your selfe: Good Master Pyed-mantle,

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Well said, Master Secretary, I stood behinde
And hard thee all. I honor thy dispatches.
If they be rude, vntrained it our method
And haue not studied the rule, dismisse 'hem quickly,
Where's Lickfinger my Cooke? that vnctuous rascall?
Hee'll neuer keepe his houre, that vessell of kitchinstuffe!

SP.P: HEere hee is come, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Pox vpon him kidney,
Alwaies too late!

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: To wish 'hem you, I confesse,
That ha'them already.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: The pox!

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: The piles,
The plague, and all diseases light on him,
Knowes not to keepe his word. I'ld keepe my word sure!
I hate that man that will not keepe his word,
When did I breake my word?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Or I, till now?
And 'tis but halfe an houre.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Halfe a yeere:
To mee that stands vpon a minute of time.
I am a iust man, I loue still to be iust.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Why? you thinke I can runne like light-foot Ralph,
Or keep a wheele-barrow, with a sayle in towne here,
To whirle me to you: I haue lost two stone
Of suet i'the seruice posting hither,
You might haue followed me like a watering pot,
And seene the knots I made along the street;
My face dropt like the skimmer in a fritter panne,
And my whole body, is yet (to say the truth)
A rosted pound of butter, with grated bread in 't!He sweepes his face.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Belieue you, he that list. You stay'd of purpose,
To haue my venison stinke, and my fowle mortify'd,
That you might ha' 'hem—

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: A shilling or two cheaper,
That's your iealousie.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Perhaps it is.
Will you goe in, and view, and value all?
Yonder is venison sent mee! fowle! and fish!
In such abundance! I am sicke to see it!
I wonder what they meane! I ha told 'hem of it!
To burthen a weake stomacke! and prouoke
A dying appetite! thrust a sinne vpon me
I ne'r was guilty of! nothing but gluttony!
Grosse gluttony! that will vndoe this Land!

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: And bating two i'the hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: I, that same's
A crying sinne, a fearefull damn'd deuice,
Eats vp the poore, deuoures 'hem—

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Sir, take heed
What you giue out.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Against your graue great Solons?
Numae Pompilij, they that made that Law?
To take away the poore's inheritance?
It was their portion: I will stand to't.
And they haue rob'd 'hem of it, plainly rob'd 'hem,
I still am a iust man, I tell the truth.
When moneies went at Ten i'the hundred, I,
And such as I, the seruants of Pecunia,
Could spare the poore two out of ten, and did it,
How say you, Broker?

SP.SPEAKER: (LIC.
SP.L: Ask your Eccho)

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: You did it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. S.
SP.L: I am for Iustice, when did I leaue Iustice?
We knew 'twas theirs, they'had right and Title to't.
Now—

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: You can spare 'hem nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Very little,

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: As good as nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: They haue bound our hands
With their wise solemne act, shortned our armes.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Beware those worshipfull eares, Sir, be not shortned,
And you play Crop i'the fleete, if you vse this licence.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: What licence, Knaue? Informer?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: I am Lickfinger,
Your Cooke.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: A saucy Iacke you are, that's once;
VVhat said I, Broker?

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: Nothing that I heard, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: I know his gift, hee can be deafe when he list.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Ha' you prouided me my bushell of egges?
I did bespeake? I doe not care how stale,
Or stincking that they be; let 'hem be rotten:
For ammunition here to pelt the boyes,
That breake my windowes?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Yes Sir, I ha' spar'd 'hem
Out of the custard politique for you, the Maiors.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: 'Tis well, goe in, take hence all that excesse,
Make what you can of it, your best: and when
I haue friends, that I inuite at home, prouide mee
Such, such, and such a dish, as I bespeake;
One at a time, no superfluitie.
Or if you haue it not, returne mee money;
You know my waies.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: They are a little crooked.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: How knaue?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: Because you do indent.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: 'Tis true, Sir,
I do indent you shall returne me money.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: Rather then meat, I know it: you are iust still.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: I loue it still. And therefore if you spend
The red-Deere pyes i'your house, or sell 'hem forth, Sir,
Cast so, that I may haue their coffins all,
Return'd here, and pil'd vp: I would be thought
To keepe some kind of house.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: By the mouldie signes?

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: And then remember meat for my two dogs:
Fat flaps of mutton; kidneyes; rumps of veale;
Good plentious scraps; my maid shall eat the reliques.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: VVhen you & your dogs haue din'd. A sweet reuersion.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: VVho's here? my Courtier? and my little Doctor?
My Muster-Master? and what Plouer's that
They haue brought to pull?

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: I know not, some green Plouer.
I'le find him out.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Doe, for I know the rest,
They are the Ieerers, mocking, flouting Iackes.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. II. SCENE. IV.
DIV2.STAGE: FITTON. PENI-BOY. SE. ALMANACH. SHVNFIELD. MADRIGAL. LICK-FINGER. BROKER.

SP.P: HOw now old Money-Bawd? w'are come—

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: To ieere me,
As you were wont, I know you.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: No, to giue thee
Some good security, and see Pecunia.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: What is't?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Our selues.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: Wee'l be one bound for another.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: This noble Doctor here.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: This worthy Courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: This Man o' war, he was our Muster-Master.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: But a Sea-Captaine now, braue Captaine Shun-field.He holds vp his nose.

SP.SPEAKER: SHVN.
SP.P: You snuffe the ayre now, as the scent displeas'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Thou needst not feare him man, his credit is sound,

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: And season'd too, since he tooke salt at Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: I doe not loue pickld security,
Would I had one good Fresh-man in for all;
For truth is, you three stinke.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: You are a Rogue,

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: I thinke I am, but I will lend no money
On that security, Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: Here's a Gentleman,
A Fresh-man i'the world, one Master Madrigall.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Of an vntainted credit; what say you to him?

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Hee's gone me thinkes, where is he? Madrigall?Madrigall steps aside with Bro∣ker.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: H' has an odde singing name, is he an Heyre?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: An Heyre to a faire fortune,

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: And full hopes:
A dainty Scholler, and a pretty Poët!

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Y'aue said enough. I ha' no money, Gentlemen,
An he goe to't in ryme once, not a penny

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Why, hee's of yeares, though he haue little beard.He snuffes againe.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: His beard has time to grow. I haue no money:
Let him still dable in Poetry. No Pecunia
Is to be seene.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: Come, thou lou'st to be costiue
Still i' thy curt'sie; but I haue a pill,
A golden pill to purge away this melancholly.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Tis nothing but his keeping o'the house here,
With his two drowsie doggs.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: A drench of sacke
At a good tauerne, and a fine fresh pullet,
Would cure him.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Nothing but a yong Haire in white-broth,
I know his diet better then the Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: What Lick-finger? mine old host of Ram-Alley?
You ha' some merat here.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: Some dosser of Fish
Or Fowle to fetch of.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: An odde bargaine of Venison,
To driue.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: Will you goe in, knaue?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: I must needs,
You see who driues me, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: Not the diuell.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT,
SP.P: Hee may be in time, hee is his Agent, now.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: You are all cogging Iacks, a Couy o' wits,
The Ieerers, that still call together at meales:
Or rather an Airy, for you are birds of prey:
Peny-boy thrusts him in.And flie at all, nothing's too bigge or high for you.
And are so truely fear'd, but not belou'd
One of another: as no one dares breake
Company from the rest, lest they should fall,
Vpon him absent.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: O! the onely Oracle
That euer peept, or spake out of a dublet.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: How the rogue stinks, worse then a Fishmonger sleeues!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Or Curriers hands!

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: And such a perboil'd visage!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: His face lookes like a Diers apron, iust!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: A sodden head, and his whole braine a possit curd!

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: I, now you ieere, ieere on; I haue no money.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: I wonder what religion hee's of!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: No certaine species sure, A kinde of mule!
That's halfe an Ethnicke, halfe a Christian!

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.P: I haue no monie, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: This stocke.
He has no sense of any vertue, honour,
Gentrie or merit.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.L: You say very right,
My meritorious Captaine, (as I take it!)
Merit will keepe no house, nor pay no house rent.
Will Mistresse Merit goe to mercat, thinke you?
Set on the pot, or feed the family?
Will Gentry cleare with the Butcher? or the Baker?
Fetch in a Phessant, or a brace of Partridges,
From good-wife Poulter, for my Ladies supper.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: See! this pure rogue!

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.L: This rogue has money tho',
My worshipfull braue Courtier has no money.
No, nor my valiant Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Hang you rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.L: Nor you, my learned Doctor. I lou'd you
Whil you did hold your practice, and kill tripe wiues.
And kept you to your vrinall; but since your thombes
Haue greas'd the Ephemerides, casting figures,
And turning ouer for your Candle-rents,
And your twelue houses in the Zodiacke:
With your Almutens, Alma cantaras,
Troth you shall cant alone for Peny-boy.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: I told you what we should find him, a meere Bawd.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: A rogue, a cheater.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.L: What you please, gentlemen,
I am of that humble nature and condition,
Neuer to minde your worships, or take notice
Of what you throw away, thus. I keepe house here
Like a lame Cobler, neuer out of doores,
With my two dogs, my friends; and (as you say)
Driue a quicke pretty trade, still. I get money:
And as for Titles, be they Rogue, or Rascall,
Or what your worships fancy, let 'hem passe
As transitory things; they're mine to day,
And yours to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: Hang thee dog.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Thou curre.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.L: You see how I doe blush, and am asham'd
Of these large attributes? yet you haue no money.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: Well wolfe, Hyaena, you old pockie rascall,
You will ha' the Hernia fall downe againe
Into your Scrotum, and I shall be sent for.
I will remember then, that; and your Fistula
In ano, I cur'd you of.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.L: Thanke your dog-leech craft.
They were 'holesome piles, afore you meddl'd with 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: What an vngratefull wretch is this?

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Hee minds
A curtesie no more, then London-bridge,
What Arch was mended last.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Hee neuer thinkes.
More then a logge, of any grace at Court,
A man may doe him: or that such a Lord
Reach't him his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.L: O yes! if grace would strike
The brewers Tally, or my good Lords hand,
Would quit the scores. But Sir, they will not doe it,
Here's a piece, my good Lord piece, doth all.
Goes to the Butehers▪ fetches in a muton,He shewes a piece.
Then to the Bakers, brings in bread, makes fires,
Gets wine, and does more reall Curtesies,
Then all my Lords, I know: My sweet Lord peece!
You are my Lord, the rest are cogging Iacks,
Vnder the Rose.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Rogue, I could beat you now,

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.L: True Captaine, if you durst beat any other.
I should belieue you, but indeed you are hungry;
You are not angry Captaine, if I know you
Aright; good Captaine. No, Pecunia,
Is to be seene, though Mistresse Band would speake,
Or little Blushet-Waxe, be ne'r so easie,
I'll stop mine eares with her, against the Syrens,
Court, and Philosophy. God be wi you, Gentlemen,
Prouide you better names. Pecunia is for you.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: What a damn'd Harpy it is? where's Madrigall?
Is he sneek'd hence.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Here he comes with Broker,Madrigall returnes.
Pecunia's Secretary.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: He may doe some good
With him perhaps. Where ha' you beene Madrigall?

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: Aboue with my Ladies women, reading verses.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: That was a fauour. Good morrow, Master Secretary.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Good morrow, Master Vsher.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: Sir, by both
Your worshipfull Titles, and your name Mas Broker.
Good morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: I did aske him if hee were
Amphibion Broker.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: A creature of two natures,
Because hee has two Offices.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: You may ieere,
You ha' the wits, young Gentlemen. But your hope
Of Helicon, will neuer carry it, heere,
With our fat family; we ha' the dullest,
Most unboar'd Eares for verse amongst our females.
I grieu'd you read so long, Sir, old Nurse Mortgage,
Shee snoar'd i'the Chaire, and Statute (if you mark'd her)
Fell fast a sleepe, and Mistresse Band, shee nodded,
But not with any consent to what you read.
They must haue somwhat else to chinke, then rymes.
If you could make an Epitaph on your Land,
(Imagine it on departure) such a Poem
Would wake 'hem▪ and bring Waxe to her true temper.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: I faith Sir, and I will try.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: 'Tis but earth,
Fit to make brickes and tyles of.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Pocks vpon't
'Tis but for pots, or pipkins at the best.
If it would keepe vs in good tabacco pipes,

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: 'Twere worth keeping.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Or in porc lane dishes
There were some hope.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: But this is a hungry soile,
And must be helpt.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Who would hold any Land
To haue the trouble to marle it.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Not a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: Let clownes and hyndes affect it, that loue ploughes,
And carts, and harrowes, and are busie still,
In vexing the dull element.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: Our sweete Songster
Shall rarifie't into ayre.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: And you Mas. Broker
Shall haue a feeling.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: So it supple, Sir,
The nerues.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: O! it shall be palpable,
Make thee runne thorow a hoope, or a thombe-ring,
The nose of a tabacco pipe, and draw
Thy ductile bones out, like a knitting needle,
To serue my subtill turnes.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: I shall obey, Sir,
And run a thred, like an houre-glasse.

SP.SPEAKER: P. S.
SP.L: Where is Broker?
Are not these flies gone yet? pray' quit my house,
I'le smoake you out else.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: O! the Prodigall!
Will you be at so much charge with vs, and losse?

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: I haue heard you ha' offered Sir, to lock vp smoake,
And cauke your windores, spar up all your doores,
Thinking to keepe it a close prisoner wi'you,
And wept, when it went out, Sir, at your chimney.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: And yet his eyes were dryer then a pummise.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: A wretched rascall, that will binde about
The nose of his bellowes, lest the wind get out
When hee's abroad.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: Sweepes downe no cobwebs here,
But sells 'hem for cut-fingers. And the spiders,
As creatures rear'd of dust, and cost him nothing,
To fat old Ladies monkeyes.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Hee has offerd
To gather vp spilt water, and preserue
Each haire falls from him to stop balls with all.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: A slaue, and an Idolater to Pecunia!

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: You all haue happy memories, Gentlemen,
In rocking my poore cradle. I remember too,
When you had lands, and credit, worship, friends,
I, and could giue security: now, you haue none,
Or will haue none right shortly. This can time,
And the vicissitude of things. I haue
All these. and money too, and doe possesse 'hem,
And am right heartily glad of all our memories,
And both the changes.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Let vs leaue the viper.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Hee's glad he is rid of his torture, and so soone.
Broker, come hither, vp, and tell your Lady,
Shee must be readie presently, and Statute,
Band, Mortgage, VVax. My prodigall young kinsman
Will streight be here to see her; 'top of our house,
The flourishing, and flanting Peny-boy.
Wee were but three of vs in all the world,
My brother Francis, whom they call'd Franck Peny-boy,
Father to this: hee's dead. This Peny-boy,
Is now the heire! I, Richer Peny-boy,
Not Richard, but old Harry Peny-boy,
And (to make rime) close, wary Peny-boy
I shall haue all at last, my hopes doe tell me.
Goe, see all ready; and where my dogs haue falted,
Remoue it with a broome, and sweeten all
VVith a slice of iuniper, not too much, but sparing,
VVe may be faultie our selues else, and turne prodigall,
In entertaining of the Prodigall.
Here hee is! and with him—what! a Clapper Dudgeon!
That's a good signe; to haue the begger follow him,
So neere at his first entry into fortune.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. II. SCENE. V.
DIV2.STAGE: PENY-BOY. IV. PENI-BOY. SEN. PICLOCK. CANTER.) BROKER. PECVNIA. STATVTE. BAND. WAX. MORTGAGE. hid in the study.

SP.L: HOw now old Vncle? I am come to see thee.
And the braue Lady, here, the daughter of Ophir,
They say thou keepst.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Sweet Nephew, if she were
The daughter o' the Sunne, shee's at your seruice,
And so am I, and the whole family,
Worshipfull Nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Sai'st thou so, deare Vncle?
Welcome my friends then: Here is, Domine Picklocke:
My man o'Law, sollicits all my causes.
Followes my businesse, makes, and compounds my quarrells,
Betweene my tenants and mee, sowes all my strifes,
And reapes them too, troubles the country for mee,
And vexes any neighbour, that I please.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: But with commission?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Vnder my hand & seale.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.P: A worshipfull place!

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: I thanke his worship for it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: But what is this old Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: A Rogue,
A very Canter, I Sir, one that maunds
Vpon the Pad, wee should be brothers though:
For you are neere as wretched as my selfe,
You dare not vse your money, and I haue none.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Not vse my money, cogging Iacke, who vses it
At better rates? lets it for more i'the hundred,
Then I doe, Sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Be not angry vncle.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: What? to disgrace me, with my Queene? as if
I did not know her valew.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Sir, I meant
You durst not to enioy it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Hold your peace,
Young Pe∣ny-boy is angyry.You are a Iacke.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Vncle, he shall be a Iohn,
And, you goe to that, as good a man as you are.
An' I can make him so, a better man,
Perhaps I will too. Come, let vs goe.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Nay, kinsman,
My worshipfull kinsman; and the top of our house;
Doe not your penitent vncle that affront,
For a rash word, to leaue his ioyfull threshold,
Before you see the Lady that you long for.
The Venus of the time, and state, Pecunia!
I doe perceiue, your bounty loues the man,
concealed vertue, that he hides
Vnder thse ags.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: I owe my happinesse to him,
qord waiting on his worship, since I brought him
, welcome to all young heires.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Thou didst indeed, for which I thanke thee yet,
Your Princesse, Vncle, is long a comming.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: She is not rigg'd, Sir, setting forth some Lady,
ill cost as much as furnishing a Fleete,

she's come at last,
The study is open'd where she sit in state.
Shee kisseth him. and like a Galley
i'the prow.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Is this Pecunia?

SP.SPEAKER: P. S.
SP.L: Vouchsafe my toward kinsman, gracious Madame,
The sauour of your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: Nay, of my lips, Sir,
To him.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: She kisses like a mortall creature,
Almighty Made, I haue long'd to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: And I haue my desire, Sir, to behold
That youth, and shape, which in my dreames and wakes▪
I haue so oft contemplated, and felt
Warme in my vynes, and natiue as my blood.
When I was told of your arriuall here,
I felt my heart beat, as it would leape out,
In speach; and all my face it was a flame,
But how it came to passe I doe not know.

SP.SPEAKER: P. I.
SP.L: O! beauty loues to be more proud then nature,
That made you blush. I cannot satisfie
My curious eyes, by which alone I'am happy,
In my beholding you.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: They passe the complement
Prettily well.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: I, he does kisse her, I like him.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: My passion was cleare contrary, and doubtfull,He kisseth her.
I shooke for feare, and yet I danc'd for ioy,
I had such motions as the Sunne-beames make
Against a wall, or playing on a water,
Or trembling vapour of a boyling pot—

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: That's not so good, it should ha'bin a Crucible,
With molten mettall, she had vnderstood it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I cannot talke, but I can loue you, Madame.
Are these your Gentlewomen? I loue them too.
And which is mistresse Statute? Mistresse Band▪
They all kisse close, the last stucke to my lips.

SP.SPEAKER: BO.
SP.P: It was my Ladies Chamber-maid, soft-Waxe.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Soft lips she has, I am sure on't. Mother Mortgage,
I' lowe a kisse▪ till she be yonger, Statute,He doubles the comple∣ment to them all.
Sweet Mistresse Band, and honey, little VVaxe,
We must be better acquainted.

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.P: We are but seruants, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: BAND.
SP.L: But whom her Grace is so content to grace,
We shall obserue.

SP.SPEAKER: WAX.
SP.P: Aand with all fit respect.

SP.SPEAKER: MOR.
SP.P: In our poore places.

SP.SPEAKER: WAX.
SP.P: Being her Graces shadowes.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: A fine well-spoken family. What's thy name?

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: Broker.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Me thinks my vncle should not need thee,
Who is a crafty Knaue, enough, beleeue it.
Art thou her Graces Steward?

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: No, her Vsher, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: What, o'the Hall? thou hast a sweeping face,
Thy beard is like a broome.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: No barren chin, Sir,
I am no Eunuch, though a Gentleman-Vsher.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Thou shalt goe with vs. Vncle, I must haue
My Princesse forth to day.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Whither you please, Sir,
You shall command her.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: I will doe all grace
To my new seruant.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Thanks vnto your bounty;
He is my Nephew, and my Chiefe, the Point,
Old Peny-boy thankes her, but makes his condition.Tip, Top, and Tuft of all our family!
But, Sir, condition'd alwaies, you returne
Statute, and Band home, with my sweet, soft Waxe,
And my good Nurse, here, Mortgage.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: O! what else?

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: By Broker.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Do not feare.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: She shall go wi' you,
Whither you please, Sir, any where.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: I see
A Money-Bawd, is lightly a Flesh-Bawd, too.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Are you aduisd? Now o'my faith, this Canter
Would make a good graue Burgesse in some Barne.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Come, thou shalt go with vs, vncle.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: By no means, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: We'll haue both Sack, and Fidlers.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: I'll not draw
That charge vpon your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: He speakes modestly,
And like an Vncle,

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: But Mas Broker, here,
He shall attend you, Nephew; her Graces Vsher,
And what you fancy to bestow on him,
Be not too lauish, vse a temperate bounty,
I'll take it to my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I will be princely,
While I possesse my Princesse, my Pecunia.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: Where is't you eat?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Hard by, at Picklocks lodging.
Old Lickfinger's the Cooke, here in Ram-Alley.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: He has good cheare; perhaps I'll come and see you.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CAN.
SP.L: O, fie! an Alley, and a Cooks-shop, grosse,
The Canter takes him a∣side, and per∣swades him,'T will sauour, Sir, most rankly of 'hem both.
Let your meat rather follow you, to a tauerne.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: A tauern's as vnfit too, for a Princesse.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: No, I haue knowne a Princesse, and a great one,
Come forth of a tauerne.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: Not goe in, Sir, though.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: She must goe in, if she came forth: the blessed
Pokahontas (as the Historian calls her
And great Kings daughters of Virginia)
Hath bin in womb of a tauerne; and besides,
Your nasty Vncle will spoyle all your mirth,
And be as noysome.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: That's true.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: No 'faith,
Dine in Apollo with Pecunia,
At braue Duke Wadloos, haue your friends about you,
And make a day on't.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Content 'ifaith:
Our meat shall be brought thither. Simon the King,
Will bid vs welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: Patron, I haue a suite.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: That you will carry the Infanta,
To see the Staple', her Grace will be a grace,
To all the members of it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I will doe it:
And haue her Armes set vp there, with her Titles,
Aurelia Clara Pecunia, the Infanta.
And in Apollo. Come (sweete Princesse) goe.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: Broker, be careful of your charge.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: I warrant you.

DIV1.HEAD: The second Intermeane after the second Act.

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: Why, this is duller and duller! intolerable! scuruy! neither Diuel nor Foole in this Play! pray God, some on vs be not a witch, Gossip, to forespeake the matter thus.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: I feare we are all such, and we were old enough: But we are not all old enough to make one witch. How like you the Vice i'the Play.

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION.
SP.P: Which is he?

SP.SPEAKER: MIR.
SP.P: Three or foure: old Couetousnesse, the sordid Peny-boy, the Money-bawd, who is a flesh-bawd too, they say.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
