SP.P: But here is neuer a Fiend to carry him away. Besides, he has neuer a wooden dagger! I'ld not giue a rush for a Vice, that has not a wooden dagger to snap at euery body he meetes.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: That was the old way, Gossip, when Iniquity came in like Hokos Pokos, in a Iuglers ierkin, with false skirts▪ like the Knaue of Clubs! but now they are attir'd like men and women o' the time, the Vices, male and female! Prodigality like a young heyre, and his Mi∣stresse Money (whose fauours he scatters like counters) prank't vp like a prime Lady, the Infanta of the Mines.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: I, therein they abuse an honorable Princesse, it is thought.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: By whom is it so thought? or where lies the abuse?

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: Plaine in the stiling her Infanta, and giuing her three names.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: Take heed, it lie not in the vice of your interpretation: what haue Aurelia, Clara, Pecunia to do with any person? do they any more, but expresse the property of Money, which is the daughter of earth, and drawne out of the Mines? Is there nothing to be call'd Infanta, but what is subiect to exception? Why not the Infanta of the Beggers? or Infanta o'the Gipsies? as well as King of Beggers, and King of Gipsies?

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: Well, and there were no wiser then I, I would sow him in a sack, and send him by sea to his Princesse.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRT.
SP.P: Faith, and hee heard you Censure, he would goe neere to sticke the Asses eares to your high dressing, and perhaps to all ours for harkening to you.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: By'r Lady but he should not to mine, I would harken, and harken, and censure, if I saw cause, for th'other Princesse sake Pokahon∣tas, surnam'd the blessed, whom hee has abus'd indeed (and I doe censure him, and will censure him) to say she came foorth of a Tauerne, was said like a paltry Poet.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: That's but one Gossips opinion, and my Gossip Tatle's too! but what saies Expectation, here, she sits sullen and silent.

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: Troth I expect their Office, their great Office! the Staple, what it will be! they haue talk't on't, but wee see't not open yet; would Butter would come in, and spread it-selfe a little to vs.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: Or the butter-box, Buz, the Emissary.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: When it is churn'd, and dish't, we shall heare of it.

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: If it be fresh and sweet butter; but say it be sower and wheyish.

SP.SPEAKER: MIR.
SP.P: Then it is worth nothing, meere pot-butter, fit to be spent in suppositories, or greasing coach-wheeles, stale stinking butter, and such I feare it is, by the being barrell'd vp so long.

SP.SPEAKER: EXPECTATION.
SP.P: Or ranke Irish butter.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: Haue patience Gossips, say that contrary to our expectations it proue right, seasonable, salt butter.

SP.SPEAKER: MIR.
SP.P: Or to the time of yeer, in Lent, delicate Almond butter! I haue a sweet tooth yet, and I will hope the best; and sit downe as quiet, and calme as butter; looke as smooth, and soft as butter; be merry, and melt like but∣ter; laugh and be fat like butter: so butter answer my expectation, and be not mad butter; If it be: It shall both Iuly and December see. I say no more, But— Dixi.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE READERS.
DIV1.P: IN this following Act, the Office is open'd, and shew'n to the Pro∣digall, and his Princesse Pecunia, wherein the allegory, and pur∣pose of the Author hath hitherto beene wholly mistaken, and so sinister an interpretation beene made, as if the soules of most of the Spectators had liu'd in the eyes and eares of these ridiculous Gossips that tattle betweene the Acts. But hee prayes you thus to mend it. To consider the Newes here vented, to be none of his Newes, or any reasonable mans; but Newes made like the times Newes, (a weekly cheat to draw mony) and could not be fitter re∣prehended, then in raising this ridiculous Office of the Staple, wher∣in the age may see her owne folly, or hunger and thirst after pub∣lish'd pamphlets of Newes, set out euery Saturday, but made all at home, & no syllable of truth in them: then which there cannot be a greater disease in nature, or a fouler scorne put vpon the times. And so apprehending it, you shall doe the Author, and your owne iudgement a courtesie, and perceiue the tricke of alluring money to the Office, and there cooz'ning the people. If you haue the truth, rest quiet, and consider that
DIV1.Q: Ficta, voluptatis causa, sint proxima veris.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. III. SCENE. I.
DIV2.STAGE: FITTON. CYMBAL, to them PICKLOCKE. REGISTER. CLERKE. THO: BARBER.

SP.L: YOu hunt vpon a wrong scent still, and thinke
The ayre of things will carry 'hem, but it must
Be reason and proportion, not fine sounds,
My cousin Cymball, must get you this Lady.
You haue entertain'd a petty-fogger here,
Picklocke, with trust of an Emissartes place,
And he is, all, for the young Prodigall,
You see he has left vs.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Come, you doe not know him,
That speake thus of him. He will haue a tricke,
To open vs a gap▪ by a trap-doore,
When they least dreame on't. Here he comes. What newes?

SP.SPEAKER: PICK.
SP.L: Where is my brother Buz? my brother Ambler:
The Register, Examiner, and the Clerkes?
Appeare, and let vs muster all in pompe,
For here will be the rich Infanta, presently,
To make her visit. Peny-boy the heyre,
My Patron, has got leaue for her to play
With all her traine, of the old churle, her Guardian.
Now is your time to make all court vnto her;
That she may first but know, then loue the place,
And shew it by her frequent visits here:
And afterwards, get her to soiourne with you.
She will be weary of the Prodigall, quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Excellent newes!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: And counsell of an Oracle!

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: How say you cousin Fitton?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: brother Picklock,
I shall adore thee, for this parcell of tidings,
It will cry vp the credit of our Office,
Eternally, and make our Staple immortall!

SP.SPEAKER: PICK.
SP.L: Looke your addresses, then, be faire and fit,
And entertaine her, and her creatures, too,
With all the migniar dise, and quaint Caresses,
You can put on 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Thou seem'st, by thy language,
No lesse a Courtier, then a man o' Law.
I must embrace thee.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Tut, I am Vertumnus,
On euery change, or chance, vpon occasion,
A true Chamaelion, I can colour for't.
I moue vpon my axell, like a turne-pike.
Fit my face to the parties, and become
Streight, one of them.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Sirs, vp, into your Desks,
And spread the rolls vpon the Table, so.
Is the Examiner set?

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Ambler, and Buz,
Are both abroad, now.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Wee'll sustaine their parts.
No matter, let them ply the affayres without,
Fitton puts on the office cloake, and Cymbal the gowne.Let vs alone within, I like that well.
On with the cloake, and you with the Staple gowne,
And keep your state, stoupe only to the Infanta;
We'll haue a flight at Mortgage, Statute, Band,
And hard, but we'll bring Wax vnto the retriue:
Each know his seuerall prouince, and discharge it.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Fitton is brought a∣bent.I do admire this nimble ingine, Picklock.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Cuz,
What did I say?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: You haue rectified my errour!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. III. SCENE. II.
DIV2.STAGE: PENI-BOY. IV. P. CANTER. PECVNIA. STA∣TVTE. BAND. MORTGAGE. WAX. BROKER. CVSTOMERS.

SP.L: BY your leaue, Gentlemen, what newes? good, good still?
I'your new Office? Princesse, here's the Staple!
This is the Gouernor, kisse him, noble Princesse,
For my sake. Thom, how is it honest Thom?
How does thy place, and thou? my Creature, Princesse?
Hee tells Pe∣cunia of Thom.This is my Creature, giue him your hand to kisse,
He was my Barber, now he writes Clericus!
I bought this place for him, and gaue it him.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: He should haue spoke of that, Sir, and not you:
Two doe not doe one Office well.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: 'Tis true,
But I am loth to lose my curtesies.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: So are all they, that doe them, to vaine ends,
And yet you do lose, when you pay you selues.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: No more o' your sentences, Canter, they are stale,
We come for newes, remember where you are.
I pray thee let my Princesse heare some newes,
Good Master Cymbal.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: What newes would she heare?
Or of what kind, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Any, any kind.
So it be newes, the newest that thou hast,
Some newes of State, for a Princesse.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Read from Rome, there.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: They write, the King of Spaine is chosen Pope.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: How?Newes from Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: And Emperor too, the thirtieth of February.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Is the Emperor dead?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: No, but he has resign'd,Newes of the Emperor, and Tilly.
And trailes a pike now, vnder Tilly.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: For pennance.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: These will beget strange turnes in Christendome!

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: And Spinola is made Generall of the Iesuits.Newes of Spinola. The fifth Monarchy, vniting the Ecclesia∣sticke and Secular power. A plot of the house of Au∣stria. More of Spinola.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Stranger!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT,
SP.P: Sir, all are alike true, and certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: All the pretence to the fifth Monarchy,
Was held but vaine, vntill the ecclesiastique,
And secular powers, were vnited, thus,
Both in one person.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: 'T has bin long the ayme
Of the house of Austria.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: See but Maximilian,
His letters to the Baron of Bouttersheim,
Or Scheiter-huyssen.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: No, of Liechtenstein,
Lord Paul, I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I haue heard of some such thing.
Don Spinola made Generall of the Iesuits!
A Priest!

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: O, no, he is dispenc'd with all,
And the whole society, who doe now appeare
The onely Enginers of Christendome.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: They haue bin thought so long, and rightly too.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Witnesse the Engine, that they haue presented him,
To winde himselfe with, vp, into the Moone:
And thence make all his discoueries!

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Read on.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: And Vittellesco, he that was last Generall,
Being now turn'd Cooke to the society,
Has drest his excellence, such a dish of egges—

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What potch'd?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: No, powder'd.His Egges.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: All the yolke is wilde fire,
As he shall need beleaguer no more townes,
But throw his Egge in.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: It shall cleare consume,
Palace, and place; demolish and beare downe,
All strengths before it!

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Neuer be extinguish'd!
Till all become one ruine!

SP.SPEAKER: F.
SP.L: And from Florence,

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: They write was found in Galileos study,
A burning Glasse (which they haue sent him too)Galilaeo's study.
To fire any Fleet that's out at Sea—

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: By Mooneshine, is't not so?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, i'the water.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: His strengths will be vnresistable, if this hold!The burning glasse, by Moon-shine.
Ha'you no Newes against him, on the contrary?

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.L: Ecle.Yes, Sit, they write here, one Cornelius-,
Hath made the Hollanders an inuisible Ecle,
To swimme the hauen at Dunkke, and sinke all
The shipping there.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Why hanot you this, Thom?
Because he keeps the Pontificiall side.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Peny-boy will haue him change sides▪How, change sides, Thom. 'Twas neuer in my thought
To put thee vp against our selues. Come downe,
Quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Why, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I venter'd not my mony
Vpon those termes: If he may change; why so.
I'll ha him keepe his owne side, sure.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT,
SP.L: Why, let him,
'Tis but writing so much ouer againe.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: For that I'll beare the charge: There's two Pieces,

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Come, do not stick with the gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: I'l take none Sir▪
And yet he shall ha'the place.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: They shall be ,
though hee pay for it.Vp, Thom: and th'Office shall take 'hem. Keep your side, Thom.
Know your owne side, doe not forsake your side, Thom.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Read.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: They write here one Cornelius-,
Hath made the Hollanders an inuisible Ecle,
To swimme the Hauen at Dunkirke, and sinke all
The shipping there.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: But how is't done?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: I'll shew you Sir
It is an Atoma, runnes vnder water,
With a sg nose, and has a nimble taile
Made like an anger, with which taile she wrigles
Betwixt the coasts of a Ship, and sinkes it streight.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Whence ha'you this newes.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: From a right hand I assure you,
The Ecle-boats here, that lye before Queen-Hyth,
Came out of Holland.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: A most braue deuice,
To murder their flat bottomes.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I doe grant you▪
Spinola's new proiect: an army in cork-shooes.But what if Spinola haue a new Proiect:
To bring an army ouer in corke-shooes,
And land them, here, at Harwich? all his horse
Are shod with corke, and fourescore pieces of ordinance,
Mounted vpon cork-carriages, with bladders,
In stead of wheeles to runne the passage ouer
At a spring-tide.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Is't true?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: As true as the rest▪

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: He'll neuer leaue his engines: I would heare now
Some curious newes.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: As what?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Magick, or
Or flying i'the ayre, I care not what.

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.L: They write from Libtzig (reuerence to your )
The Art of drawing farts out of dead bodies,
Extraction of fartsIs by the Brotherhood of the Rosie Crosse,
Produc'd vnto perfection, in so sweet
And rich a tincture—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: As there is no Princesse,
But may perfume her chamber with th'extraction.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: There's for you, Princesse.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: What, a fart for her?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: I meane the spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: Beware how she rsents it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: The perpetu∣all Motion.And what hast thou, Thom?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: The perpetuall Motion▪
Is here found out by an Alewife in Saint Katherines,
At the signe o' the dancing Beares▪

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: What, from her tap?
I'll goe see that, or else I'll send old Canter.
He can make that discouery.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: Yes, in Ale.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Let me haue all this Newes, made vp, and seal'd▪

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: The people presse vpon vs, please you, Sir,The Regi∣ster offers him a roome.
Withdraw with your faire Princesse. There's a roome
Within, Sir, to retyre too.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: No, good Register,
We'll stand it out here, and obserue your Office;The Office call'd the house of fame.
What Newes it issues.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: 'Tis the house of fame, Sir,
Where both the curious, and the negligent;
The scrupulous, and carelesse; wilde, and stay'd;
The idle, and laborious; all doe meet,
To tast the Cornu copiae of her rumors,
Which she, the mother of sport▪ pleaseth to scatter
Among the vulgar: Baites, Sir, for the people!
And they will bite like fishes.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Let's see't.

SP.SPEAKER: DOP.
SP.L: Ha'you in your prophane Shop, any Newes
O'the Saints at Amsterdam?

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: Yes, how much would you?1. Cust. Ashe baptist.

SP.SPEAKER: DOP.
SP.P: Six peny worth.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.P: Lay your mony down, read, Thomas.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: The Saints do write, they expect a Prophet, shortly,
The Prophet Baal, to be sent ouer to them,Prophet Ba∣al expected in Helland.
To calculate a time, and halfe a time,
And the whole time, according to Naömetry.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: The measuring o'the Temple: a Cabal
Found out but lately, and set out by Archie,
Or some such head, of whose long coat they haue heard,
And being black, desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: DOP.
SP.L: Peace be with them!Archie mourn'd then.

SP.SPEAKER: REG▪
SP.L: So there had need, for they are still by the eares
One with another.

SP.SPEAKER: DOP.
SP.P: It is their zeale.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.P: Most likely.

SP.SPEAKER: DOP.
SP.P: Haue you no other of that species?

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: Yes,
But dearer, it will cost you a shilling.

SP.SPEAKER: DOP.
SP.L: Verily,
There is a nine-pence, I will shed no more.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.P: Not, to the good o'the Saints?

SP.SPEAKER: DOP.
SP.L: I am not sure,
That, man is good.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: Read, from Constantinople,
Nine penny'orth.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: They giue out here,The great Turk turn'd Christian▪ the grand Signior
Is certainely turn'd Christian, and to cleare
The controuersie'twixt the Pope and him,
Which is the Antichrist; he meanes to visit
The Church at Amsterdam, this very Sommer,
And quit all marks o'the beast.

SP.SPEAKER: DOP.
SP.L: Now ioyfull tydings.
Who brought in this? Which Emissary?

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: Buz.
Your countrey-man.

SP.SPEAKER: DOP.
SP.L: Now, blessed be the man,
And his whole Family, with the Nation.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: Yes, for Amboyna, and the Iustice there!
This is a Doper, a she Anabaptist!
Seale and deliuer her her newes, dispatch.

SP.SPEAKER: C. 2.
SP.L: Ha'you any newes from the Indies? any mirac
2. Cust.Done in Iapan, by the Iesuites? or in China?

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.L: A Coloney e Cookes sent ouer to conert the Canniballs.No, but we heare of a Colony of cookes
To be set a shore o'the coast of America,
For the conuersion of the Caniballs,
And making them good, eating Christians.
Here comes the Colonell that vndertakes it.

SP.SPEAKER: C. 2.
SP.P: 3. Cust. By Colonel Lickfinger.Who? captaine Lickfinger?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Newes, newes my boyes!
I am to furnish a great feast to day,
And I would haue what newes the Office affords.

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.L: We were venting some of you, of your new proiect,

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.P: Afore 'twas paid for, you were somewhat too hasty.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: What Lickfinger! wilt thou conuert the Caniballs,
With spit and pan Diuinity?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Sir, for that
I will not vrge, but for the fire and zeale
To the true cause; thus I haue vndertaken:
With two Lay-brethren, to my selfe, no more,
One o'the broach, th'other o'the boyler,
In one sixe months, and by plaine cookery,
No magick to't, but old Iapets physicke,
The father of the Europaean Arts,
To make such sauces for the Sauages,
And cookes their meats, with those inticing steemes,
As it would make our Caniball-Christians,
Forbeare the mutuall eating one another,
Which they doe doe, more cunningly, then the wilde
Anthropophagi; that snatch onely strangers,
Like my old Patrons dogs, there.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: O, my Vncles!
Is dinner ready, Lickfinger?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: When you please, Sir.
I was bespeaking but a parcell of newes,
To strew out the long meale withall, but't seemes
You are furnish'd here already.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: O, not halfe!

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: What Court-newes is there? any Proclamations,
Or Edicts to come forth.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Yes, there is one.
That the Kings Barber has got, for aid of our trade:
Whereof there is a manifest decay.
T let long hayre runne to seed▪ to sow bald pates.A Precept for the wearing of long haire,
To runne to seed, to sow bald pates withall,
And the preseruing fruitfull heads, and chins,
To help a mistery, almost antiquated.
Such as are bald and barren beyond hope,
Are to be separated, and set by
For Vshers, to old Countesses.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: And Coachmen.
To mount their boxes, reuerently, and driue,
Like Lapwings, with a shell vpo' their heads.
Thorow the streets. Ha'you no Newes o the Stge?
They'll aske me about new Playes, at dinner time.
And I should be as dumbe as a fish.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: O! yes.
There is a Legacy left to the Kings Players,Spalato's Legacy to the Players.
Both for their various shifting of their Scene,
And dext'rous change o'their persons to all shapes,
And all disguises: by the right reuerend
Archbishop of Spalato.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: He is dead,
That plai'd him!

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: Then, h'has lost his share o' the Legacy.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: What newes of Gundomar?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: A second Fistula,
Or an excoriation (at the least)
For putting the poore English-play, was writ of him,Gundo∣mar's vse of the game at Chesse, or Play so cal∣led.
To such a sordid vse, as (is said) he did,
Of cleansing his posterior's.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: Iustice! Iustice!

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Since when, he liues condemn'd to his share, at Bruxels.
And there sits filing certaine politique hinges,
To hang the States on, h'has heau'd off the hookes.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: What must you haue for these?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Thou shalt pay nothing,
But reckon 'hem in i'the bill. There's twenty pieces,
Her Grace bestowes vpon the Office, Thom,Hee giues 20. pieces, to the Of∣fice. Doubles it.
Write thou that downe for Newes.

SP.SPEAKER: REG.
SP.L: We may well do't,
We haue not many such.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: There's twenty more,
If you say so; my Princesse is a Princesse!
And put that too, vnder the Office Seale.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: If it will please your Grace to soiourne here,Cymbal takes Pecu∣nia aside, courts and wooes her, to the Office.
And take my roofe for couert, you shall know
The rites belonging to your blood, and birth,
Which few can apprehend: these sordid seruants,
Which rather are your keepers, then attendants,
Should not come neere your presence. I would haue
You waited on by Ladies, and your traine
Borne vp by persons of quality, and honour,
Your meat should be seru'd in with curious dances,
And set vpon the boord, with virgin hands,
Tun'd to their voices; not a dish remou'd,
But to the Musicke, nor a drop of wine,
Mixt, with his water, without Harmony,

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: You are a Courtier, Sir, or somewhat more;
That haue this tempting language!

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: I'm your seruant,
Exellent Princesse, and would ha'you appeare
That, which you are. Come forth State, and wonder,
Of these our times, dazle the vulgar eyes.
And strike the people blind with admiration.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CAN.
SP.L: Why, that's the end of wealth! thrust riches outward,
And remaine beggers within: contemplate nothing
But the vile sordid things of time, place, money,
And let the noble, and the precious goe,
Vertue and honesty; hang 'hem; poore thinne membranes
Of honour; who respects them? O, the Fates!
How hath all iust, true reputation fall'n,
Fitton hath beene cour∣ting the wai∣ting-women, this while, and is ieered by them.Since money, this base money 'gan to haue any!

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.P: Pitty, the Gentleman is not immortall.

SP.SPEAKER: WAX.
SP.P: As he giues out, the place is, by description.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: A very Paradise, if you saw all, Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: WAX.
SP.L: I am the Chamber-maid, Sir, you mistake,
My Lady may see all.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Sweet Mistresse Statute, gentle Mistresse Band,
And Mother Mortgage, doe but get her Grace
To soiourne here.—

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: I thanke you gentle Waxe,

SP.SPEAKER: MOR.
SP.P: If it were a Chattell, I would try my credit.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: So it is, for terme of life, we count it so.

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: She meanes, Inheritance to him, and his heyres▪
Or that he could assure a State, of yeeres:
I'll be his Statute-Staple, Statute-Merchant,
Or what he please.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: He can expect no more.

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: His cousin Alderman Security,
That he did talke of so, e'en now—

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: Who, is
The very broch o'the bench, gem o'the City.

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: He and his Deputy, but assure his life
For one seuen yeeres.

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: And see what we'll doe for him,
Vpon his scarlet motion.

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: And old Chaine,
That drawes the city-eares.

SP.SPEAKER: WAX.
SP.L: When he sayes nothing,
But twirles it thus.

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.P: A mouing Oratory!

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: Dumb Rethoricke, and silent eloquence!
As the fine Poet saies!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Come, they all scorne vs,
Doe you not see't? the family of scorne!

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: Doe not belieue him! gentle Master Picklocke,
They vnderstood you not: the Gentlewomen,
They thought you would ha'my Lady soiourne, with you,
And you desire but now and then, a visit?

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Yes, if she pleas'd, Sir, it would much aduance
Vnto the Office, her continuall residence!
(I speake but as a member)

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: 'Tis inough.
I apprehend you. And it shall goe hard,
But I'll so worke, as some body shall worke her!

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: 'pray you change with our Master, but a word about it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Well, Lickfinger, see that our meat be ready,
Thou hast Newes inough.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Something of Bethlem Gabor,
And then I'm gone.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: We heare he has deuis'd
Bethlem Gabors Drum.A Drumme, to fill all Christendome with the sound:
But that he cannot drawe his forces neere it,
To march yet, for the violence of the noise.
And therefore he is faine by a designe,
To carry 'hem in the ayre, and at some distance,
Till he be married, then they shall appeare.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Or neuer; well, God b'wi'you (stay, who's here?)
A little of the Duke of Bauier, and then—

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.L: Hhas taken a gray habit,The Duke of Bauier. and is turn'd
The Churches Millar, grinds the catholique grist
With euery wind: and Tilly takes the toll.

SP.SPEAKER: CVS. 4.
SP.L: Ha'you any newes o'the Pageants to send downe?
Into the seuerall Counties.4. Cust. The Page∣ants. All the countrey
Expected from the city most braue speeches▪
Now, at the Coronation.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: It expected
More then it vnderstood: for, they stand mute,
Poore innocent dumb things; they are but wood.
As is the bench and blocks, they were wrought on, yet
If May-day come, and the Sunne shine, perhaps,
They'll sing like Memnons Statue, and be vocall.

SP.SPEAKER: CVS. 5.
SP.P: Ha'you any Forest-newes?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: None very wild, Sir,
Some tame there is, out o'the Forrest of fooles,5. Cust. The new Parke in the Forrest of Fooles.
A new Parke is a making there, to seuer
Cuckolds of Antler, from the Rascalls. Such,
Whose wiues are dead, and haue since cast their heads,
Shall remaine Cuckolds-pollard.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.P: I'll ha'that newes.

SP.SPEAKER: CVS.
SP.P: 1. And I. 2. And I. 3. And I. 4. And I. 5. And I.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Sir, I desire to be excus'd; and, Madame:Peny-boy would inuite the Master of the Office
I cannot leaue my Office, the first day.
My Cousin Fitton here, shall wait vpon you.
And Emissary Picklocke.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: And Thom: Clericus?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: I cannot spare him yet, but he shall follow you,
When they haue ordered the Rolls. Shut vp th'Office,
When you ha'done, till two a clocke.
BY your leaue, Clerkes,
Where shall we dine to day? doe you know? the Ieerers.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: Where's my fellow Fitton?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: New gone forth.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Cannot your Office tell vs, what braue fellowes
Doe eat together to day, in towne, and where?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Yes, there's a Gentleman, the braue heire, yong Peny-boy,
Dines in Apollo.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: Come, let's thither then,
I ha' supt in Apollo!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: With the Muses?

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: No,
But with two Gentlewomen, call'd, the Graces▪

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: They' were euer three in Poetry.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: This was truth, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: Sir, Master Fitton's there too!

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: All the better!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: We may haue a ieere, perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Yes, you'll drink, Doctor.
(If there be any good meat) as much good wine now,
As would lay vp a Dutch Ambassador.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: If he dine there, he's sure to haue good meat,
For, Lickfinger prouides the dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: Who?
The glory o'the Kitchin? that holds Cookery,
A trade from Adam? quotes his broths▪ and sallads?
And sweares he's not dead yet, but translated
In some immortall crust, the past of Almonds?

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: The same. He holds no man can be a Poet,
That is not a good Cooke, to know the palats,
And seuerall tastes o'the time. He drawes all Arts
Out of the Kitchin, but the Art of Poetry,
which he concludes the same with Cookery.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Tut, he maintaines more heresies then that.
He'll draw the Magisterium from a minc'd-pye,
And preferre Iellies, to your Iulips, Doctor▪

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: I was at an Olla Podrida of his making,
Was a braue piece of cookery! at a funerall!
But opening the pot-lid, he made vs laugh,
who'had wept all day! and sent vs such a tickling
Into our nostrills, as the funerall feast
Had bin a wedding-dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Gi'him allowance,
And that but moderate, he will make a Syren
Sing i'the Kettle, send in an Arion,
In a braue broth, and of a watry greene,
Iust the Sea-colour, mounted on the backe
Of a growne Cunger, but, in such a posture,
As all the world would take him for a Dolphin.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: Hee's a rare fellow, without question! but
He holds some Paradoxes.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: I, and Pseudodoxes.
Mary, for most, he's Orthodox i'the Kitchin.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: And knowes the Clergies tast!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: I, and the Layties!

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: You thinke not o'your time, we'll come too late,
If we go not presently.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: Away then.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Sirs,
You must get o'this newes, to store your Office,
VVho dines and sups i' the towne? where, and with whom?
'Twill be beneficiall: when you are stor'd;
And as we like our fare, we shall reward you.

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.P: A hungry trade,'twill be.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Much like D. Humphries,
But, now and then, as th'holesome prouerb saies,
'Twill obsonare samem ambulando.

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.P: Shut vp the Office: gentle brother Thomas.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Brother, Nathaniel, I ha'the wine for you.
I hope to see vs, one day, Emissaries.

SP.SPEAKER: CLA.
SP.P: Why not? S'lid, I despaire not to be Master!

SP.L: HOw now? I thinke I was borne vnder Hercules starre!
Nothing but trouble and tumult to oppresse me?He is started with Bro∣ker's com∣ming back.
Why come you backe? where is your charge?

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: I ha'brought
A Gentleman to speake with you?

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: To speake with me?
You know 'tis death for me to speake with any man.
What is he? set me a chaire.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: He's the Master
Of the great Office.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.L: The Staple of Newes,
A mighty thing, they talke Six thousand a yeere.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: Well bring your sixe in. Where ha' you left Pecunia?

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: Sir, in Apollo, they are scarce set.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: Bring sixe.

SP.SPEAKER: BRO.
SP.P: Here is the Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: He must pardon me,
I cannot rise, a diseas'd man.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: By no meanes, Sir,
Respect your health, and ease.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: It is no pride in me!
But paine, paine; what's your errand, Sir, to me?Hee sends Broker backe.
Broker, returne to your charge, be Argus-eyed,
Awake, to the affaire you haue in hand,
Serue in Apollo, but take heed of Bacchus.
Goe on, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: I am come to speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: 'Tis paine for me to speake, a very death,
But I will heare you!

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Sir, you haue a Lady,
That soiournes with you.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Ha?He pretends infirmity. I am somewhat short
In my sense too—

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Pecunia.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: O' that side,
Very imperfect, on—

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Whom I would draw
Oftner to a poore Office, I am Master of—

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: My hearing is very dead, you must speake quicker.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Or, if it please you, Sir, to let her soiourne
In part with me; I haue a moyety
We will diuide, halfe of the profits.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Ha?
I heare you better now, how come they in?
Is it a certaine businesse, or a casuall?
For I am loth to seeke out doubtfull courses,
Runne any hazardous paths, I loue streight waies,
A iust, and vpright man! now all trade totters.
The trade of money, is fall'n, two i'the hundred.
That was a certaine trade, while th' age was thrifty,
And men good husbands, look'd vnto their stockes,
Had their mindes bounded; now the publike Riot
Prostitutes all, scatters away in coaches,
In foot-mens coates, and waiting womens gownes,
They must haue veluet hanches (with a pox)
Now taken vp, and yet not pay the vse;
Hee talkes vehemently and aloud.Bate of the vse? I am mad with this times manners.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: You said e'en now, it was death for you to speake.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: I, but an anger, a iust anger, (as this is)
Puts life in man. Who can endure to see
The fury of mens gullets, and their groines?
Is mou'd more and more.What fires, what cookes, what kitchins might be spar'd?
What Stewes, Ponds, Parks, Coupes, Garners, Magazines?
What veluets, tissues, scarfes, embroyderies?
And laces they might lacke? They couet things—
Superfluous still; when it were much more honour
They could want necessary! What need hath Nature
Of siluer dishes? or gold chamber-pots?
Of perfum'd napkins? or a numerous family,
To see her eate? Poore, and wise she, requires
Meate onely; Hunger is not ambitious:
Say, that you were the Emperour of pleasures,
The great Dictator of fashions, for all Europe,
And had the pompe of all the Courts, and Kingdomes,
Laid forth vnto the shew? to make your selfe
Gaz'd, and admir'd at? You must goe to bed,
And take your naturall rest: then, all this vanisheth.
Your brauery was but showen; 'twas not possest:
While it did boast it selfe, it was then perishing.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: This man has healthfull lungs.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: All that ex∣cesse
Appear'd as little yours, as the Spectators.
It scarce fills vp the expectation
Of a few houres, that entertaines mens liues.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: He has the monopoly of sole-speaking.
He is angry.Why, good Sir? you talke all.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Why should I not?
Is it not vnder mine owne roofe? my feeling?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: But I came hete to talk with you.

SP.SPEAKER: P. S.
SP.L: Why, an'I will not
Talke with you, Sir? you are answer'd, who sent for you?

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Bids him get out of his house.No body sent for me—

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: But you came, why then
Goe, as you came, heres no man holds you, There,
There lies your way, you see the doore.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: This's strange!

SP.SPEAKER: P. Se.
SP.L: 'Tis my ciuility, when I doe not rellish
The party, or his businesse. Pray you be gone, Sir.
I'll ha' no venter in your Ship, the Office
Your Barke of Six, if'twere sixteene, good, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: You are a rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: I thinke I am Sir, truly.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: Cymbal railes at him. He ieeres him.A Rascall, and a money-bawd.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: My surnames:

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.P: A wretched Rascall!

SP.SPEAKER: P. S.
SP.L: You will ouerflow—
And spill all.

SP.SPEAKER: CYM.
SP.L: Caterpiller, moath,
Horse-leach, and dung-worme—

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Still you lose your labor.
I am a broken vessell, all runnes out:
A shrunke old Dryfat. Fare you well, good Sixe.

DIV1.HEAD: The third Intermeane after the third Act.

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: A notable tough Rascall! this old Peny-boy! right City-bred!

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: In Siluer-streete, the Region of money, a good seat for a Vsurer.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: He has rich ingredients in him, I warrant you, if they were ex∣tracted, a true receit to make an Alderman, an' he were well wrought vpon, according to Art.

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: I would faine see an Alderman in chimia! that is a treatise of Aldermanity truely written.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: To shew how much it differs from Vrbanity.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: I, or humanity. Either would appeare in this Peny-boy, an' hee were rightly distill'd. But how like you the newes? you are gone from that.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: O, they are monstrous! scuruy! and stale! and too exotick! ill cook'd! and ill dish'd!

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: They were as good, yet, as butter could make them!

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: In a word, they were beastly buttered! he shall neuer come o' my bread more, nor my in mouth, if I can helpe it. I haue had better newes from the bake-house, by ten thousand parts, in a morning: or the conduicts in Westminster! all the newes of Tutle-street, and both the Alm'ries! the two Sanctuaries▪ long, and round Wool-staple! with Kings-street, and Chanon-row to boot!

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: I, my Gossip Tatle knew what fine slips grew in Gardiners-lane; who kist the Butchers wife with the Cowes-breath; what matches were made in the bowling-Alley, and what bettes wonne and lost; how much grieft went to the Mill and what besides: who coniur'd in Tutle-fields, and how many? when they neuer came there. And which Boy rode vpon Doctor Lambe, in the likenesse of a roaring Lyon, that runne away with him in his teeth, and ha's not deuour'd him yet.

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: Why, I had it from my maid Ioane Heare-say: and shee had it from a limbe o'the schoole, shee saies, a little limbe of nine yeere old; who told her, the Master left out his coniuring booke one day, and hee found it, and so the Fable came about. But whether it were true, or no, we Gossips are bound to beleeue it, an't be once out, and a foot: how should wee entertaine the time else, or finde our selues in fashionable discourse, for all companies, if we do not credit all, and make more of it, in the reporting?

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P:
For my part, I beleeue it: and there were no wiser then I, I would haue ne'er a cunning Schoole-Master in England. I meane a Cun∣ning-Man, a Schoole-Master; that is a Coniurour, or a Poet, or that had any acquaintance with a Poet. They make all their schollers Play-boyes! Is't not a fine sight, to see all our children made Enter∣luders? Doe wee pay our money for this? wee send them to learne their
Grammar, and their Terence, and they learne their play-books? well, they talke, we shall haue no more Parliaments (God blesse vs) but an'wee haue, I hope, Zeale-of-the-land Buzy, and my Gossip, Rabby Trou∣ble-truth will start vp, and see we shall haue painfull good Ministers to keepe Schoole, and Catechise our youth, and not teach 'hem to speake Playes, and Act Fables of false newes, in this manner, to the super-uexa∣tion of Towne and Countrey, with a wanion.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. IIII. SCENE. I.
DIV2.STAGE: PENY-BOY. IV. FITTON. SHVNFIELD. ALMANACK. MADRIGAL. CAN∣TER. PICKLOCKE.

SP.L: COme, Gentlemen, let's breath from healths a while.
This Lickfinger has made vs a good dinner,
For our Pecunia: what shal's doe with our selues,
While the women water? and the Fidlers eat?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Let's ieere a little.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Ieere? what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Ex∣pect, Sr.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: We first begin with our selues, & then at you,

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: A game we vse.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: We ieere all kind of persons
We meete withall, of any rancke or quality,
And if we cannot ieere them, we ieere our selues.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: A pretty sweete society! and a gratefull!

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: 'Pray let's see some.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Haue at you, then Lawyer.
They say, there was one of your coate in Bet'lem, lately,

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: I wonder all his Clients were not there.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: They were the madder sort.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Except, Sir, one
Like you, and he made verses.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Madrigall,
A ieere.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: I know.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: But what did you doe, Lawyer?
When you made loue to Mistresse Band, at dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: Why? of an Aduocate, he grew the Clyent.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Well play'd, my Poet.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: And shew'd the Law of nature
Was there aboue the Common-Law.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Quit, quit,

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Call you this ieering? I can play at this,
'Tis like a Ball at Tennis.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Very like,
But we were not well in.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: 'Tis indeed, Sir.
When we doe speake at volley, all the ill
We can one of another.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: As this morning,
(I would you had heard vs) of the Rogue your Vncle.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM
SP.P: That Mony-bawd.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: We call'd him a Coat-card
O'the last order.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What's that? a Knaue?

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: Some readings haue it so, my manuscript
Doth speake it, arlet.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: And your selfe a Foole
O'the first ranke, and one shall haue the leading
O'the right-hand file, vnder this braue Commander.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What saist thou, Canter?

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Sir, I say this is
A very wholesome exercise, and comely.
Like Lepers, shewing one another their scabs.
Or flies feeding on vlcers.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: What Newes Gentlemen?
Ha' you any newes for after dinner? me thinks
We should not spend our time vnprofitably.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: They neuer lie, Sir, betweene meales, 'gainst supper
You may haue a Bale or two brought in.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: This Canter,
Is an old enuious Knaue!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: A very Rascall!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: I ha' mark'd him all this meale, he has done nothing
But mocke, with scuruy faces, all wee said.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: A supercilious Rogue! he lookes as if
He were the Patrico—

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: Or Arch-priest o'Canters,

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Hee's some primate metropolitan Rascall,
Our shot-clog makes so much of him.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM
SP.L: The Law,
And he does gouerne him

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What say you, Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: We say, we wonder not, your man o' Law,
Should be so gracious wi'you; but how it comes,
This Rogue, this Canter!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: O, good words.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: A fellow
That speakes no language—

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: But what gingling Gipsies,
And Pedlers trade in—

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: And no honest Christian
Can vnderstand—

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Why? by that argument,
You all are Canters, you, and you, and you,He speakes to all the Ieerers.
All the whole world are Canters, I will proue it
In your professions.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I would faine heare this,
But stay, my Princesse comes, prouide the while,
I'll call for't anone. How fares your Grace?

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. IIII. SCENE. II.
DIV2.STAGE: LICKFINGER. PECVNIA. STATVTE-BAND. VVAXE. to them.

SP.P: I hope the fare was good.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: Yes, Lickfinger,
Lickfinger is challeng'd by Madrigal of an argu∣ment.And we shall thanke you for't and reward you.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: Nay, I'll not lose my argument, Lickfinger;
Before these Gentlemen, I affirme,
The perfect, and true straine of poetry,
Is rather to be giuen the quicke Celler,
Then the fat Kitchin.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Heretique, I see
Thou art for the vaine Oracle of the Botle.
The hogshead, Trismegistus, is thy Pegasus.
Thence flowes thy Muses spring, from that hard hoofe:
Seduced Poet, I doe say to thee,
A Boyler, Range, and Dresser were the Fountaines,
Of all the knowledge in the vniuerse.
And they 'are the Kitchins, where the Master-Cooke—
(Thou dost not know the man, nor canst thou know him,
Till thou hast seru'd some yeeres in that deepe schoole,
That's both the Nurse and Mother of the Arts,
And hear'st him read, interpret, and demonstrate!)
A Master-Cooke! Why, he's the man o' men,
For a Professor! he designes, he drawes,
He paints, he carues, he builds, he fortifies,
Makes Citadels of curious fowle and fish,
Some he dri-dishes, some motes round with broths.
Mounts marrowbones, cuts fifty angled custards,
Reares bulwark pies, and for his outerworkes
He raiseth Ramparts of immortall crust;
And teacheth all the Tacticks, at one dinner:
What Rankes, what Files, to put his dishes in;
The whole Art Military. Then he knowes,
The influence of the Starres vpon his meats,
And all their seasons, tempers, qualities,
And so to fit his relishes, and sauces,
He has Nature in a pot, 'boue all the Chymists,
Or airy brethren of the Rosie-crosse.
He is an Architect, an Inginer,
A Souldiour, a Physician, a Philosopher,
A generall Mathematician.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: It is granted.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: And that you may not doubt him, for a Poet—

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: This fury shewes, if there were nothing else!
And 'tis diuine! I shall for euer hereafter,
Admire the wisedome of a Cooke!

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.P: And we, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: O, how my Princesse drawes me, with her lookes,Peny-boy is courting his Prin∣cesse all the while.
And hales me in, as eddies draw in boats,
Or strong Charybdis ships, that saile too neere
The shelues of Loue! The tydes of your two eyes!
Wind of your breath, are such as sucke in all,
That doe approach you!

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.P: Who hath chang'd my seruant?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Your selfe, who drinke my blood vp with your beames;
As doth the Sunne, the Sea! Pecunia shines
More in the world then he: and makes it Spring
Where e'r she fauours! 'please her but to show
Her melting wrests, or bare her yuorie hands,
She catches still! her smiles they are Loue's fetters!
Her brests his apples! her teats Stawberries!
Where Cupid (were he present now) would cry
Fare well my mothers milke, here's sweeter Nectar!
Helpe me to praise Pecunia, Gentlemen:
She's your Princesse, lend your wits,

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: A Lady,
The Graces taught to moue!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: The Floures did nurse!They all be∣ginne the ncomium of Pecunia.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Whose lips are the instructions of all Louers!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: Her eyes their lights, and riualls to the Starres!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: A voyce, as if that Harmony still spake!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: And polish'd skinne, whiter then Venus foote!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Young Hebes necke, or Iunoe's armes!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: A haire,
Large as the Mornings, and her breath as sweete,
As meddowes after raine, and but new mowne!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Laeda might yeeld vnto her, for a face!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: Hermione for brests!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Flora, for cheekes!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: And Helen for a mouth!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Kisse, kisse 'hem, Princesse.She kisseth them.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: The pearle doth striue in whitenesse, with her necke,

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: But loseth by it: here the Snow thawes Snow;
One frost resolues another!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: O, she has
A front too slippery to be look't vpon!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: And glances that beguile the seers eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Kisse, kisse againe, what saies my man o' warre?Againe.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: I say, she's more, then Fame can promise of her.
A Theame, that's ouercome with her owne matter!
Praise is strucke blind, and deafe, and dumbe with her!
Shee doth astonish Commendation!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Well pumpt i'faith old Sailor: kisse him too:
Though he be a slugge. What saies my Poet-sucker!She kisseth Captaine Shunfield.
He's chewing his Muses cudde, I doe see by him.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: I haue almost done, I want but e'ne to finish.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: That's the 'ill luck of all his workes still.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: To beginne many works, but finish none;

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: How does he do his Mistresse work?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Imperfect.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: I cannot thinke he finisheth that.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Let's heare▪

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: It is a Madrigall, I affect that kind
Of Poem, much.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: And thence you ha' the name.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: It is his Rose. He can make nothing else

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: I made it to the tune the Fidlers play'd,
That we all lik'd so well.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Good, read it, read it.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: The Sunne is father of all mettalls, you know,
Siluer, and gold.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: I, leaue your Prologues, say!

SP.SPEAKER: MADRIGAL.
SP.L: As bright as is the Sunne her Sire,
Or Earth her mother, in her best atyre,
Or Mint, the Mid-wife, with her sire,
Comes forth her Grace!
The splendour of the wealthiest Mines!
The stamp, and strength of all imperiall lines,
Both maiesty and beauty shines,
In her sweet face!
Looke how a Torch, of Taper light,
Or of that Torches flame, a Beacon bright;

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: That Mint the Midwife does well.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: That's fairely said of Money.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Good!

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: Now there, I want a line to finish, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Or of that Beacons fire, Moone-light:

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: So takes she place!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: 'Tis good.
And then I 'haue a Saraband—
She makes good cheare, she keepes full boards,
She holds a Faire of Knights, and Lords,
A Mercat of all Offices,
And Shops of honour, more or lesse.
According to Pecunia's Grace,
The Bride hath beauty, blood, and place,
The Bridegrome vertue, valour, wit,
And wisedome, as he stands for it.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Call in the Fidlers. Nicke, the boy shall sing it,
He vrgeth her to kisse them all.Sweet Princesse, kisse him, kisse 'hem all, deare Madame,
And at the close, vouchsafe to call them Cousins.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: Sweet Cousin Madrigall, and Cousin Fitton,
My Cousin Shunfield, and my learned Cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: Al-manach, though they call him Almanack.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Why, here's the Prodigall prostitutes his Mistresse!

SP.SPEAKER: P·IV.
SP.L: And Picklocke, he must be a kinsman too.
My man o' Law will teach vs all to winne,
And keepe our owne. Old Founder.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Nothing, I Sir?
I am a wretch, a begger. She the fortunate.
Can want no kindred, wee, the poore know none.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: Nor none shall know, by my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: Nor mine,

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Sing, boy, stand here.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Look, look,The boy sings the song. how all their eyes
Dance i'their heads (obserue) scatter'd with lust!
At sight o' their braue Idoll! how they are tickl'd,
With a light ayre! the bawdy Saraband!
They are a kinde of dancing engines all!
And set, by nature, thus, to runne alone
To euery sound! All things within, withou them,
Moue, but their braine, and that stands still! mere monsters
Here, in a chamber, of most subtill feet!
And make their legs in tune, passing the streetes!
These are the gallant spirits o'the age!
The miracles o'the time! that can cry vp
And downe mens wits! and set what rate on things
Their half-brain'd fancies please! Now pox vpon'hem.
See how solicitously he learnes the Iigge,
As if it were a mystery of his faith!

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: A dainty ditty!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: O, hee's a dainty Poet!
When he sets to't!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: And a dainty Scholler!They are all struck with admiration.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: No, no great scholler, he writes like a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Pox o' your Scholler.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Pox o'your distinction!
As if a Scholler were no Gentleman.
With these, to write like a Gentleman, will in time
Become, all one, as to write like an Asse,
These Gentlemen? these Rascalls! I am sicke
Of indignation at 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: How doe you lik't, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: 'Tis excellent!

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: 'Twas excellently sung!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: A dainty Ayre!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What saies my Lickfinger?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: I am telling Mistresse Band, and Mistresse Statute,
What a braue Gentleman you are, and Waxe, here!
How much 'twere better, that my Ladies Grace,
Would here take vp Sir, and keepe house with you.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What say they?

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.P: We could consent, Sr, willingly.

SP.SPEAKER: BAND.
SP.P: I, if we knew her Grace had the least liking.

SP.SPEAKER: WAX.
SP.P: We must obey her Graces will, and pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I thanke you, Gentlewomen, ply 'hem, Lickfinger.
Giue mother Mortgage, there—

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Her doze of Sacke.
I haue it for her, and her distance of Hum.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: Indeede therein, I must confesse, deare Cousin,The Gallants are all about Pecunia.
I am a most vnfortunate Princesse.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: And
You still will be so, when your Grace may helpe it.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: Who'ld lie in a roome, with a close-stoole, and garlick?
And kennell with his dogges? that had a Prince
Like this young Peny-boy, to soiourne with?

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: He'll let you ha' your liberty—

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.L: Goe forth,
Whither you please, and to what company—

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: Scatter your selfe amongst vs—

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Hope of Pernassus!
Thy Iuy shall not wither, nor thy Bayes,
Thou shalt be had into her Graces Cellar,
And there know Sacke, and Claret, all December,
Thy veine is rich, and we must cherish it.
Poets and Bees swarme now adaies, but yet
There are not those good Tauernes, for the one sort,
As there are Flowrie fields to feed the other.
Though Bees be pleas'd with dew, aske little Waxe
That brings the honey to her Ladyes hiue:
The Poet must haue wine. And he shall haue it.

SP.P: BRoker? what Broker?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Who's that? my Vncle!

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: I am abus'd, where is my Knaue? my Broker?

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Your Broker is laid out vpon a bench, yonder,
Sacke hath seaz'd on him, in the shape of sleepe.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: Hee hath beene dead to vs almost this houre.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE
SP.P: This houre?

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: Why sigh you Sr? 'cause he's at rest?

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: It breeds my vnrest.

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Will you take a cup
H strikes the Sacke out of his hand.And try if you can sleepe?

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: No, cogging Iacke,
Thou and thy cups too, perish.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: O, the Sacke!

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: The sacke, the sacke!

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: A Madrigall on Sacke!

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.P: Or rather an Elegy, for the Sacke is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: VVhy doe you this, Sir? spill the wine, and raue?
For Brokers sleeping?

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: VVhat through sleepe, and Sacke,
My trust is wrong'd: but I am still awake,
Hee would haue Pecu∣nia home. But shee refuseth. And her Traine.To waite vpon your Grace, please you to quit
This strange lewd company, they are not for you.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.P: No Guardian, I doe like them very well.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE
SP.L: Your Graces pleasure be obseru'd, but you
Statute, and Band, and Waxe, will goe with me.

SP.SPEAKER: SAT.
SP.P: Truly we will not.

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: VVe will stay, and wait here
Vpon her Grace, and this your Noble Kinsman.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.P: Noble? how noble! who hath made him noble?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: VVhy, my most noble money hath, or shall▪
My Princesse, here. She that had you but kept,
And treated kindly, would haue made you noble,
And wise, too: nay, perhaps haue done that for you,
An Act of Parliament could not, made you honest.
The truth is, Vncle, that her Grace dislikes
Her entertainment: specially her lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: Nay, say her iaile. Neuer vnfortunate Princesse,
Was vs'd so by a Iaylor. Aske my women,
Band, you can tell, and Statute, how he has vs'd me,
Kept me close prisoner, vnder twenty bolts—

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: And forty padlocks—

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: All malicious ingines
A wicked Smith could forge out of his yron:
As locks, and keyes, shacles, and manacles,
To torture a great Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: H'has abus'd
Your Graces body.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: No, he would ha' done,
That lay not in his power: he had the vse
Of our bodies, Band, and Waxe, and sometimes Statutes:
But once he would ha'smother'd me in a chest,
And strangl'd me in leather, but that you
Came to my rescue, then, and gaue mee ayre.

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: For which he cramb'd vs vp in a close boxe,
All three together, where we saw no Sunne
In one sixe moneths.

SP.SPEAKER: WAX.
SP.P: A cruell man he is!

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: H'has left my fellow Waxe out, i'the cold,

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: Till she was stiffe, as any frost, and crumbl'd
Away to dust, and almost lost her forme.

SP.SPEAKER: WAX.
SP.P: Much adoe to recouer me.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Women Ieerers!
Haue you learn'd too, the subtill facultie?
Come, I'll shew you the way home, if drinke,
Or, too full diet haue disguis'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: Troth,
We haue not any mind, Sir, of returne—

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: To be bound back to backe.—

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.L: And haue our legs
Turn'd in, or writh'd about—

SP.SPEAKER: WAX.
SP.L: Or else display'd—

SP.SPEAKER: STA.
SP.L: Be lodg'd with dust and fleas, as we were wont—

SP.SPEAKER: BAN.
SP.P: And dyeted with dogs dung.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Why? you whores,
My bawds, my instruments, what should I call you,
Man may thinke base inough for you?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Heare you, vncle.
I must not heare this of my Princesse seruants,
And in Apollo, in Pecunia's roome,
Goe, get you downe the staires: Home, to your Kennell,
As swiftly as you can. Consult your dogges,
The Lares of your family; or beleeue it,
The fury of a foote-man, and a drawer
Hangs ouer you.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Cudgell, and pot doe threaten
A kinde of vengeance.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: Barbers are at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: Washing and shauing will ensue.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: The PumpeThey all threaten,
Is not farre off; If't were, the sinke is neere:
Or a good Iordan.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: You haue now no money,

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: But are a Rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: I am cheated, robb'd
Ieer'd by confederacy.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: No, you are kick'd
And vsed kindly, as you should be.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: Spurn'd,And spurne him.
From all commerce of men, who are a curre.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P:
Kicke him, out▪
Hee ex∣claimes.A stinking dogge, in a dublet, with foule linnen.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: A snarling Rascall, hence.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Out.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Wel, re∣member,
I am coozen'd by my Cousin, and his whore!
Bane o'these meetings in Apollo!

SP.SPEAKER: LIC.
SP.L: Goe, Sir,
One of his Dogges.You will be tost like Block, in a blanket else.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Downe with him, Lickfinger.

SP.SPEAKER: P. SE.
SP.L: Saucy Iacke away,
Pecunia is a whore.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Play him downe, Fidlers,
And drown his noise. Who's this!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: O Master Pyed-mantle!
Pyed-man∣tle brings the Lady Pecunia her pedigree.BY your leaue, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.L: Her Graces Herald,

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: No Herald yet, a Heraldet.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: A Canter.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: O, thou said'st thou'dst sprone vs all so!

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Sir, here is one will proue himselfe so, streight,
So shall the rest, in time.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: My Pedigree?
I tell you, friend, he must be a good Scholler,
Can my discent. I am of Princely race,
And as good blood, as any is i'the mines,
Runnes through my veines. I am, euery limb, a Princesse!
Dutchesse o' mynes, was my great Grandmother.
And by the Fathers side, I come from Sol.
My Grand-father was Duke of Or, and match'd
In the blood-royall of Ophyr.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.P: Here's his Coat.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.P: I know it, if I heare the Blazon.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.L: He beares
In a field Azure, a Sunne proper, beamy,
Twelue of the second.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: How farr's this from canting?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Her Grace doth vnderstand ti.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: She can cant, S•.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.P: What be these? Besants?

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.P: Yes, an't please your Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: That is our Coat too, as we come from Or.
What line's this?

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.L: The rich mynes of Potosi.
The Spanish mynes i'the West-Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.P: This?

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.P: The mynes o' Hungary, this of Barbary.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.P: But this, this little branch.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.P: The Welsh-myne that.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.P: I ha'Welsh-blood in me too, blaze, Sir, that Coat.

SP.SPEAKER: PYE.
SP.L: She beares (an't please you) Argent, three leekes vert
In Canton Or, and tassel'd of the first.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: Is not this canting? doe you vnderstand him?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Not I, but it sounds well, and the whole thing
Is rarely painted, I will haue such a scrowle,
What ere it cost me.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.L: VVell, at better leasure,
We'll take a view of it, and so reward you.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Kisse him, sweet Princesse, and stile him a Cousin.She kisseth.

SP.SPEAKER: PEC.
SP.P: I will, if you will haue it. Cousin Pyed-mantle.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I loue all men of vertue, from my Princesse,
Vnto my begger, here, old Canter, on,
On to thy proofe, whom proue you the next Canter?

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: The Doctor here, I will proceed with the learned.
VVhen he discourseth of dissection,
Or any point of Anatomy: that hee tells you,
Of Vena caua, and of vena porta,
The Meseraicks, and the Mesenterium.
VVhat does hee else but cant? Or if he runne
To his Iudiciall Astrologie,
And trowle the Trine, the Quartile and the Sextile,
Platicke aspect, and Partile, with his Hyleg
Or Alchochoden, Cuspes, and Horroscope.
Does not he cant? VVho here does vnderstand him?

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: This is no Canter, tho!

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Or when my Muster-Master
Talkes of his Tacticks, and his Rankes, and Files;
His Bringers vp, his Leaders on, and cries,
Faces about to the right hand, the left,
Now, as you were: then tells you of Redoubts,
Of Cats, and Cortines. Doth not he cant?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Yes, 'faith.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: My Eg-chind Laureat, here, when he comes forth
With Dimeters, and Trimeters, Tetrameters,
Pentameters, Hexameters, Catalecticks,
His Hyper, and his Brachy-Catalecticks,
His Pyrrhichs, Epitrites, and Choriambicks.
What is all this, but canting?

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: A rare fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: Some begging Scholler!

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: A decay'd Doctor at least!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Nay, I doe cherish vertue, though in rags.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: And you, Mas Courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Now he treats of you,
Stand forth to him, faire.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: With all your fly-blowne proiects,
And lookes out of the politicks, your shut-faces,
And reseru'd Questions, and Answers that you game with, As
Is't a Cleare businesse? will it mannage well?
My name must not be vs'd else. Here, 'twill dash.
Your businesse has receiu'd a taint, giue off,
I may not prostitute my selfe. Tut, tut,
That little dust I can blow off, at pleasure.
Here's no such mountaine, yet, i'the whole worke!
But a light purse may leuell. I will tyde
This affayre for you; giue it freight, and passage.
And such mynt-phrase, as 'tis the worst of canting,
By how much it affects the sense, it has not.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: This is some other then he seemes!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: How like you him?

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: This cannot be a Canter!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: But he is, Sir,
And shall be still, and so shall you be too:
We'll all be Canters. Now, I thinke of it,
A noble Whimsie's come into my braine!
Canters-Colledge, begun to be erected.I'll build a Colledge, I, and my Pecunia,
And call it Canters Colledge, sounds it well?

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: Excellent!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: And here stands my Father Rector,
And you Professors, you shall all professe
Something, and liue there, with her Grace and me,
Your Founders: I'll endow't with lands, and meanes,
And Lickfinger shall be my Master-Cooke.
What? is he gone?

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: And a Professor.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: And read Apicius de reculinaria
To your braue Doxie, and you!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: You, Cousin Fitton,
Shall (as a Courtier) read the politicks;
Doctor Al-manack, hee shall read Astrology,
Shunfield shall read the Military Arts.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.P: That's Ma∣drigall.As caruing, and assaulting the cold custard.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: And Horace here, the Art of Poetry.
His Lyricks, and his Madrigalls, fine Songs,
Which we will haue at dinner, steept in claret,
And against supper, sowc't in sacke.

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.L: In troth
A diuine Whimsey!

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.L: And a worthy worke,
Fit for a Chronicle!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Is't not?

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: To all ages.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: And Pyed-mantle, shall giue vs all our Armes,
But Picklocke, what wouldst thou be? Thou canst cant too.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: In all the languages in Westminster-Hall,
Fleas, Bench, or Chancery. Fee-Farme, Fee-Tayle,
Tennant in dower, At will, For Terme of life,
By Copy of Court Roll, Knights seruice, Homage,
Fealty, Escuage, Soccage, or Frank almoigne,
Grand Sergeanty, or Brgage.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Thou appear'st,
a Canter. Thou shalt read
All Littletons tenures to me, and indeed
All my Conueyances.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: And make 'hem too, Sir?
Keepe all your Courts, be Steward o'your lands,
Let all your Leases, keepe your Euidences,
But first, I must procure, and passe your mort-maine
You must haue licence from aboue, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: Feare not,
Pecunia's friends shall doe it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: But I shall stop it.
Your worships louing, and obedient father,
Your painefull Steward, and lost Officer!
Here his fa∣ther disco∣uers him∣selfe.Who haue done this, to try how you would vse
Pecunia, when you had her: which since I see,
I will take home the Lady, to my charge,
And these her seruants, and leaue you my Cloak,
To trauell in to Beggers Bush! A Seate,
Is built already, furnish'd too, worth twentie
Of your imagin'd structures, Canters Colledge.

SP.SPEAKER: FIT.
SP.P: 'Tis his Father!

SP.SPEAKER: MAD.
SP.P: Hee's aliue, me thinks.

SP.SPEAKER: ALM.
SP.P: I knew he was no Rogue!

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: Thou, Prodigall,
Was I so carefull for thee, to procure,
And plot wi' my learn'd Counsell, Master Picklocke,
This noble match for thee, and dost thou prostitute,
Scatter thy Mistresse fauours, throw away
Her bounties, as they were red-burning coales,
Too hot for thee to handle, on such rascalls?
Who are the scumme, and excrements of men?
If thou had'st sought out good, and vertuous persons
Of these professions: I'had lou'd thee, and them.
For these shall neuer haue that plea 'gainst me,
Or colour of aduantage, that I hate
Their callings, but their manners, and their vices.
A worthy Courtier, is the ornament
Of a Kings Palace, his great Masters honour.
This is a moth, a rascall, a Court-rat,
That gnawes the common-wealth with broking suits,
And eating grieuances! So, a true Souldier,
He is his Countryes strength, his Soueraignes safety,
And to secure his peace, he makes himselfe.
The heyre of danger, nay the subiect of it,
And runnes those vertuous hazards, that this Scarre-crow
Cannot endure to heare of.

SP.SPEAKER: SHV.
SP.P: You are pleasant, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: P. CA.
SP.L: With you I dare be! Here is Pyed-mantle,
'Cause he's an Asse, doe not I loue a Herald?
Who is the pure preseruer of descents,
The keeper faire of all Nobility,
Without which all would runne into confusion?
Were he a learned Herald, I would tell him
He can giue Armes, and markes, he cannot honour,
No more then money can make Noble: It may
Giue place, and ranke, but it can giue no Vertue.
And he would thanke me, for this truth. This dog-Leach,
You stile him Doctor, 'cause he can compile
An Almanack; perhaps erect a Scheme
For my great Madame monkey: when 't has ta'ne
A glister, and bewrai'd the Ephemerides.
Doe I despise a learn'd Physician?
In calling him a Quack-Saluer? or blast
The euer-liuing ghirlnd, alwaies greene
Of a good Poet? when I say his wreath
Is piec'd and patch'd of dirty witherd flowers?
Away, I am impatient of these vlcers,
(That I not call you worse) There is no sore,
Or Plague but you to infect the times. I abhorre
Your very scent. Come, Lady, since my Prodigall
Knew not to entertaine you to your worth,
I'll see if I haue learn'd, how to receiue you,
Hee points him to his patch'd cloake throwne off.With more respect to you, and your faire traine here.
Farewell my Begger in veluet, for to day,
To morrow you may put on that graue Robe,
And enter your great worke of Canters Colledge,
Your worke and worthy of a Chronicle,

DIV1.HEAD: The fourth Intermeane after the fourth Act.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: Why? This was the worst of all! the Catastrophe!

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: The matter began to be good, but now: and he has spoyl'd it all, with his Begger there!

SP.SPEAKER: MIRT.
SP.P: A beggerly Iacke it is, I warrant him, and a kin to the Poet.

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: Like enough, for hee had the chiefest part in his play, if you marke it.

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: Absurdity on him, for a huge ouergrowne Play-maker! why should he make him liue againe, when they, and we all thought him dead? If he had left him to his ragges, there had beene an end of him.

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: I, but set a beggar on horse-backe, hee'll neuer linne till hee be a gallop.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: The young heyre grew a fine Gentleman, in this last Act!

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: So he did, Gossip: and kept the best company.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: And feasted 'hem, and his Mistresse!

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: And shew'd her to 'hem all! was not iealous!

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: But very communicatiue, and liberall, and beganne to be magnificent, if the churle his father would haue let him alone.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: It was spitefully done o' the Poet, to make the Chuffe take him off in his heighth, when he was going to doe all his braue deedes!

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: To found an Academy!

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: Erect a Colledge!

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: Plant his Professors, and water his Lectures.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: With wine, gossips, as he meant to doe, and then to de∣fraud his purposes?

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: Kill the hopes of so many towardly young spirits?

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: As the Doctors?

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: And the Courtiers! I protest, I was in loue with Master Fitton. He did weare all he had, from the hat-band, to the shooe-tye, so politically, and would stoop, and leere?

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: And lie so, in waite for a piece of wit, like a Mouse-trap?

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: Indeed Gossip, so would the little Doctor, all his behauiour was meere glister! O' my conscience, hee would make any parties physicke i' the world worke, with his discourse.

SP.SPEAKER: MIR.
SP.P: I wonder they would suffer it, a foolish old fornicating Father, to rauish away his sonnes Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: And all her women, at once, as hee did!

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: I would ha' flyen in his gypsies face i'faith.

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: It was a plaine piece of politicall incest, and worthy to be brought afore the high Commission of wit. Suppose we were to censure him, you are the youngest voyce, Gossip Tatle, beginne.

SP.SPEAKER: TATLE.
SP.P: Mary, I would ha' the old conicatcher coozen'd of all he has, i'the young heyres defence, by his learn'd Counsell, Mr Picklocke!

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: I would rather the Courtier had found out some tricke to begge him, from his estate!

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: Or the Captaine had courage enough to beat him.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: Or the fine Madrigall-man, in rime, to haue runne him out o' the Countrey, like an Irish rat.

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: No, I would haue Master Pyed-mantle, her Graces He∣rald, to pluck downe his hatchments, reuerse his coat-armour, and nul∣lifie him for no Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: Nay, then let Master Doctor dissect him, haue him open'd, and his tripes translated to Lickfinger, to make a probation dish of.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN. TAT.
SP.P: Agreed! Agreed!

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: Faith I would haue him flat disinherited, by a decree of Court, bound to make restitution of the Lady Pecunia, and the vse of her body to his sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: And her traine, to the Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: And both the Poet, and himselfe, to aske them all forgiuenesse!

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: And vs too▪

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.L: In two large sheetes of paper—

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: Or to stand in a skin of parchment, (which the Court please)

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: And those fill'd with newes!

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: And dedicated to the sustaining of the Staple!

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: Which their Poet hath let fall, most abruptly?

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: Banckruptly, indeede!

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: You say wittily, Gossip, and therefore let a protest goe out a∣gainst him.

SP.SPEAKER: MIR.
SP.P: A mourniuall of protests; or a gleeke at least!

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: In all our names:

SP.SPEAKER: CEN.
SP.P: For a decay'd wit—

SP.SPEAKER: EXP.
SP.P: Broken—

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: Non-soluent—

SP.SPEAKER: CENSVRE.
SP.P: And, for euer, forfet—

SP.SPEAKER: MIRTH.
SP.P: To scorne, of Mirth?

SP.SPEAKER: TAT.
SP.P: Subsign'd. Tatle, Stay, they come againe.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. V. SCENE. I.
DIV2.STAGE: PENY-BOY. IV. to him THO. BARBER. after, PICKLOCKE.

SP.L: Hee comes out in the patchd cloak his father left him.NAy, they are fit, as they had been made for me,
And I am now a thing, worth looking at!
The same, I said I would be in the morning.
No Rogue, at a Comitia of the Canters,
Did euer there become his Parents Robes
Better, then I do these: great foole! and begger!
Why doe not all that are of those societies,
Come forth, and gratulate mee one of theirs?
Me thinkes, I should be, on euery side, saluted,
Dauphin of beggers! Prince of Prodigalls!
That haue so fall'n vnder the eares, and eyes,
And tongues of all, the fable o'the time,
Matter of scorne, and marke of reprehension!
I now begin to see my vanity,
Shine in this Glasse, reflected by the foile!
Where is my Fashioner? my Feather-man?
My Linnener? Perfumer? Barber? all?
That tayle of Riot, follow'd me this morning?
Not one! but a darke solitude about mee,
Worthy my cloake, and patches; as I had
The epidemicall disease vpon mee:
And I'll sit downe with it.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: My Master! Maker!
How doe you? Why doe you sit thus o'the ground, Sir?
Heare you the newes?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: No, nor I care to heare none.
Would I could here sit still, and slip away
The other one and twenty, to haue this
Forgotten, and the day rac'd out, expung'd,
In euery Ephemerides, or Almanack.
Or if it must be in, that Time and Nature
Haue decree'd; still, let it be a day
Of tickling Prodigalls, about the gills;
Deluding gaping heires, loosing their loues,
And their discretions; falling from the fauours
Of their best friends, and parents; their owne hopes;
And entring the society of Canters.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: A dolefull day it is, and dismall times
Are come vpon vs: I am cleare vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: How, Thom?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: Why? broke! broke! wretchedly broke!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.P: Our Staple is all to pieces, quite dissolu'd!

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: Shiuer'd, as in an earth-quake! heard you not
The cracke and ruines? we are all blowne vp!
Soone as they heard th' Infanta was got from them,
Whom they had so deuoured i'their hopes,
To be their Patronesse, and soiourne with 'hem;
Our Emissaries, Register, Examiner,
Flew into vapor: our graue Gouernour
Into a subt'ler ayre; and is return'd
(As we doe heare) grand-Captaine of the Ieerers.
I, and my fellow melted into butter,
And spoyl'd our Inke, and so the Office vanish'd.
The last hum that it made, was, that your Father,
And Picklocke are fall'n out, the man o' Law.Hee starts vp at this.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: How? this awakes me from my lethargy.

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: And a great suite, is like to be betweene 'hem,
Picklocke denies the Feofement, and the Trust,
(Your Father saies) he made of the whole estate,
Vnto him, as respecting his mortalitie,
When he first laid this late deuice, to try you.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Has Picklock then a trust?

SP.SPEAKER: THO.
SP.L: I cannot tell,
Here comes the worshipfull—

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: What? my veluet-heyre,Picklocke enters.
Turn'd begger in minde, as robes?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: You see what case,
Your, and my Fathers plots haue brought me to.

SP.SPEAKER: P. C.
SP.L: Your Fathers, you may say, indeed, not mine.
Hee's a hard hearted Gentleman! I am sorie
To see his rigid resolution!
That any man should so put off affection,
And humane nature, to destroy his owne!
And triumph in a victory so cruell!
He's fall'n out with mee, for being yours,
And calls me Knaue, and Traytors to his Trust,
Saies he will haue me throwne ouer the Barre—

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Ha'you deseru'd it?

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: O, good heauen knowes
My conscience, and the silly latitude of it!
A narrow minded man! my thoughts doe dwell
All in a Lane, or line indeed; No turning,
Nor scarce obliquitie in them. I still looke
Right forward to th'intent, and scope of that
Which he would go from now.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Had you a Trust, then?

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Sir, I had somewhat, will keepe you still Lord
Of all the estate, (if I be honest) as
I hope I shall. My tender scrupulous brest
Will not permit me see the heyre defrauded,
And like an Alyen, thrust out of the blood,
The Lawes forbid that I should giue consent,
To such a ciuill slaughter of a Sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Where is the deed? hast thou it with thee?

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: No,
It is a thing of greater consequence,
Then to be borne about in a blacke boxe,
Like a Low-countrey vorloffe, or Welsh-briefe.
It is at Lickfingers, vnder locke and key.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: O, fetch it hither.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: I haue bid him bring it,
That you might see it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: Knowes he what brings?

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: No more then a Gardiners Asse, what roots he carries,

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I was a sending my Father, like an Asse,
A penitent Epistle, but I am glad
I did not, now.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC.
SP.L: Hang him, an austere grape,
That has no iuice, but what is veriuice in him.

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.P: I'll shew you my letter!

SP.SPEAKER: PC.
SP.L: Shew me a defiance!
Peny-boy runnes out to fetch his letter.If I can now commit Father, and Sonne,
And make my profits out of both. Commence
A suite with the old man, for his whole state,
And goe to Law with the Sonnes credit, vndoe
Both, both with their owne money, it were a piece
Worthy my night-cap, and the Gowne I weare,
A Picklockes name in Law. Where are you Sir?
What doe you doe so long?

SP.SPEAKER: P. IV.
SP.L: I cannot find
Where I haue laid it, but I haue laid it safe.

SP.SPEAKER: PIC
